"Deadpool and Wolverine" is a highly entertaining film that takes some bold creative risks, making it a refreshing addition to the superhero genre. However, it does fall short in terms of plot and narrative depth.The film's formula, while familiar, is executed well. It doesn't require viewers to have an encyclopedic knowledge of the Marvel universe, which is a refreshing change from some recent entries in the franchise. This accessibility is a welcome relief for casual fans who might feel overwhelmed by the interconnected storylines and myriad characters of the Marvel Cinematic Universe.One of the film's greatest strengths is its unabashed fan service. Much like "Spider-Man: No Way Home," it delights in bringing together beloved characters and playing to the audience's nostalgia and affection for the franchise. This approach ensures that the film is engaging and fun, even if it doesn't break new ground. The interactions between Deadpool and Wolverine are especially enjoyable, filled with the irreverent humor and banter that fans have come to expect from Deadpool and the gruff, no-nonsense attitude of Wolverine.However, "Deadpool and Wolverine" does suffer from a lack of substantial plot. The narrative feels more like a series of entertaining vignettes than a cohesive story. There's a sense that the film is more concerned with delivering memorable moments and fan-pleasing scenes than with crafting a compelling, overarching plot. As a result, it can feel somewhat aimless and insubstantial.In conclusion, "Deadpool and Wolverine" is a fun, enjoyable movie that succeeds in delivering fan service and entertaining character interactions. It may not be a masterpiece, but it doesn't need to be. Its primary goal is to entertain, and in that regard, it succeeds admirably. For fans of the characters, it's certainly worth a watch, even if it doesn't leave a lasting impact.

This movie, I got to say, is not much of a movie. Did I enjoy the jokes? Yes I did. Did I enjoy the big celebrity cameos? Absolutely. But, other than that, that's pretty much all this movie has to offer. I love the first 2 Deadpool movies because they were movies about Deadpool. This 3rd movie is a movie about Marvel. They should just call it, Big Super Marvel Cinematic Universe Movie, cause that's pretty much what it was.So if you're looking for some good laughs, and are into the multiverse thing, this movie is for you. If you're looking for a movie with an actual plot, with good characters and good development that actually leads to a point, then this movie is not for you.I would give it 2 stars out of 5.

I just watched Deadpool & Wolverine and it was an absolute blast! Seeing Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman together was a dream come true. Their chemistry is off the charts, and you can tell they're having a ton of fun. The humor is outrageous and hilarious, with plenty of moments that had me laughing out loud. The film balances humor with some genuinely heartfelt moments. Wolverine's gruff, no-nonsense attitude is the perfect foil to Deadpool's relentless goofiness, and their dynamic is pure gold.The action scenes are top-notch, with gory, over-the-top battles that showcase both characters' unique abilities. Plus, there are some fantastic cameos that made the experience even more enjoyable. Seeing familiar faces pop up unexpectedly added an extra layer of excitement to the movie.Overall, Deadpool & Wolverine is a fantastic addition to the MCU and a must-watch for any fan of these iconic characters. It's a wild, fun, and surprisingly touching ride that I can't wait to experience again.

Watched the premier last night. It truly met the hyped expectations. Am having trouble discerning whether it is better than the first film. The first deadpool took me by surprise with the action-comedy elements. Got all of that and more. Nothing was sacred. Left some story lines hanging but hopefully this finally stops the farces of multiple universes, changing timelines and all the confusion in the last few years. Recommended for anyone who likes the genre. If you're expecting a deep drama, don't go see this. You're not the target audience. Great comments, great Easter eggs, great cameos. The cameos caught me off guard. I was thrilled.

Absolutely one of the best movies I've ever watched and an amazing addition to the MCU. The amount of 4th wall breaks and iconic cameos made this movie full of surprises and the comedy never missed. Lots of bloody, gory fun with slicing and dicing all throughout the movie. Ryan and Hugh really outdid themselves with this movie and I hope to see more from them in the future.This plot sets up a lot of potential for the future MCU and connects the other Deadpool and X-men movies to the MCU storyline. I thought including the TVA was a really good idea and it made sense to the story, as well as connecting to the Loki series. Definitely a must watch for anyone not afraid of blood and offensive content.

I will start by saying I absolutely loved this movie. It was so nostalgic and so much fun to watch. The crazy amount of cameos from numerous former X-men characters as well as other superhero characters was so beautiful to watch and I am so appreciative that marvel and the directors took their time to really bring Deadpool full swing into the marvel universe. With that being said, I felt like Reynolds and marvel were so excited about making a rated r movie, that they forgot that there's more to movie making than swear words and debauchery. I have zero qualms with going all out, and I have never once cared about a movie having curse words, but it definitely felt like the director was almost trying to prove a point. It just felt like they were too busy trying to rub the rated r in your face rather than make a great movie. It still turned out amazing, and the story and acting was gold as ever, but it just tried too hard. It could have been even better if they would have accepted the rated r and used it without relying solely on it. Overall I loved the movie, it just felt forced and overbearing at times.

The highly anticipated pairing of Deadpool and Wolverine has finally hit the screens, and while it delivers an abundance of laughter and action, it falls short of being a truly exceptional film due to some pacing and scripting issues.One of the standout aspects of this movie is the return of Hugh Jackman as Wolverine, who slips back into the iconic role with ease. His presence is a welcome addition to the film, and his chemistry with Ryan Reynolds' Deadpool is undeniable. Reynolds, too, shines as the Merc with a Mouth, bringing his signature wit and irreverence to the role.The opening scene sets the tone for the film, showcasing an impressive action sequence that seamlessly blends humor and intensity. This tone is maintained throughout the movie, with plenty of laugh-out-loud moments that will leave audiences entertained. However, some of these moments feel stretched or overly reliant on Reynolds' quick wit, which can become exhausting at times.One of the primary issues with the film is its scripting. While the dialogue is often hilarious, some of Ryan Reynolds' lines feel too heavy-handed and could have been shortened or edited down for better flow. This is particularly noticeable in the film's second act, where the pacing begins to drag due to an overabundance of exposition and meandering subplots.Despite these flaws, the film's strengths lie in its ability to balance humor and heart. The dynamic between Deadpool and Wolverine is genuinely engaging, and their banter is some of the film's highlights. The action sequences are also well-choreographed and visually stunning, making for an immersive viewing experience.In conclusion, while Deadpool & Wolverine is an enjoyable film with plenty of laughs and exciting moments, it falls short of being a truly exceptional movie due to some scripting and pacing issues. With some tighter editing and more concise dialogue, this film could have reached its full potential. Nonetheless, fans of both characters will find plenty to love, and the chemistry between Jackman and Reynolds makes for a compelling watch.Rating: 7/10Recommendation: If you're a fan of either Deadpool or Wolverine, or enjoy action-comedies with a healthy dose of irreverence, this film is definitely worth watching. However, viewers seeking a more streamlined narrative may find themselves slightly disappointed.

The humour is pure Deadpool - And the chemistry between the Merc With The Mouth & the 200+ year old Logan is the absolute star of this comic book to big screen fest - All of the supporting cast add to the mayhem - Big shout out Blind Al (Disney give her a series) - Corrin is great as the protagonist even though she is not given a lot to work with script wise - The Cameos are all great but the best Cameo, the darkest of all was an amazing & so left field - Id skip 3D a wee tad gimmicky - maybe 15% too much breaking the wall - Overall a Huge Massive Meat injection into the Cultivated meat world of Marvel...

I am just going to say it for everyone if you enjoyed this film that's great it's good Marvel film in long time but it's not a great film at all. The story and plot are mess and doesn't make any sense at all. The flim sometimes feels sluggish and doesn't get to the point waste so much of the time with unnecessary dialogues and jokes that sometimes work but most times make you annoyed. Villan was just bland bad and seriously I haven't seen this bad of villan in long time. I didn't watch ms Marvel so I don't know. Now this film is fun one time watch that waste too much of its time. It does not effect MCU in any way shape or form honestly. There is just one scene with Happy some mention of Avengers but that's it. Now chemistry of huge Jackman and Ryan is absolute blast. It was fun to see them interact fight only good thing about this film. I had such high hopes for this Film but falls short on pretty much everything.

I just couldn't care less about this turd-burger of a film. Not especially worse than most of the MCU crap, but certainly not in the top-tier. And I mean, hey, if I'm being honest, a top-tier MCU film only ranks about a 7 anyway."Deadpool and Wolverine" is a film which consists almost entirely of fan-service. If you follow the comics and films so religiously that you can cite issues and pages (or seasons and episodes) like Bible-verses, then presumably this trifle is designed to flatter your knowledge endlessly. Perhaps it works in that light; I do not know.What I do know is, by normal storytelling measures, this film has absolutely nothing to offer. Every plot-development here is so arbitrary that the overall story makes no difference at all. There are no stakes, and nothing like character-development. If anyone dies, you can rest assured the Disney/MCU lot will find an arbitrary excuse to bring them back. There's just zero plot, zero story, zero character-development, zero reason to care about anything happening onscreen.But hey, there ARE a lot of quips! The overall effect is like watching a thirtysomething adult smash-together their superhero action-figures for two hours, while making R-Rated jokes about it. Funny at times, but entirely forgettable, and I'll be damned if there was anything even WORTH remembering about the story.Ultimately, it's the kind of movie which is fun in the moment, but kinda depressingly hollow upon reflection. I don't recommend it, as there are far better ways to spend two hours at a movie-theater this summer -- but see it if you must. If you're just nuts for this kinda stuff, you'll get a lot more out of it than I did.EDIT: I should have found room in my review to observe that at least half of this film is an ad for the Honda Odyssey minivan. Because why not? It's that kind of movie.

I absolutely loved this movie. Ryan Reynolds is a comic genius. I think he's one of the funniest actors of all time. His timing is on remarkable. The whole cast was great. Hugh Jackman was a great sidekick. He was more serious but his acting was very good. I would love to see them together again. Oh and by the way, Hugh's body...wowsa! It's been awhile since I've gone to see a movie twice but I'm going again but I know I missed some things because Ryan is so quick. Also the cameos. The music too. Flashback to the 80's and 90's. Great fight scenes. Best I've seen in awhile. Don't miss this one on the big screen.

What an absolutely mind-blowing experience! After waiting for what felt like forever, this film did not just meet expectations; it shattered them. It was an exhilarating, wholesome journey full of surprises, emotional moments, and epic scenes that left me in awe. Ryan Reynolds, Hugh Jackman, and Shawn Levy have outdone themselves, pouring their hearts into a movie that resonates on so many levels.From the first moment to the last, this film was a wild ride. The team behind it threw everything they had into making it spectacular, and it shows. This isn't just another addition to the MCU timeline or a continuation of FOX's "X-Men" saga; it's a love letter to all of us who grew up with these characters and have cherished their stories. Now, as adults, we get to relive that magic all over again.With Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman leading the charge, you know you're in for a treat. The laughter was relentless-I laughed so hard, my stomach hurt. The jokes are sharp and relentless; this isn't Deadpool diluted by the MCU, but Deadpool at his absolute finest. The chemistry between Reynolds and Jackman is electric, with their bromance playing out in the most entertaining way possible. The story pulls at your heartstrings, especially if you're familiar with the characters' histories and their complex universes.The cameos! Oh, the cameos! Even knowing some of them beforehand didn't diminish their impact. Each appearance added another layer of excitement and nostalgia. And the supporting cast-wow. While we're undoubtedly there for the leads, the movie wouldn't be the same without the brilliant performances of the rest of the ensemble. Emma Corrin's villain, Cassandra Nova, is a standout addition. She's smart, ruthless, and brings a chilling yet humorous edge to the story.Visually, the movie is a feast for the eyes. The action sequences are some of the most creative and intense I've ever seen. Imagine adamantium swords and claws wreaking havoc in the most spectacular way possible-bloody, chaotic, and utterly mesmerizing. The music complements the visuals perfectly, enhancing every moment and sometimes making you laugh just with the choice of song.The film is an overwhelming cascade of excitement, with every scene packed to the brim with action, humor, and heart. Reynolds and Jackman's dynamic is pure gold, driving the film to incredible heights. The opening sequence alone is worth the price of admission, and there's a particular fight scene towards the end that's simply mind-boggling in its execution and sheer madness."Deadpool & Wolverine" has instantly become one of my top cinematic experiences. The theater was a symphony of laughter, cheers, and tears, uniting the audience in a shared journey of emotions. The movie's rewatchability is off the charts; it's perfectly paced, and you'll definitely want to catch all the details you might have missed on your first viewing. It's destined to be a box office juggernaut, and I can't wait to see it again and again.As for the post-credits scene, I'm practically bursting at the seams not to spoil it. It's epic beyond words, leaving a lasting mark on the MCU and proving that this film is far from just a fun diversion. It's a crucial, game-changing piece of the MCU puzzle, and one of its finest entries to date. The anticipation for what comes next in the MCU and for these beloved characters is through the roof.In summary, this movie is an extraordinary achievement. It's overwhelming in the best possible way, packed with everything fans could want and more. From its relentless humor and breathtaking action to its heartfelt story and unforgettable cameos, it's a rollercoaster of emotions and excitement. Reynolds, Jackman, and Levy have created something truly special, a film that not only lives up to the hype but surpasses it in every way imaginable. This is not just a movie; it's an event, an experience that will leave you eagerly awaiting the next chapter in this incredible saga.

Amazing movie. Reynolds and Jackman come together to create a masterpiece. Cameos were fun, fighting was bloody. Story was good, villain was badass. All the cameos create a nice set up future for a few and I can't wait for it. Marvel is putting themselves in a very good direction with this movie, I really hope they can just keep the pace from this movie and use it to transfer into another. I hope Deadpool is now like ironman and cap used to be, showing up in a lot of movies that weren't even there own solo movie. I hope this isn't wolverines last run either bc he was better than ever. Hugh Jackman is a total legend and proves it even more in this film. Credit scene is amazing!

Every time goes the same. I find myself praying "please, don't suck" before every superheroe movie. This time the feeling I'm left with is mixed. The comedy was on point. I like the deadpool character having emotions and a strong character development. The dynamic with wolverine was excellent. Perfect chemistry. The wolverine mystic was not hurt, I may even dare say it was pumped up. All the perfomances were great. Now to the dirty business. I honestly think all the writing energy was put into developing every cameo in a funny and awesome way (I flavored every cameo like a sweet fart on a cold day). Ever since the previous movie when deadpool time traveled things got messy. The plot is just cheap stuff. Besides barely making sense, it ends up being a "Let's save the world with a happy ending while we beat a petty villian nobody will remember" type of movie. Nevertheless, it got me laughing a lot, which is a big win for any movie lately. Deapool 1 was a 10 in my book, and I wanted that, I'm really sorry this wasn't that. All the great cameos won't make up for a lame plot.

This movie was a true love letter to fans and to Marvel. Storywise, it was pretty basic and mid. Hero tries to save the day. We know how it goes by now. The villain was pretty cool as well but their motivations were just meh. I would've wanted a bit more backstory.Everything else was absolutely amazing. The opening scene was eye catching and it hooked me right into the movie. The sound design was awesome. It's so incredibly satisfying to see action scenes play out on the beat of songs. And there were a lot of great action scenes in this movie, all different, unique and intriguing in their own way.Deadpool is known for his comedic value and this movie doesn't miss. I thought it was pretty funny. I love the 4th wall breaks and references to real life.The movie is filled with surprises, especially for people who've been a Marvel fan for a longer time. Teenager me was shedding tears out of happiness.In general, I loved this movie. I literally dreamed that I was watching it again today. It was lots of fun although the core story could have been a bit stronger.

Deadpool 3 is an absolute riot! It successfully blends the irreverent, fourth-wall-breaking humor of the previous Deadpool films with the larger-than-life spectacle of the Marvel Cinematic Universe.What Works: * Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman: Their on-screen chemistry is electric. Reynolds delivers his signature snarky wit, while Jackman brings a gruff charm to Wolverine that perfectly complements Deadpool's antics.* Action-Packed: The film doesn't skimp on the action. The fight scenes are brutal and entertaining, with Deadpool's signature over-the-top violence.* Humor: The jokes land consistently, with plenty of meta-humor, pop culture references, and unexpected twists.* MCU Integration: Deadpool's entry into the MCU is handled with cleverness and respect for both the character and the franchise.What Could Be Improved: * Plot: While the story is serviceable, it takes a backseat to the characters and the action.* Pacing: The film could have benefited from a tighter edit in some places.Overall, Deadpool 3 is a must-watch for fans of the character and the MCU alike. It's a refreshing departure from the typical superhero fare and a testament to the power of a well-executed R-rated film.

Movie starts with a tired, beaten and defeated (emotionally) Deadpool; nursing a rejection from the Avengers and a broken heart. Abducted by the TVA, he's told his universe (AKA FOX STUDIOS) is dying and needs to be put out of its misery. However, he alone, is chosen to transition to the prime sacred timeline (AKA Marvel.) Deadpool decides instead to recruit other forgotten hero's (of FOX) and save the day.Suffice it to say, my expectations going in were low... I was prepared for a paper thin, nonsensical plot designed only as a vehicle for pandering cameos and non stop witty repartee between dead pool and Wolverine. Boy was I wrong. Not only is the plot logical, and compelling / but so is the villain (and her motivation). Rather than rolling my eyes at the cameos I found myself mentally demanding more! More!You never found out (in the movie) who plays female deadpool - which was a bit of a lost opportunity - but the emotional scenes were well done and the endingi? Literal chills.Doubt this will "save" marvel but it's by far the best movie to come out of that studio in 4 years and will make billions.

Here it is, the third installment. Deadpool & Wolverine. Alright, so it rambles and has some major OCD issues. And the plot-line sort of just stumbles into existence but who cares. Its easy to see, just within the first 5 minutes (and from the trailers too, obviously) that this was made for one thing; fan service. And man does Ryan Reynolds bring his A-game. In the league of actors that have graced the screen with comedic brilliance, and we know there have been a-plenty, Reynolds will go down in history as one of the best. The level of his smart-a** is a cut above the rest. Jackman's Wolverine is straight-man to the N-th degree to Reynold's Deadpool and it is easy to see why this was something that both wanted to do for over a decade. Not to even mention the CAMEOS!!! Irreverent and all over the place, Deadpool & Wolverine is an electric, crazy ride that kneels to the fans and asks for forgiveness for the past five or six years of weak creativity, disrespect of the source material ( aka comic book cannon!!) and poor treatment of the fandom by Marvel/Disney. Thanks for the laughs Ryan, Hugh and the rest of the cast, this was the best fun at the movies I've had since Tropic Thunder. About time Hollywood.

Humor and Dubbing: "Deadpool" is known for its sharp, irreverent humor. Ryan Reynolds' performance, coupled with the Hindi dubbing, enhances its comedic appeal, making the jokes more accessible and relatable to a wider audience.Cameos and Characters: Cameos from lesser-known X-Men characters in "Deadpool" and key figures in the Wolverine films, such as Professor X in "Logan," enrich the narratives. These appearances link the movies to the larger X-Men universe and provide depth without overshadowing the main characters.Action and Choreography: The opening fight scene in "Deadpool" is a masterclass in blending brutality with humor, setting a high standard for action sequences. Meanwhile, the Wolverine films, especially "Logan," deliver intense, visceral combat that reflects the character's ferocity and struggle.Emotional Depth: Both films offer more than just action and humor. "Deadpool" explores themes of love and revenge, while "Logan" delves into mortality and redemption, providing emotional depth that resonates with audiences.

I've seen every Marvel movie, including the crappy "The Marvels" and "Black Panther 2".I think this Deadpool-Wolverine is among the best Marvel movies. Better than Deadpool 1 and Deadpool 2, all the Avengers, Captain America, Iron Man, and Thor movies.Certainly the most witty Marvel movie. Cool, funny, serious, everything rolled into one movie.Still not going to win Best Picture, but a movie I would watch again every few years.It's got all the makings of a great movie. Great writing, which salient. Smart. Good story. Great character development for Deadpool and Wolverine. Great directing and acting.It's a winner.

If there was ever a duo more chaotic, more thrilling, and more unpredictable than Deadpool and Wolverine, I haven't seen it. "Deadpool & Wolverine" brings together two of Marvel's most beloved anti-heroes in a film that's as much a rollercoaster ride of action as it is a laugh-out-loud comedy.Plot and Storyline: The plot might not be the most intricate or profound, but it doesn't need to be. The story follows Deadpool and Wolverine as they reluctantly team up to take down a new, formidable threat. The film cleverly balances intense action sequences with moments of genuine emotion, all while maintaining the irreverent tone that Deadpool is known for. The storyline is straightforward but filled with enough twists and turns to keep viewers engaged from start to finish.Characters and Performances: Ryan Reynolds as Deadpool is, as always, a perfect blend of sarcastic wit and chaotic energy. His performance is spot-on, bringing the same level of humor and charisma that fans have come to expect. Hugh Jackman's Wolverine is the ideal foil to Deadpool's antics-gruff, serious, and no-nonsense. The chemistry between Reynolds and Jackman is undeniable, and their banter provides some of the film's best moments. The supporting cast also delivers strong performances, though they are often overshadowed by the dynamic leads.Action and Special Effects: The action scenes are some of the film's highlights, with well-choreographed fights and impressive special effects. Whether it's Wolverine's brutal claw attacks or Deadpool's over-the-top acrobatics, each sequence is crafted with precision and creativity. The film doesn't shy away from violence, but it's always tempered with humor, making even the goriest scenes oddly entertaining.Humor and Dialogue: Deadpool's trademark humor is ever-present, filled with meta-jokes, fourth-wall breaks, and pop culture references. The dialogue is sharp, witty, and often laugh-out-loud funny. While some of the jokes might go over the heads of casual viewers, fans of the characters and the Marvel universe will appreciate the clever writing.Overall: "Deadpool & Wolverine" is a fun, fast-paced film that delivers exactly what it promises: high-octane action, plenty of laughs, and a healthy dose of fan service. It might not be the most groundbreaking superhero movie out there, but it's one that fans will thoroughly enjoy. If you're looking for a movie that doesn't take itself too seriously and offers plenty of entertainment, "Deadpool & Wolverine" is a must-watch.

Wow, how to even describe this movie?Deadpool was ceasessly introduced into the MCU. Sure, you might want to get accquited with a few MCU films first to understand what's going on, but the movie does a good enough job explaining the stakes.What you really should do homework for is the sheer amount of cameos from Fox's library of Marvel movies, from Fantastic Four to Elektra. This movie is an unbashed celebration of the history of these movies as well as the 2000's cultural milestones.And, of course, you get your sassy pansexual fourth wall demolisher and your heroic muscle man.I cannot recommend this movie enough.

Sporting more cameos than a bad mobile game advert (although Pedro Pascal doesn't show up here), 'Deadpool And Wolverine (2024)' is one of the most meta movies I can think of. Frankly, it's meta to the point that it doesn't actually exist... or, at least, it feels that way. It's the equivalent of the TVA-created limbo so much of its plot takes place in: a barren, out-of-time wasteland with no discernible features other than the remnants of long-forgotten Marvel movies/ universes. It exploits its audience's nostalgia, ostensibly acting as an ode to the Fox-era of Marvel but actually just parading around the carcasses of films that only the most loyal fans remember at all, let alone fondly. You don't even have to be all that cynical to see that its various cameos and callbacks are incredibly hollow, bereft of any real narrative significance. These things are designed to be recognised, rather than admired. The joy they evoke - which I'm not immune to, by the way - fades incredibly quickly because of this, and they lose even more power when they're inevitably robbed of the element of surprise (either by the inherently one-time nature of that element or, far more bafflingly, by Marvel's marketing department themselves).By assembling itself out of only the most memorable parts of previous movies' corpses, the picture lacks any real identity of its own. Its meta elements aren't used to comment on... well, anything really. It doesn't acknowledge it's a movie so it can say anything about filmmaking, nor about the relationship between audiences and the media they consume; it doesn't point out its place in Marvel's incredibly complex multiverse to do anything other than poke fun at the very things it indulges in, while also feeling just a smidge smug. Despite its vaguely satirical elements, it's all seems a little bit self-satisfied, and it panders to its audience in a way that's sort of off-putting. It takes things fans have loved about even Marvel's least successful efforts, and the running jokes they've created about said efforts, and transforms them into a shamelessly corporate currency that can be exchanged for cold hard cash. That this film has made so much money only further suggests that audiences don't care about story if they're bombarded by things they've seen before, which will in turn cause Disney to learn the wrong lessons and cram more cameos into their now-middling franchise instead of actually putting genuine effort into the stories of its individual entries.Of course, the less pessimistic version of all this is that Marvel is simply giving its fans what they want. Whether or not it's blatantly motivated by money instead of artistic merit, it's making people happy and that's all that matters. When it comes down to it, there's a lot of truth to that. However, you can please people while still telling a compelling story. I don't think we should accept a sub-par product simply because it scratches the same itch as well-written fan-fiction. To be fair, though, the picture isn't bad. Its flaws are far more relevant in retrospect, even though there's always something that stops you from becoming fully immersed in the experience. In the moment, the flick is fairy fun. It's oddly paced, sure, but it has plenty of diverting set-pieces and unashamedly colourful sets and costumes. The action is often exciting, although it doesn't make as much use of the eponymous characters' healing abilities as I'd like. It's generally fast-paced and filled with nice little moments that showcase the skills of the characters involved. Some of the larger battle scenes are a bit hard to follow because they're really busy and quite unfocused, but even these are peppered with those aforementioned satisfying character moments. The best fight, and highlight of the overall affair, is one set in a car that sees Deadpool and Wolverine tear each other up in a confined space (the utilisation of the environment in this scene is a deciding factor in its superiority over the bouts set on an entirely flat plane). The affair isn't as funny as either of its predecessors, but there are several amusing moments and a generally light tone that keeps you in fairly good spirits throughout. Annoyingly, a lot of the jokes amount to Deadpool simply saying something that the audience understands but nobody else in the scene does, resulting moments in which the characters stand around and wait for him to finish his schtick (or, at most, tell him to shut up). Furthermore, a lot of the humour - including plenty of the visual gags - relies on information only the most die hard fans will possess. Even the best cameos (which, for me, were the ones I didn't know were coming) sort of just happen and then disappear, fairly regularly being dismissed as a form of shock comedy.Although I spoke earlier about how the film has nothing going on beneath its surface, it does try to evoke some pathos from the (very basic) arcs of its two titular characters. The problem is that we've already seen both of them go through almost the exact same emotional journey, and one of those was in 'Logan (2017)' which is so much better than this on every conceivable level that it's almost embarrassing. The most saccharine moments try to cash in on an emotional connection that the picture simply hasn't taken the time to establish, so they end up feeling really false. There's very little emotionality here, despite some commendable work from the lead actors, and the earnestness of the affair is actually somewhat jarring; it doesn't gel with the typically sardonic tone you expect from Deadpool. Still, it's worth hammering home just how good Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman are here. This is definitely Reynolds' best character, and it's always a treat to see Jackman (doubly so when he's donning his iconic claws). They do exactly what they need to, making a fairly convincing double act in the process. I just wish they actually got something to sink their teeth into, that their much-awaited team-up wasn't also a multiverse movie concerned more with mining IP than building a narrative of its own. Without them, though, there's no way this would even get made, let alone be as good as it is. The supporting players all do well with what they're given, it's just that they aren't given all that much.Ultimately, the movie is generally fairly fun but undeniably rather empty. It mostly makes good use of its R rating (it's a visceral treat to see its characters tear their enemies - and each other - apart and cuss them out while they do it), even if it doesn't exactly tell a mature tale. There's a sense that it isn't really anything, other than a collection of moments designed to make you point at the screen and say "I remember that!", but it also works well enough as light entertainment that I won't begrudge anyone who says they truly enjoy it. Heck, I even enjoy it (even if it doesn't seem like it). I just don't know how much. It's tempting to say that it's all set up for something later down the line, but it isn't even that really. It's just this bizarre artefact that encapsulates where the movie industry is at the moment, an uncertain time where studio heads seem to be as chronically online as their franchises' most passionate fans and continue to pander in an effort to make more money. As soulless as it may be (despite the genuine care put into it by many of its creators), it is entertaining fluff with some energetic action and a couple of solid (if rather one-note) lead performances. It's good, but it's by no means great. I wish it did more with its premise.

This movie is just wall to wall fun. It has all the hallmarks of a movie made by people who enjoy their craft and want you to enjoy their work.I genuinely get the sense that everyone involved had a blast making this movie and I loved it.Cameos galore, Easter eggs, dripping with meta commentary and fourth wall shattering.Beyond all that, it serves as a pretty decent superhero movie and it must be said that this might just be peak wolverine.Logan was awesome but here I think we got our best wolverine ever.There's some nicely shot action, lots of gore, plenty of ridiculous kills and the movie made me laugh out loud more than many movies have done.I absolutely loved seeing Tyler mane's sabertooth, Wesley snipes playing blade again and a whole litany of original cast members from previous marvel work.It's an absolute riot.

Go and watch the film! Forget about these over educated critics, who couldn't make or write a decent Film. They are waiting for next french film about some obscure matter, pointing out some philosophical moments and Dialogue the rest of us dummies missed. Its comic book movie!! Enjoy it for what it is. The Cameos are pretty awesome and the storyline is ok. The film doesn't take the MCU closer to secret wars or any other upcoming projects, However it delivers as a good addition to the Deadpool story. For any Comic book Fan, take it as a limited arc graphic novel before the main event. Funny, Bloody and Entertaining!

Hmmm. Bit torn on what I thought of this or what rating I should give it.If I am reviewing this with a traditional movie structure in mind, it is a complete fail. It has no real story, no real structure, scenes move from one scene to the next without much continuity or reason and uses these things knowingly.However, this is deadpool and I decided my feelings on the movie should be with that in mind.It is funny. At times really funny. It looks amazing. I'm not a fan of fight scenes usually but these are fantastically choreographed and are really entertaining. Bringing wolverine in, makes no sense and yet paradoxically makes loads of sense, it completely makes the movie and Jackman plays it perfectly.If you go into this wanting to critique it as a movie as the observer did, it's rubbish. If you accept it's a deadpool movie, yeah it's decent, not as good as the first one by a long shot and most probably not even the second but it is a lot of fun and it's entertaining, though I'm not sure it's going to warrant a second viewing.

The Wolverine popcorn bucket was actually better than the movie..So, where do I start? Ah, yes, with the barrage of jokes that are aging faster than Wolverine's hairline. The MCU - sometimes they hit it out of the park, and sometimes, well, they serve up a big ol' dud. Their version of Deadpool? Yeah, that didn't tickle my funny bone. It felt like an endless parade of flashy explosions and cameos, with actual storytelling taking a backseat. Coherent narrative? What's that? But hey, I'm clearly the odd one out here. It made $200 million in just two days and got an A on Cinemascore. Guess I'll just sit here in my minority corner with my bottle of Jack Daniel's.

Deadpool and Wolverine offers a most-refreshing tone to the Marvel Cinematic Universe, crippled after offering a series of quality-questionable, at best, projects that represent a meager attempt at living up to the Avengers Endgame legacy. Nevertheless, this last delivery from the Disney-owned studio is well-aware of all the above, and it does a notable job at dealing with the rampant crisis Marvel faces. While it is true Deadpool and Wolverine manifests a colossal fan-service, worrisome in any other context, it is precisely what the average audience needed the most; a movie that encompasses thrilling action sequences salted with alright humour and a rewarding, yet basic, plot, served as an R-Rated dish reinforced with hefty Disney budget. Undeniably, Deadpool and Wolverine is not a piece of high-end cinema, but only a sublime Super Hero film that ultimately reminds its audience of days gone when the same genre could draw millions into theaters.

I'll be very honest with the review, I absolutely enjoyed this movie in the theatre, the comedy, the action, the dialogues, the story, the putting together of all characters was 100% perfect.Earlier i didn't like Deadpool 2 very much so initially i had the same impression for this movie before it was about to start but once it started my thoughts changed and I loved Deadpool and Wolverine together.I think Deadpool will never be complete without Ryan.You have pulled out a stunner.So yeah 10/10 from my side.The music and the jokes oh my god top notch.P. S this is the best movie I've watched in 2024 till date (11th Aug 2024)

Deadpool & Wolverine brings back two of the most popular Marvel characters in the titular roles. Ryan Reynolds returns as Deadpool having last appeared in Deadpool 2 (2018) and Hugh Jackman returns as Wolverine having bid farewell to his iconic character in Logan (2017). It was fantastic to see both actors return again. The movie was well worth the hype and it was a great experience from start to finish with plenty of non stop humour and action. A lot of question marks and concerns were going to be raised about the third Deadpool movie after Disney's takeover of 20th Century Fox but there's nothing to worry about at all. There's a lot of crude jokes and blood and gore which Deadpool is well known for.Deadpool (Ryan Reynolds) is enjoying making the best of a normal life until he finds himself being thrust back into the action by Mr Paradox (Matthew Macfayden) after being told his current universe is under threat of being wiped out from existence. After reluctantly agreeing to stop the threat, Deadpool also finds himself reluctantly enlisting the help of Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) from another universe who is even more reluctant to join forces with the motormouthed hero. Both Deadpool and Wolverine find them forming an antagonistic alliance to face off against Cassandra Nova (Emma Corrin) who is the evil twin of the beloved Charles Xavier aka Professor X.There is going to be no spoilers here, otherwise it will spoil things. Deadpool & Wolverine was great from start to finish. So many laughs, non stop action, lots of jokes and Easter eggs, and Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman made a great on screen duo. It was great to see them back. Deadpool & Wolverine is another great hit in the Marvel series. All fans of Marvel, Deadpool and Wolverine will really enjoy themselves. Have a great time watching the movie, and this is another hit for 2024.8/10.

Genuinely a rollercoaster of fun and action from Ryan Reynolds & Hugh Jackman! They delivered and more. The music, the action, the storyline all blended together perfectly for this epic movie.Not to spoil it for anyone there are a lot of amazing surprises and characters, and they try to do justice for everyone and all of Marvel, in the funniest way possible and a lot of heart.After 35 years of being a fan of the superhero genre and supporting the comic book movie genre whole heatedly, this came through with flying colors. A geeks dream come true.Really what Marvel should have been doing after Endgame.Watch it and you won't regret it.

Greetings from Lithuania."Deadpool & Wolverine" (2024) felt like that third part in the series when creators run out of ideas, so they just threw everything in movie to make it work. It does work enough so I could mildly recommend it but for those looking for a good movie with Wolverine in it - just rewatch Logan instead because this film is pure fan fiction.The many cameos were actually good and I really enjoyed them all. There are plenty jokes that lands, yet plenty that felt flat. Acting was... well I mean what acting? Not much required here. And it's the plot and script that felt draggy and uninspired in this film - it's kinda been there done that and it drags.Overall - plenty of good cameos, some good laughs and action scenes that do work and it's a nice film to recommend it.

Yesterday I went to the theaters to see Deadpool & Wolverine starring Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman and directed by Shawn Levy. In this third installment of the Deadpool series we see Wade (Reynolds) being gifted the opportunity to realize his dreams of becoming one of the Avengers but at the expense of seeing his world destroyed. In true Deadpool fashion, he decides instead to enlist Wolverine to help him save his world and everyone in it. I thoroughly enjoyed the first 2 films and was very excited to see this so I purposely avoided trailers and plot details as best I could.This movie is non-stop fun from the very beginning. It features numerous cameos and countless easter eggs referencing basically every Marvel movie ever made. The chemistry between Jackman and Reynolds is brilliant, and the fight scenes are incredible. The story lacks a little at times but overall, they do a good job of bringing the point home. This movie is pure entertainment and can be best described as the best kind of nerd porn. I absolutely loved it and recommend seeing it while it is still in theaters.

I had higher expectations. It wasn't bad by any stretch but the first two were way better. Basically Disney took the lazy way out. They filled the movie full of cameos and easter eggs. They are trying to buy the fan base back. The problem is none of it means anything.All in all it was fun. I felt like the comedic moments in the movie fell a little flat. The villan was kind of lame. I wish the TVA would just go away. I will say this is the best Marvel movie in a long time. I'm not sure this is going to save the marvel universe but it is a step in the right direction.There were some interesting implications from everything that took place.

If you are a deadpool fan first of all dont wait for ott this movie is made for theatre experience . Ryan reynolds , hugh jackman have done a great job in movie and this movie is first R rated movie of MCU universe yes deadpool has announced in the movie that he is now officially part of MCU and he has totally nailed the character of deadpool his roasting for marvel , fox star studios & hyundai car was awesome and the fourth wall he has broken again in this movie was great the action was also good and the cameo was unexpected but have a value in the movie . In the end i would like to request you dont pirate this as ryan has told that producer ke L lag jainge

TLDR: It's pretty good. Not mind altering or moving but fun escapism.The Good: Hugh Jackman as Wolverine and all the surprises.The Bad: Deadpool gets to be a bit much but, like that's his thing so you get what you order by buying the ticket.I will watch all the Marvel movies. They have my number and I know it. I like to unplug from the news and embrace the escapism. We all need escapism from time to time.The title of this movie says it all. If you have seen the Deadpool movies or the X-Men series and Wolverine spinoff this one is for you. I would guess you don't need to have seen all the movies in all the series to have fun with this one but I'm so deep in the cult it's tough to say.The writing was a little weak and formulaic but it was a comic book action movie that makes fun of its self while trying to say something about needing purpose and recognizing what drives purpose.Hugh Jackman as Wolverine was so fun to see again. He nails the role so well and they wrote his character best.If somehow you missed the spoilers, the twists and turns and cameos are fun.Deadpool's madness is more noticeable as he enters the MCU. It was fun to see the merc with the mouth go on another adventure. He really pushes buttons in this one but that's who the character is.I would have liked to have seen a little more screen time for some of the auxiliary characters in this movie.

This review was made a few days after watching the movie and in all honesty, it was amazing which is expected from a "Deadpool" movie after the first two.I was excited as to how they will introduce the story of brining back wolverine and it was done nicely enough to not think too much about it, finally seeing deadpool and wolverine on the big screen together is crazy, the chemistry between ryan reynolds and hugh jackman was perfect, as well as finally and officially making deadpool join the MCU which could save it from the continuous downfall it is having for the past few years with some exceptions.This movie is definitely a comedy but some drama scenes including logan, hugh jackman did a great job although some characters were under utilized which would've increased the emotions involved within those scenes.The villain was below average and I would've liked more taking into consideration what we know of the villain.Everytime we watch a deadpool movie, we get barraged with easter eggs, references and a lot of breaking the 4th wall jokes which are the best part of the movie as a whole, if you're into the marvel universe and not just that but also following the social issues involving entertainment industries and much more, you'll find the movie more enjoyable and the jokes way funnier, the more you know the more you'll have fun is what i'll name this experience.Amazing and unexpected guest cameos as well.It is a definitely a must watch.

You want action? You want sentiment? You want Comedy? You want Cameo's? Look no further. At a low point for Marvel this would be a new high point. It does not disappoint. Only haters will give this less than a 9. We've all been waiting for this way too long. Not only does this movie provide well, but it set up the rest of Marvel to move Forward again. Between the Avengers and X-men world to the Deadpool franchise being stronger than ever, this is a must see. I thought that the abundance of trailers was going to spoil the movie but you will see that there is just too much great content. If there's a movie to see, this is it.

Deadpool arrives with a blast of comedy, action, drama and pure heart that lives up to the hype. It's also a surprisingly nostalgic movie, a love letter and fond farewell to all those Marvel linked movies that preceded the MCU. A reminder that past movies did have the magic to captivate us long before RDJ was ever cast as Iron Man.We can't predict what the MCU will bring, or if it will survive the depths it has sank into post-Endgame, but Deadpool & Wolverine are a throwback to subtle CGI, fantastically choreographed fight scenes/stuntwork, and epic storytelling.You will watch it dozens of times.

I have seen Deadpool and Wolverine a total of three times in the past week. Somehow I still want to watch it over and over. I find something new to love every time I watch it again. The humor is some of the best movie humor I have seen in a very long time. The jokes are actually laughable and some of them are quite unbelievable and my jaw was on the floor. The music was practically perfect in every way. It made some of the scenes so unforgettable that I can perfectly in-vision them in my head when I hear the songs. Deadpool and Wolverine was so worth the wait and I cannot wait to see where the story goes next!

I know this probably isn't a popular opinion but i was left rather disappointed after seeing this.For starters, i like Ryan Reynolds as an actor but I'm pretty tired of his scripts with some sort of gag or joke every few lines. I get that it's inkeeping with the character but it would help if the majority of those were funny but they rarely are & it just feels so forced. Again, I'm not against comedic moments or jokes & it did make me laugh a few times, it's just that i laughed far, far less than it really wanted or expected me to.To be honest, the best moments of the film were either it's few serious moments courtesy of Hugh & his great acting or the large scale fight scenes that were done well. I was also pleasantly surprised with Emma Corrin.The film is very much Deadpool & Wolverine in that it mostly forgets about all the other characters that played a big part in the previous films, leaving it to feel pretty disjointed from them.Overall, the film felt mostly forgettable & essentially, it was just another throwaway story set in the overused & underutilised multiverse.

I think the film is good and very unique, especially for the actor Deadpool who makes me feel a very pleasant vibe. The chemistry between Deadpool and Wolfrine is also quite good, where Deadpool is very talkative and Wolfrine is very angry.As a Marvel fan, I quite enjoyed this film, starting from the soundtrack which was very cool and suited Deadpool. Really a very entertaining fan service film. However, my advice for those of you who are not Marvel fans is to watch the film series before Deadpool, the Logan film, and the Loki series. As well as understanding Fox's dispute with Disney because you will understand 70% of the jokes in this film if you have done what I mentioned.Because if you don't, you definitely won't understand the jokes and the storyline will make you confused. However, in my opinion, the soundtrack and action photography are the best and can be enjoyed by everyoneIt's really a very fun, unique and fresh film with wild ideas.

In all honesty I came into this movie expecting huge things. I'm a major fan of the other 2 deadpools with a pretty much perfect blend of comedy story and action. However in this one I didn't feel that blend as much. LOTS of the jokes were funny don't get me wrong but it almost felt they were doing too much sometimes or just unnecessarily, almost like thor love and thunder. The action I'll be honest I liked a lot,all the fight sequences were epic and were one of the highlights of the film. But my biggest disappointment was the story. Don't get me wrong in no way am I saying the story was bad but just kinda messy. Ik it's supposed to be a multiverse movie and everything but I felt like it became too diatached from what mad the other deadpools great. But in no way am I saying this movie is rubbish. It was both funny and enjoyable and I loved all the cameos and wolverine in this. I just wish they'd had kept some more themes of the other deadpools. In no work is this movie a six but nor a seven. It's good but nothing really more.

It felt like watching an episode of Friends, funny at times and forgotten a second after it ended. I was very disappointed, the group that made the film aimed as low as possible, we will make you laugh with shallow jokes and not invest a second in emotion, plot depth, character development, we will also bring some characters from decades ago that will make you feel nostalgic, in short tricks of laziness and disdain for the audience. It's really sad to me that the audience buys this deception. Just like it was with Spider-Man - there is no way home, it worked for them, it worked for them even now. For me it was the reminder that the fun of the early years of MCU will unfortunately not return.

Directed & Co-Written by Shawn Levy, the movie follows Wade Wilson (Ryan Reynolds) seeks to lead a quiet life away from his past as Deadpool. However, everything takes an unexpected turn when the TVA takes him to help them save the timeline. He then recruits the Wolverine (Hugh Jackman), the only person he hopes that could help.It seems evident that the introduction of X-Men/Mutants into the MCU was planned in the context of the multiverse concept for the next saga. Even though I like the idea, I can't help but think that Marvel's decision to bring back a character with a definitive ending might be seen as a desperate move. However, given that the multiverse and variants will be central themes for phase four to six, I have no doubt that they will manage to make it work somehow. Considering the mixed reception of the current and last phases, I was afraid they would botch this up again. Thankfully, I was wrong.Deadpool & Wolverine is far from perfect, but it does provide a theater experience that people have missed since Spider-Man: No Way Home. However, if you start to think deeply about where the movie fit in the Fox timeline after the events in Days of Future Past and some pretty significant plot holes (I hope you don't), the movie starts to fall apart. I don't think those would be a big problem though. I see it as merely a continuation problem in the script because this movie is supposed to be a standalone one. Besides, it's actually a great redemption arc story for the characters. Deadpool finally gets to be the hero he always wanted to be, while Wolverine, who has let his entire kind down, has the opportunity to save countless others.After watching all the previous X-Men movies, it's finally safe to say that Hugh Jackman delivered the best performance as the beloved character he portrayed for 24 years. That one scene really stood out, and it was great to finally see him in the iconic suit. Ryan Reynolds did a great job as the Merc with a Mouth, but I feel like he wasn't quite at the same level as in Deadpool 2.All in all, Deadpool & Wolverine is like a prayer that people have been praying for years, and when it's finally here, it just feels like home.

I know, i know...I'm gonna see all the hate for rating this an 8, but hey, it ain't Oppenheimer after all.Love Jackman, and often like Reynolds. Enjoyed the first Deadpool, did not enjoy the second.This film succeeds because instead of parading around new, obscure superheroes, and trying desperately to advance a feminist orientation, it plays what started the whole metaverse to begin with: classic superhero dudes creating mayhem and wisecracking through and through.I'm over the Ryan Reynolds shtick for the most part. It sometimes lands, but often blurs the other tones necessary to sustain a two hour movie.Lots of cameos, lots of callbacks.So, highly recommend, unless your prior favorite movie was Mary Poppins or Bring It On.

Good movie .Here's a 600-word movie review that covers Deadpool (2016) and Logan (2017), focusing on their impact on the superhero genre and the performances of Ryan Reynolds as Deadpool and Hugh Jackman as Wolverine.Movie Review: Deadpool (2016) and Logan (2017)The superhero genre has seen its fair share of evolution over the years, with movies ranging from light-hearted escapades to darker, more introspective tales. Deadpool (2016) and Logan (2017) stand out as two films that pushed the boundaries of what superhero movies could be, each in its own unique way. While Deadpool brought a fresh and irreverent take to the genre, Logan delivered a gritty, emotional farewell to one of its most iconic characters.Deadpool: A Game-Changer in Superhero ComedyDirected by Tim Miller and starring Ryan Reynolds as the titular character, Deadpool was a breath of fresh air in a genre that was beginning to feel formulaic. The film's success was largely due to its willingness to break the fourth wall, its R-rated humor, and its self-awareness. Ryan Reynolds, who had been attached to the character of Deadpool for years, finally got the chance to do justice to the "Merc with a Mouth," and he delivered in spades.Reynolds' performance is the heart and soul of Deadpool. He effortlessly blends sarcasm, wit, and vulnerability, making Deadpool one of the most memorable characters in the superhero pantheon. The film's plot is relatively straightforward, focusing on Wade Wilson's quest for revenge after being subjected to a rogue experiment that leaves him with accelerated healing powers but a disfigured appearance. What sets Deadpool apart, however, is its tone. The film revels in its irreverence, poking fun at superhero tropes, the X-Men franchise, and even Reynolds' own career missteps.The film's action sequences are as kinetic as they are humorous, with Deadpool's acrobatics and swordplay providing a visual treat. But it's the script, co-written by Rhett Reese and Paul Wernick, that truly shines. The dialogue is sharp, filled with quips and pop culture references that land more often than not. Deadpool doesn't take itself too seriously, and that's precisely what makes it so enjoyable. It's a film that embraces the absurdity of its premise and runs with it, resulting in a wildly entertaining ride that redefined what a superhero movie could be.Logan: A Heart-Wrenching FarewellIn stark contrast to Deadpool's irreverence, Logan (2017) is a somber, emotionally charged film that serves as a fitting conclusion to Hugh Jackman's 17-year tenure as Wolverine. Directed by James Mangold, Logan is set in a dystopian future where mutants are nearly extinct, and an aging Logan is struggling with the weight of his past. The film's tone is grim, reflective, and deeply human, offering a raw and unflinching look at the toll that years of violence have taken on the once-indestructible Wolverine.Hugh Jackman delivers a career-defining performance as Logan, portraying the character with a depth and vulnerability that had only been hinted at in previous films. His portrayal of a weary, broken man who is forced to confront his own mortality is both powerful and heartbreaking. Patrick Stewart is equally compelling as Charles Xavier, whose once-great mind is deteriorating due to a neurodegenerative disease. The relationship between Logan and Xavier forms the emotional core of the film, and their scenes together are some of the most poignant in the superhero genre.Logan eschews the typical superhero formula in favor of a more grounded, character-driven narrative. The film's violence is brutal and unrelenting, serving as a stark reminder of the consequences of a life spent fighting. But amidst the bloodshed, Logan is ultimately a story about redemption and the search for peace. The introduction of Laura, a young mutant with powers similar to Logan's, adds another layer to the film's exploration of legacy and the passing of the torch.

It's a good movie. But not one of those I'll be able to watch 5 times a year like the others.Fantastic ending to deadpool, even tho I hope there will be more. A slight different style than the first two - tho I can't really put my finger on what they had that this one was missing.The fight scenes were amazing as always. The references to other movies, real life individuals + the cameos gave the movie an extra spark! It broke the forth wall a bit too much, but at the same time; it's deadpool, so it was expected.The sensitivity and emotions in this movie gave another feel to both deadpool and wolverine that I have missed in earlier movies.Overall it's a great movie, something nice to watch on a slow and tired Sunday.

This movie was SO good from start to finish. By the time the opening credits finished rolling I was already convinced this would be one of the best Marvel movies in a while.Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman are a fantastic pair, and it's easy to tell they're having a great time in every scene, carrying the audience with them all along.All the jokes landed not just for me, but for everyone in theatre, and they were simply geniusly written.The cameos were loads of fun, as well as all the references to other Marvel movies that came before it.Overall, the movie was a great experience, lots of laughs throughout the whole movie and some truly epic moments!

When the very first scene of the movie has Deadpool digging out Wolverine's decomposing corpse from "Logan" and using it to fight a bunch of NPCs, you know you're in for something irreverent and fun. And fun, of which the movie has plenty. It's true that over the years, people have grown accustomed to Ryan Reynolds' style of humor, which since the popularity of the first "Deadpool" movie, has followed him around into every other movie he makes. But there's always something special when Ryan delivers the same obnoxious 'c*ck-and-b*lls' jokes wearing that loveable red suit.What convinced us all to go to the cinemas and check this movie out after the years of being sick of superhero movies however, is not Deadpool in and of itself, but the addition of Hugh Jackman's Wolverine to the mix. It's a character so beloved and one we can almost never picture anyone else in, and this movie is further proof as to why. It's a pairing that we knew would always work out well, and unsurprisingly it does. It's the banter between Deadpool and Logan that makes this movie as fun and enjoyable as it is, and credit to both actors whose chemistry was the best thing about this movie.All that being said, we're once again back to the inevitable Marvel problem of having a paper thin script which has the now banal world ending stakes it always has. It's something that has been overplayed so much that it even makes a Deadpool movie somewhat tedious. It's a Deadpool movie, so sure you're about to expect some silliness sprinkled around, but where you don't want to see it is in the blueprint of the script. And unfortunately, that's where it is, with the laziness and the lethargy of Marvel's writing department sticking around like a sore thumb.It's a movie full of banter and cameos and while that makes for an amazing theater-going experience, it's not enough to warrant longevity. The cameos are surprising, but only the first time you watch it, and that probably makes this movie the weakest of the three Deadpool movies. All criticism aside though, it's a movie worth checking out for sure while the hype is still on, because it's not going to be as fun once it's out on digital, when everyone knows what surprises to expect.

I'm a huge fan of the Wolverine films and like Hugh Jackman as an actor and person. That's the only reason I decided to watch this, as I've always found Ryan Reynolds a bit meh and was not into the Deadpool films.It's always struck me that Ryan thinks he's 100 times funnier than he actually is and that is super-amplified here. I didn't laugh once at any of his quips. They're non-stop and don't contain an ounce of wit. It just gets really tedious and annoying especially in that sarcastic, smug voice.But at least beneath the stupid jokes in the previous Deadpool films, particularly the first, there is an actual dramatic plot that is interesting to watch. This was a complete mess. The initial idea sounded interesting in the beginning but it failed to deliver on the story it promised.It's a weird mish-mash of other ideas already done over and over. I'd already been bored out of my head with the time variance plot in Loki, which they've used here as a means of getting hold of a multiverse Wolverine. There's a scene with 100 various Deadpools which we've already seen in Spiderman. And as others have said, it draws massively on other films from X-men, Marvel and other franchises to make up it's story because there's nothing to the plot. The dramatic element is drawn from your reaction to relevant moments from those films. There's not one original concept. And the fact that it's drawing on so much ultimately results in it not knowing what it's really trying to do. Thus, what ends up being the focus are the jokes, gore, fight scenes, cameos and special effects.The cameos didn't bring anything to the film. Jennifer Garner, Wesley Snipes and Dafne Keen played their roles well, but it didn't go anywhere or do anything. Weirdly Chris Evans seemed to be playing Cap rather than Johnny Storm?! And why on earth was Channing Tatum, Gambit?! And "Cavillrine" was just stupid.I like gory fight scenes, that didn't bother me, I was bothered by the fact that it's pointless and boring to watch because there isn't anything at stake. Deadpool and Wolverine constantly fighting throughout got incredibly tiring; I expected this film to be about the two of them grudgingly working together towards a mutual cause, whilst annoying the crap out of each other, the only time they actually did team up was at the end.About the only saving grace was the female villain who played Charles Xavier's sister; she was brilliant but it was wasted talent.Although I'd lowered my expectations accordingly with it being a film led by Deadpool, it managed to be worse than that bar. It's just a real damn shame that Hugh Jackman reprised a brilliant, iconic character for this rubbish. He at least, delivered, as you'd expect him to, but it was for nothing.I'm not the type to 1-star something to make up for all the high ratings on a film that is clearly awful, but I was sorely tempted with this. 3 for Hugh and the villain.

Simply awesomeoe movie, A complete package of Action and comedy. Marvel Reloaded."Deadpool & Wolverine," the latest blockbuster superhero film, is an exhilarating, action-packed rollercoaster that masterfully blends humor, high-octane action, and deep character moments. Directed by [Director's Name], this film offers a fresh take on the beloved characters, Deadpool and Wolverine, who have captivated audiences for years.From the opening scene, the film establishes its tone: irreverent, witty, and explosively dynamic. The plot kicks off with Deadpool, portrayed with trademark charisma by Ryan Reynolds, and Wolverine, brought to life once again by Hugh Jackman, finding themselves in an unlikely team-up. The premise revolves around a complex conspiracy involving a shadowy organization that threatens global security, forcing these two unlikely heroes into an uneasy alliance.The chemistry between Reynolds and Jackman is palpable and arguably one of the film's strongest assets. Reynolds' Deadpool is a masterclass in comedic timing and fourth-wall-breaking brilliance. His humor is relentless and often absurd, creating a constant stream of laughs that never feels forced. Meanwhile, Jackman's Wolverine is as brooding and intense as ever, but this film allows him to explore a more vulnerable side. The dynamic between Deadpool's relentless jokiness and Wolverine's gruff seriousness leads to some of the film's most memorable moments, with their banter providing a perfect counterpoint to the high stakes of their mission.The film's screenplay is sharp and engaging, with clever dialogue and a well-paced plot that keeps the audience invested from start to finish. The writers strike a delicate balance between humor and action, ensuring that neither element overshadows the other. The story is driven by strong character motivations, and the interactions between Deadpool and Wolverine offer both comedic relief and emotional depth. This character development adds layers to the typical superhero narrative, making the film not just an action spectacle but a story about two characters finding common ground despite their differences.Visually, "Deadpool & Wolverine" is a feast for the eyes. The action sequences are expertly choreographed and executed with a flair that showcases the unique abilities of both heroes. From Wolverine's berserker rages to Deadpool's acrobatic combat style, the fight scenes are thrilling and inventive. The special effects are top-notch, creating visually stunning set pieces that enhance the story rather than distract from it. The film's color palette and cinematography further contribute to its overall vibrant and energetic aesthetic.The supporting cast also deserves commendation. The film introduces several new characters who add depth to the story, each bringing their own unique flair to the narrative. The antagonists are well-developed, providing a credible threat that challenges both Deadpool and Wolverine. Their motivations are clear and compelling, making the stakes feel real and immediate.Musically, the soundtrack complements the film's tone perfectly. The score is dynamic and exciting, enhancing the emotional and action-packed moments. The use of popular music tracks is both nostalgic and fitting, adding an extra layer of engagement for viewers."Deadpool & Wolverine" is not just a superhero film; it's a celebration of the genre's potential to entertain and provoke thought. It excels in blending humor with heart, action with introspection, and spectacle with substance. The film reaffirms Deadpool's place as a comedic anti-hero and Wolverine's status as a complex, brooding warrior. Together, they make for a formidable and entertaining duo.In conclusion, "Deadpool & Wolverine" is a triumph of superhero cinema, offering a perfect mix of humor, action, and character-driven storytelling. It's a must-see for fans of the genre and newcomers alike, promising an unforgettable experience that showcases the best of both characters. The film not only lives up to its hype but exceeds it, making it a standout entry in the superhero genre.

Wow, what an absolute treat this was!"Deadpool & Wolverine" is a rollercoaster ride that will leave you breathless and grinning like an idiot. It's pure nostalgia from start to finish, with cameos popping up left and right like a Marvel fan's wildest dream. Seriously, this is the bloodiest, funniest Marvel film yet, and I need more of whatever this madness is ASAP. Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman are a match made in sarcastic, mutant heaven, and their on-screen bromance is everything.I left the cinema buzzing, my cheeks sore from laughing so much. This movie nails the perfect blend of humor, action, and a few surprisingly touching moments that sneak up on you. Whether you're a casual viewer or a die-hard Marvel nerd, you're going to be over the moon with this one. Packed with inside jokes and Easter eggs galore, "Deadpool & Wolverine" is the ultimate fan service. If you're looking for a film that delivers nonstop fun and mayhem, this is it.I WANT MORE OF WHERE THIS CAME FROM, please and thanks!

Deadpool & Wolverine releases today, and you cannot miss this one for anything! These guys cooked. This film brings together two of Marvel's most beloved anti-heroes, offering fans a wild ride filled with irreverent humor and gritty action.Ryan Reynolds delivering a performance that is both hilariously over-the-top and deeply nuanced. Hugh making an unexpected return and he isnt the only character who is making a comeback heret. There are so many cameos from Xmen, MCU and fox world, its a pure bliss to see them all together. Wolverine & Deadpool's chemistry is unexpectedly entertaining. The screenplay cleverly balances their contrasting personalities.One of the tilms standout aspects is its ability to balance humor with heartfelt moments. Deadpool's one liners and commentary provide constant laughs, and nakes the movie a fun ride. Story is somewhat okayish & repetetive, but screenplay covers that flaw. Undoubtedly this is Shawn's magnum opus. He has crafted this film beautifully. Credit video will probably get you emotional. Movie was insane from the very second it started and till the very end.

If ever there was a critic proof movie, then "Deadpool and Wolverine" surely is it. A fourth wall breaking, in-joking, buddy comedy, which bizarrely serves as a romantic finale to both the good and the terrible of defunct Fox/Marvel world.The Time Variance Authority remove Wade Wilson (Ryan Reynolds) from his timeline and offer him a place on Earth-616, as Wilson's timeline has been slowly dying since the death of its "anchor being" Logan (Hugh Jackman). Using his Deadpool superhero persona, Wilson decides to save his timeline by recruiting another Logan to take his place, eventually securing a drunken failed version of him. Mr Paradox (Matthew MacFadyen) a TVA middle manager, is tired of slowly watching timelines die though and instead plans to use a device to speed up the process.It unquestionably is a case of style over substance, a rapid scattershot cavalcade of sex jokes, swearwords, references, and cameos. Occasionally, I do think that Reynolds takes the character into the realm of annoying, but I would say the majority of the time he's just about threading the needle. Jackman gets to play the straight man (in every sense) alongside the motormouth Wilson. Their fight scenes are fun, and for the most part look reasonably good, save for some dodgy CGI in the multi-Deadpool battle.Talking about the cameos is a bit too close to spoiler territory, so I'll pull away from that, but it's interesting that it finds a way to include movies that were never even made in the film. I made a special effort to avoid spoilers as much as I could going in, so some of the reveals were truly delightful to me. I would say that perhaps this offered Marvel a chance to put an end to the multiverse saga, that seems to be floundering under the weight of disgraced actors and a general sense that nothing happening in these films has consequence, if you can always pull another version of a character from the multiverse to replace the one you lost. However, the comiccon announcement seems to suggest they're embracing, rather than shying away from that.Its' a thinner and more inconsequential plot than I would have hoped for, but it's a fun ride whilst you're on it. Will Deadpool get to exist in the wider MCU now, we'll have to wait and see?

Here we go again,The same idiotic ideas of:Let's make multiverse or time travel!Let's add the universe destruction at steak, if someone fart somewhere the universe at risk and will be destroyed!I really tried so hard to like this movie but couldn't, even if they try so hard to make fun of Marvel and Disney. This movie fell in the same mistakes and did the same stupid plots.Like you had Hugh Jackman, Ryan Reynolds, and hell you even had Wesley Snips and yet managed to not give depth to any characters in this movie!Why Logan's world was destroyed? What is the backstory of Cassandra Nova? His ex seeing someone but then in one sentence she decide to come back in half second.What a waste of potentials! And time!

Finally something worth to watch.The opening of the movie its so good, I am already in love with the movie.I mean Mr. Ryan jokes was so hilarious it makes the movie even better. I was laughing the whole time.Ryan needs His own standup comedy.I was hoping to see captain America but instead its the F4 So many surprises in this movie.It was true that deadpool should be in the Avengers team.Honestly this movie is too good. Hilarious,brutal, funny, heartwarming at the same time and wild. I will love to see another sequel from this movie Deadpool need His own team for sure.Well, go see the movie in theater.

Deadpool and Wolverine is the third film in the trilogy. The first 2 films were quite successful, garnering excellent box office and good ratings from the audience. Many people remember them because of: rather vulgar and black humor, breaking the fourth wall, unexpected fanservice, excessive cruelty and of course the magnificent Ryan Reynolds. The third part in this regard does not lag behind its predecessors, I will say more - to some extent it surpassed them. And although the film is very different from the first two, it still has a similar structure, but of course there are differences, and in some moments colossal. Perhaps it was thanks to them that the third part was remembered much more vividly, but of course you should not forget that this time the film is not only about Deadpool, but also about Wolverine, which attracts all the eyes of the audience. Hugh Jackman is as beautiful as ever in the image of Wolverine, giving out another great performance. We have been waiting for his return for more than 7 years, and for good reason, because the character came out quite interesting. It was a pleasure to follow his relationship with the main character, and the cherry on the cake was his backstory. On top of everything else, I was pleased with the canonical costume and that legendary mask, it is clear that the films were shot with a soul, wanting to give fans the very multiverse of madness that everyone had dreamed of for so long. Perfectly matched music, slow mo action, the return of old characters and the insane appearance of other unexpected (sometimes insane) cameos are the soul of this film, and the warm and touching ending warms the heart. The film fully met my expectations and gave me a lot of positive emotions, which means that it works, of course it has disadvantages, but for me personally, the main disadvantage was not the greatest timing, and the rest is no longer important.

To say that the MCU has been in a slow decline would be an understatement. MCU fans have been calling out for a 'Marvel Messiah' to rescue the falling franchise. In comes Deadpool & Wolverine.The whole movie lives up to its hype and did not disappoint one bit. From unhinged dark humour comedies to some interesting cameo's.One can say thank to Kevin Fiegie for listening to Marvel fans ! But we should also thank Fox for their own services and aid in providing all access to their marvel characters! (Sony please take note).Now to summarise.
