Yes, I would highly recommend seeing the movie. In someway and possibly arguably the best top 3 MCU film, if not number one but I'll let you decide that !

This movie is crude, violent, hilariously funny with the perfect amount of nostalgia. I did have high expectations and I was not disappointed. The cameos are also genius, one surprise after another.It's typical Ryan Reynolds DeadPool humour, I think it had an ok storyline but I was too busy laughing and being shocked I probably do need to see it a second timeIt's gory, even more than the first 2 but it's was fine. You should probably watch the Loki series on Disney as there are lots of people from that series on there but even if you haven't they explain it through the movie anyway so it's not that important but you just won't know the characters straight away. They must of had a pretty huge budget with the amount of big stars in this, it was epic.Hugh Jackman is jacked!! My god he looks good, and I love the tributes to the original comic book series.Go see it, it's absolutely worth it, you will be laughing from start to finish.

The third really had nothing to add, but they added stuff anyway. With the good reviews I was hoping for something as good as the last two, but instead it turned into the usual Hollywood circle jerk.The intro was great, but it was all downhill from there.That's actually the end of my review. The rest of this is filler for IMDum.The while movie was basically filler but some of the jokes were good. They clearly focused on ending the franchise vs making a good film. It wasn't awful, but I expected it to be at least as good as the last ones. I think it suffered from direction. Also, a little gay stuff is funny, but too much is bad and gross . . . Thankfully Borat didn't make a cameo appearance.

The long wait is over. And we finally have the 3rd installment of Deadpool but this time it's going to be under Marvel / Disney. This Deadpool sequel is the first rated R film from any Disney Marvel film and they were able to pull it off nicely overall.The story follows Wade's story from the ending of Deadpool 2 as he tries to search for some place where he can matter again. As the years went by, he was recruited by the TVA for a not so pleasant mission which lead him to different Earths to team up with a Wolverine variant to save his own doomed future. The film is full with action sequences specially the bloody fight scenes between Wolverine and Deadpool. The film was still able to pull off a good plot with good message but I guess what really brings this sequel to the next level are those cameos we did not see coming mixed with those we expected to see and they did not disappoint.Comparing to first DP films, this feels better than Deadpool 2. If you're a movie goer, a Marvel fan, a comic fan, you'll enjoy this movie and the wait is totally worth it. (You can see those bones and blood flying to you when you're in IMAX). And oh the soundtrack is probably the best from the three filmsCameos +++++ Story ++++ Action +++++ Humor +++ Soundtrack +++++The credits was a nice touch to Marvel Foxverse#deadpoolandwolverine is 8.5/10. I love it from start to very end"Everyone wants to matter. Turns out you don't have to be someone else to do it. You just need to open your eyes and look around. And if you're lucky, you'll find a few friends."

We should have left half-way through but we were curious to see how it ended.This was the only big movie we saw this Summer and I'm just do disappointed that after the first two (brilliant) Deadpool movies and some of the great movies Wolverine has been in, (these are probably my two favourite Marvel characters) that so many people thought that this script was worthy of this team-up.Also, what was the point of all the endless references? So many of which will go over most people's heads ten years from now.Finally, I can't understand why there are so many 9/10 and 10/10 scores..Don't waste your own money - if you're curious, then wait until it comes out on D+

And as of July 2024, Deadpool and Wolverine is the newest instalment in the pantheon of Marvel movies. This time though, Deadpool steps out of the 20th Century Fox universe and squarely into the Disney controlled Marvel MCU. If you don't know what any of that means, just type it all into google and see what comes out..In Deadpool and Wolverine, Ryan Reynolds drags Hugh Jackman kicking and screaming through an array of carnage, in-jokes, timelines and movie references. Chock full of cameos of past marvel characters who either briefly or never existed, this is a comic book movie fan's wet dream. If you are not a fan of any of this stuff, then this movie is not going to make any sense whatsoever, you will be completely lost as there is not much a plot to speak of.

The first and second *Deadpool* movies had something truly special. The first film introduced us to the gritty, gruesome origin of Deadpool, and its dark tone was perfectly balanced with a fresh, comical, anything-goes style of production that we had never seen before. Ryan Reynolds nailed the role. By the time *Deadpool 2* arrived, fans were hungry for more of that same style, and not only did it deliver, but it also gave us a compelling plot with the introduction of Cable, played by Josh Brolin.However, this third movie seems to miss the mark completely. While Ryan's comedic performance is once again a highlight-and arguably the best part of the movie-after a while, the jokes start to wear thin and even become annoying. There's a time and place for everything, but in this film, it feels like nothing was taken seriously. And because Deadpool didn't take anything seriously, neither did we, which ultimately detracted from the entire experience.The cameos were fantastic, but the story itself fell flat. It was so poorly constructed that it felt like it was written by AI. I would even go so far as to say it's one of the worst plots in Marvel history. It made no sense from the beginning, and it's a shame they dragged a complex character like Wolverine into this mess.In the end, the film was dull, predictable, and annoyingly funny-not in the good way the first two were.

Shawn Levy has made one of the most entertaining and interesting films of recent years Pace of the story, action, cinematography, all the elements of the story were executed in the best possible way. Unlike the other MCU movies of the last few years, Deadpool really had something to show. The hype and vibe of the film were completely correct, it is true that it did not have a story as rich as End Game's , and you should not expect it either, It had the beauty of a well-written story tho .The CEO of Marvel said that this movie is a new beginning for a new MCU age , and he was nothing but damn right about new age having been started with Deadpool and wolverineThere are millions of fans with millions of different ideas, but still, if you want to have a new experience in comedy and action, Deadpool and Wolverine is definitely worth every pennycameos are awesome.Such a gold comedy .

I always loved deadpool but a movie with deadpool and wolverine? Just... WOW! It's a movie about to heroes that they feel that they don't value trying to save their universe. It's a movie with a lot o humour, sarcasm (and specially about marvel, fox, the heroes and many more) with a lot of Easter eggs. The fights are amazing! The actors are all in the point. It's like actually they are the characters that they playing. With action, amazing animation, suspense, plot twist, things that you won't imagine will happen or you'll see. The actors have an amazing chemistry with everything! A big WARNING! The movie have a lot of spoilers for coming movies. Also, if you watched the previous deadpool movies you know that there are many bad words and implicitly.My advise, let yourself free, take pop corn and laugh with your heart! You'll have so much fun for all the during of the movie!

Obviously a lot of fan service came with this one, but it's done a good way. Humor was top notch, chemistry between Hugh Jackman and Ryan Reynolds was off the charts, action was great and story was satisfying. One of the best things was the soundtrack, all certified bangers. All the cameos were reaply nice and nothing felt forced to me. If i had to point a bad thing - or more like a less good thing - it's the antagonist. Without spoiling it, we pretty much have two antagonists, one i didnt mind and actually provided a lot of (even more) comic relief, but the other one was kinda meh. Not bad, just meh. But again, wouldnt call it bad tho.Also good performances by Ryan and Hugh, but especially Hugh, there are a couple of scenes where he went all out.Catch this one in the theater!

Well, it's worth waiting for!The movie is great with a combination of unfiltered jokes and unexpected action scenes. Also, it makes my nostalgic feelings better by seeing my favorite childhood characters.This movie is one that fans have been eagerly anticipating for a long time, and it does not disappoint. The story is engaging and keeps you hooked from start to finish. The blend of humor and action is perfect, creating a balance that keeps the audience entertained throughout. The jokes are fresh and funny, often catching you off guard with their wit and timing. The action scenes are well-choreographed and thrilling, providing plenty of excitement.One of the highlights of the movie is its ability to evoke nostalgia. Seeing beloved characters from my childhood brought back so many memories. It was a delight to see how these characters have been adapted for the big screen, maintaining their original charm while also fitting into the modern setting. The filmmakers have done a fantastic job of respecting the source material while also bringing something new to the table.The performances are another strong point. The cast is excellent, with each actor bringing their character to life in a way that feels both authentic and engaging. The chemistry between the characters is palpable, making their interactions feel genuine and heartfelt. Whether it's the lead actors or the supporting cast, everyone delivers performances that contribute to the overall success of the movie.The visual effects and cinematography are top-notch as well. The movie is visually stunning, with beautiful landscapes, impressive special effects, and a vibrant color palette that brings the story to life. The action sequences are particularly well done, with smooth transitions and clear visuals that make them easy to follow. The attention to detail in the visual presentation adds another layer of enjoyment to the experience.The soundtrack deserves a mention too. The music complements the scenes perfectly, enhancing the emotional impact of key moments and adding to the overall atmosphere. Whether it's an intense action scene or a touching emotional moment, the soundtrack helps to elevate the experience and draw the audience further into the story.Overall, this movie is a fantastic experience that offers something for everyone. Whether you're a long-time fan of the characters or new to the story, you'll find plenty to enjoy. The combination of humor, action, and nostalgia creates a unique and enjoyable experience that is sure to leave a lasting impression. The wait was definitely worth it, and I would highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a great time at the theater.In summary, this movie excels in many areas. The humor is sharp and well-timed, the action is exciting and well-executed, and the nostalgic elements add a wonderful layer of depth. The performances are strong across the board, and the visual and audio elements are top-notch. It's a movie that will make you laugh, keep you on the edge of your seat, and tug at your heartstrings all at once. If you're looking for a movie that offers a bit of everything, this one is definitely worth checking out.So, if you haven't seen it yet, make sure to grab your tickets and head to the theater. You won't be disappointed. This movie is a great addition to any movie lover's collection and a fantastic way to spend a couple of hours. Enjoy the ride!

Watched it yesterday on the big screen. It was ... well, yeah it was fun. But a very flawed fun that could have been way better. The action was great, even if Deadpool would not constantly have pointed out that the action is great. The brawling match between the two protagonists was fun to watch, but in the end both are pretty much immortal and none of the fights really mattered so the whole thing was kind of ... dare I say it - boring. Not once was I emotionaly attached to anyone in this picture. All the cool stuff of the first movies, like 4th wall breaks, the ultra-violence and the dick and ass jokes were simply too much. After an hour or so the film just started to reference itself over and over again. I could also not quite follow the time-line story with multiverse yadda yadda. And between all the dick jokes and the 500th 4th wall break were some supposedly serious moments, but since everything seems to be a joke in this movie even these serious scenes felt too artificial.The weakesst point imho is that there is never any urgency or real threat. All characters are just mocking images of themselfs now who constantly fight NPCs who do not matter - at all.All the meta stuff going on, like mocking Fox and Disney, the millions of eastereggs, the constant talking to the audience, the critics of marvel movies(!) might have worked for me, but am I expected to know production notes now in order to get the joke? Come on. As a movie it's a five for me, but I'll add a point for trying hard to be something on its own. I do really hope this will be the tombstone of Marvel. What else could there be mocked, referenced, pointed out or milked? It's like eating at McD: You leave with a full stomach but it's never satisfying food - or food in general.

No spoilers! But let's just clear this up right at the beginning: this movie is basically 95% fan service. And if you buy into that (like I did) then you will have a fantastic time. If you don't (or if you hate Deadpool as a character) then you probably won't enjoy it as much.Aside from that though, the thing that I enjoyed most about the movie is that Deadpool feels much more like he should. I love Deadpool 1 and 2, but he always kind of felt like he stuck out in those worlds. Yeah it's the same universe as X-Men, but it felt like they wouldn't let him get TOO comic booky (and in the second movie he basically doesn't fourth wall break at all, it's just snark and pop culture references). But here though, they let it all fly, and it works brilliantly.There's fourth wall breaking, ridiculous (in a good way) fight scenes, and just general over-the-top shenanigans for the entire runtime. There's still lots of meta humor, lots of shots at Disney and Fox, but I enjoyed it. I had so much fun with this movie and haven't laughed that much in a long time.As for issues (aside from the fan service), it does feel like Deadpool gets a little sidelined at times. The movie tries to balance both him and Wolverine, and sometimes it's a little weighted in Wolverine's favor. The emotional stakes are also fairly shallow. Yeah it has them and tries to justify them (and Wolverine actually gets some good development), but it's nothing you haven't seen before and isn't going to blow you away.So if you go into this expecting Logan, you're going to be severely disappointed. But if you go in expecting a shameless fan-service filled action romp, then you'll have a grand time.

I cannot understand why this movie is so highly rated. I have found it to be very disappointing. It looks cheap, with flat cinematography and with the sets that look like they were filmed in a garage or at a construction site. The movie basically looks like it was made for TV and streaming. The storyline is dumb, and it borrows heavily from previous Marvel tropes, ideas and cliches about multiverse blah blah. Because neither Deadpool nor Wolverine can be killed in a conventional sense the action and the fight scenes have no real stakes or tension, and they look cartoonish. Deadpool's constant verbal diarrhea quickly gets boring and exhausting, even if it contains a decent joke every few minutes. The "inside jokes" about Disney, Fox or Kevin Feige didn't work for me. Wolverine is one-note throughout the entire movie - serious and pissed off. The Marvel cameos are strictly for Marvel nerds, they didn't impress me much. Overall I didn't really enjoy this movie.

The movie is great. I wil try to tell all the emotions that I got from that movie Advantages 1. Movie kips you concentrated all the time. No time to breath 2. There a lot of jokes about everything. I dont want tell what exactly. Without spoilers!3. The main two actors did a really great job. They gave something new to superhero world. Not always it must to be for teens (12+) 4. The rating adults fits that movie.The man director of marvel studio made a good decision give to Rayan Reynolds tondo what he want. Its like a fresh air Everyone who say super hero is a past wrong. Deadpool 3 proof it.I had only one disappointment In the final fight was couple times that made me feel that wolverine is not really fighting. It was looks like he hits the air.

It's crazy...no exaggeration, and really take my "bleh-ness" about media overall (and especially superhero stuff), even The Boys's dark satire, into account when I say this - the meta-mea-culpa, unfiltered, unmetered insanity-mixed-with-genuine-heart-and-emotion of Deadpool & Wolverine is legitimately incredible. Insanely entertaining, and timeline-breakingly heartening and affirming. I was so ready to hate away - I've been conditioned to. But genuinely, the best superhero-genre film since, I feel like saying Dark Knight. That's at least how I feel right now. So many Disney/MCU meta-self-stabs, worth the ticket price alone. Ryan got full control of everything said, it's very clear. I'll call it now that it's making over 2B - this catharsis of 'superhero films are just bad nowadays aren't they' growing since Endgame, *actually* addressed in the film. Tight editing too, and Matt McFadyen nails it. A lot of fun had making it, it's clear. So much laughter and cheering in the packed cinema - an audience that felt seen and met where they are, frustrated/tired/jaded/confused, instead of bludgeoned obliviously/arrogantly yet again with another confusing overwrought MCU slog. This film is *with* the audience, and (without any spoilers) literally kills all the confusion and bloat of the past 5 years in one swoop. You'll genuinely love it. I'd love to go see it again. It's actually insane - the film would literally not be as effective or entertaining if Marvel *hadn't* bloat-fested and over-indulged for the past few years, because the fact they actually did that (and messed up as bad as they have) *made* this film. The conceit is so clever, it makes it feel like all that was intentional, just to justify this film and its premise of meta-apologising/meta-scrapping-and-starting again. Genuinely impressed - if this is the last MCU film I watch I'll be truly glad of it. If they keep up this quality though, and stop funding/favouring harmful entities, we could actually return to pre-Endgame levels of appreciation for the genre. I would love them to see how much people appreciate their mistake-owning in film form, so that they make actually mistake-owning and apologising moves in real life. One can hope!

When you go see a Deadpool movie you know what you're in for, or at least I do. For me it's kind of a one-time deal that's filled with sophomoric humor, gags, some good action and that's that. But this basically amps it up an another notch or two and it gets a little tedious towards the end. It's also openly sacrilegious so just know that going in. Hugh Jackman is very good in it though and there were some pretty funny gags at times. For me it all just got to be too much as the film progressed. I don't really regret having seen it but probably won't watch it again. This should be the last standalone Deadpool film in my opinion.

Now I understand the very simple title and the short runtime..guys ,this is not a huge pivotal MCU movie..it's basically celebrating deadpool and wolverine plus the old x-men movies..for some people that was a bad deal..but for me it was worth it because I had a blast with this movie !..the cameos are awesome , action scenes with epic music are top tier as usual , a few times I was laughing out loud..deadpool is a little washed out and exhausted , but wolverine..wolverine MADE this movie !..every fight scene with him is just goosebumps , whenever it gets stale or the tone gets too silly , wolverine even things out..the only thing bad about this movie is that it's too short..I swear when it was near the end I checked the time and I was like on no they're gonna wrap it up now and I really wanted it to go on..especially since I feel like this movie was cut a little and a lot of cameos are missing !..but in the end ,what can I say..there will never be a bad deadpool movie..and Hugh Jackman as wolverine will never stop being epic..I was entertained..a 10 for me.

"Deadpool & Wolverine" offers a mixed bag of entertainment, capturing some of the zany charm that fans of Deadpool have come to expect, largely thanks to Ryan Reynolds' comedic flair and the numerous cameos sprinkled throughout the film. These elements certainly inject a dose of fun and levity, making the movie enjoyable in parts.However, the movie falls short compared to the classic Marvel films of earlier days. The storyline is thin, with the inclusion of the TVA and the multiverse feeling more confusing and irritating than exciting. The villain, a rather bland and underdeveloped character, lacks depth and screen time, failing to leave a lasting impression.Despite these flaws, "Deadpool & Wolverine" manages to surpass the likes of "Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness" and "Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania," and is certainly a step up from "Ms. Marvel." Nevertheless, it's clear that Marvel/Disney has the potential to deliver much better.

It's a damn good time at the movies. Has the best jokes of the trilogy because it's much sharper and timely. Gore is still present although it's not as shocking as the first 2. Fight scenes are good and you may never see those fights ever again probably. :/Unfortunately the story is just alright and very straight-forward but who cares when you and the whole theater are having a good time. I too can only remember the gory bridge fight from the first movie and the whole comical death of the X Force and "Hi Wade" & "Bye Wade" from the second movieBeware of all the spoilers on the internet and make sure u watch it asap!!!2 hours+ flew by so fast I wish it was longer. (I didn't like Logan btw it was too s l o w w w for me). Fox really didn't spend a dime more than they wanted.

I loved Deadpool and I loved Wolverine and I loved all the cameos and the jokes and the fight scenes... BUT.. The story was so lame........The movie was very enjoyable but it felt like they came up with just any story to make the movie happen. It lacked the appeal of the first two Deadpool movies. There was nothing at stake and it just felt like the kind of lazy writing Deadpool mocked in the first movie. A superhero movie is only as good as its villain and despite Emma Corrin's great performance the movie didn't really do her character justice.This movie was mostly about fan service, as a fan myself, I think they delivered 100%. I just wish they put more effort into writing a great story as much as they did servicing the fans.

I absolutely loved the first Deadpool-it was witty, funny, intelligent, and a real breath of fresh air.But unfortunately, they've managed to ruin it this time around.I enjoy a good action movie with humor and clever jokes, but they went way overboard with the profanity in this one. It felt like there was an unnecessary F-bomb every two seconds, and it quickly became repetitive and unfunny.The multiverse concept that has been driving the MCU lately is really starting to wear thin. When you have a thousand versions of the same character, it becomes hard to care about what happens to any of them.I hate this multiverse concept deeply.There was also almost no storyline here, just over-the-top action scenes with an overly angry Hugh Jackman and Ryan Reynolds, countless cameos, and non-stop profanity, which all felt like a distraction from the lack of actual plot.A good action movie doesn't need to be a hyper-violent bloodbath, but this film seemed to think otherwise. The violence felt excessive and unnecessary, and it didn't serve the story in any meaningful way.I like Quentin Tarantino movies, so i'm not sensible about the matter if it serves the story.It reminded me of what happened with Thor: Love and Thunder-just like that movie, they tried too hard to replicate the magic of Thor: Ragnarok, but ended up failing, They made exact same mistakes.Honestly, the only aspect of this movie that was done right was the marketing campaign.And as for that dog licking Deadpool's mouth repeatedly? It was just plain disgusting.I'm done with the MCU, They were done after Infinity War, i just kept giving them chances one after another.

This is the best movie in 2024, the script and the story was the best.It was real comedy and the action in the movie were great, it takes you from real comedy that makes you laugh to drama and then to a massive action with the best choices of music in the background, loved the movie.It was enjoyable to watch.Expect the unexpected, I recommend everyone to watch this movie, you will miss the best movie in 2024.Usually when we have a squel to a movie it disappoint us with a weak story but in Deadpool and Wolverine , you cannot ask for better.It deserve all the hypes , it's really cool to watch comedy that makes you laugh nowadays.Thank you Disney and Marvel for creating this magic.

We've all waited in anticipation for the release of Deadpool & Wolverine. I will go out on a limb and say that THIS MOVIE WAS EVERYTHING THE MCU NEEDED!! This might just be one of the best comic book films of all times! Ryan Reynolds does not hold back! There were instances where the audience couldn't believe what they were hearing. The jokes will make you laugh out loud. The brutal and visceral action sequences will have you on the edge of your seats!!! The emotions hit.Hugh Jackman knocks it out the park once again as Wolverine. This is certainly a contender for his performance in Logan.The story and plot is straight out of a comic book movie which I love, this has all the authenticity I was desperately hoping for from a deadpool film. Get ready, Marvel Jesus has arrived. The movie is certainly up there for the best superhero movies oat. 10/10. Ps-you are not ready for the cameos!!!

The movie is pure cinema! Congrats to Shawn Levy, Ryan Reynolds, Hugh Jackman, Emma Corrin and the rest of the crew whether they are in the movie or the backstage. Seeing this team-up of these two actors in their iconic roles after 15 years was the best movie experience since 'Spider-Man: No Way Home'. The cameos never disappoint but I don't want to get into that to avoid spoilers. The humor was amazing and very deadpooly. It was comedic where it wanted to be and unlike 'Thor: Love and Thunder' this movie was actually funny. The visual effects and the cgi were pretty good and in my opinion better than any of the recent marvel projects. Overall, this movie with all the characters in it didn't disappoint at all. Amazing movie, congratulations again to everyone who worked on it!

Not as good as Deadpool, better than Deadpool 2.A fun ride with fabulous perfromances from Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackson, great to finally see Wolverine portrayed this way. Cameos were great and somewhat unexpected in a few instances, glad I hid from the Youtube spoilers. But... The morning after and the endorphines have worn off. I feel It relies a little too heaily on memberberries and nostalgia to hide a lackluster story, that said, it could have been another 2hrs long and I would still have been having fun.Would I like more Deadpool and Wolverine team ups in the future, hell yeah, but maybe use some of the pre-existing storylines from the comics as current Hollywood writers seem to only be good at dialogue.

Its beautiful everything is perfectly executed , funny but not too much funny that the story is just out of the movie. Its just perfect everything down to the last minute detail . Best movie I've ever gone to a cinema to even tho i had tow geeks behind me that kept orgasming at each and every goddamn reference that Deadpool said, the moving chairs and 3D glasses made it 65% better in my opinion of course, now im just trying to write anything to fill the review also my cousin didn't understand jack so he just kept fake laughing whenever he heard other people laugh that was annoying but not annoying enough to ruin the experience.

"Deadpool and Wolverine" would be a phenomenal movie, combining the irreverent humor of Deadpool with Wolverine's gritty, intense persona. Both characters, played by Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman respectively, have a dynamic that fans adore. Their contrasting styles - Deadpool's comedic, fourth-wall-breaking antics and Wolverine's brooding, fierce demeanor - create a compelling and entertaining balance.The film could explore their uneasy alliance, mixing brutal action sequences with hilarious, biting dialogue. Their banter alone would be worth the price of admission, as each character's unique quirks and personalities clash and complement each other in unexpected ways.The storyline could delve into a mission requiring their reluctant partnership, showcasing epic battles, surprising twists, and deeper character development. The plot could also introduce new villains and allies, enriching the Marvel universe further.Cameos and references to other Marvel characters would enhance the experience, making it a treat for long-time fans. Overall, "Deadpool and Wolverine" would not only be a great movie due to its action and humor but also because of the rich character interactions and storytelling possibilities it presents.

7.0/10 (Definitely Recommend)I went into "Deadpool & Wolverine" not knowing what the whole plot point was because I wanted to be surprised. I don't know if that hurt my ability to enjoy the film or not, but after coming out of the showing I felt it was overhyped for what was produced. The story isn't anything special, and the villain is cool to see but comes out mediocre.Some of the sequences are over the top and excessive in the humour they produce. They start off enjoyable, but because they continue beyond appropriate enjoyment, my laughter started to die down. However, there are a lot of good parts that are funny and laughter ranges from little snorts to complete chuckles.The action and aggression that comes with the film are good, but they're lumped into parts instead of spread out to continue the enjoyment so boredom kicks in. Visually the film is just enjoyable especially in 3D. The violence and blood is excessive, but doesn't ruin the film.The chemistry between Hugh and Ryan is amazing. I loved seeing them on the screen together and their banter is enjoyable. I also liked the cameos that come throughout, and some of the easter eggs that I was able to catch.Overall, a slightly overhyped film that still entertains. I wish I could be more specific on things, but I don't want to ruin or spoil the film for anyone. Action is too lumped instead of spread out, the comedy is both lumped, but also spread out to maintain a form of laughter throughout. Visually appealing especially in 3D, and the cameos/easter eggs are fantastic.That's it for now. Thanks for taking time to read my review. Happy watching and enjoy the show!

Wow, where do I even start? "Deadpool vs. Wolverine" felt like an absolute trainwreck. The storyline was paper-thin, with so many plot points that made no sense at all. It was as if they were just throwing random ideas together without any regard for coherence. One moment you're in one setting, the next you're somewhere else with zero explanation. It was like a bunch of disconnected scenes stitched together.There was no heart in this movie whatsoever. I didn't feel anything for the characters or their supposed struggles. It lacked any depth, emotion, or real stakes. It's like they forgot that great superhero films need some kind of emotional core to keep the audience invested. This was just mindless action without purpose.And the humor? It fell completely flat. Just because you throw in a ton of cursing doesn't automatically make something funny. It felt like a teenager trying too hard to be edgy, with juvenile jokes that made me cringe more than laugh. The whole thing had the feel of a script written by a 12-year-old who thinks swearing is the peak of comedy.Overall, this movie was a huge letdown. It tried to coast on the popularity of Deadpool and Wolverine, but without a solid story or any meaningful character moments, it was just an empty, chaotic mess.

I have to qualify this by saying I never saw any prior Deadpool movies and only some of the X-men movies. Despite those facts I really loved this movie. There are definitely things I wish I understood better about some of the back story and characters but you can watch this one with no prior knowledge and still enjoy it. It is hilariously funny, edgy, and sharp. The script is good and self-effacing. The characters are great. Hugh Jackman is fantastic. This is unique. It is not intended for kids. It is adult and funny and violent and blue as hell. I loved "Mary Poppins" more than I can admit. This was a good time at the movies. I would see this again.

Let me first start off. I am a huge Marvel fan. I have watched every Marvel movie. The Deadpool series was not my favourite. Oh boy did Ryan Reynolds knock this movie out of the park. Him along with Hugh Jackman is a match made in heaven that I wished Marvel had done years ago. They are fantastic together. I loved how they combined old school characters with new characters. I haven't laughed this hard at the movies in a very long time. It is very gory and bloody but there are scenes that make up for it that embraces both comedy and emotion. A truly great movie knows how to combine the two and this movie did it. GO WATCH IT. You will not be disappointed. Best movie of 2024 and a home run for Marvel and the Deadpool series.

Another fitting tribute THE Wolverine. The best version so far. The chemistry between Wade and Logan is spot on. The gore, the humor, the action, the "what ifs", nostalgia and more (;-))was on the money and exactly what the people asked for. If you're a fan of Marvel, Wolverine or deadpool, this movie provided.If nothing else this movie was entertaining and worth the ticket. Watch it, dont bring your kids and enjoy.Without spoilers, I highly recommend watching this movie. Bit of a warning though, some concepts do make reference to older x-men, marvel, MCU and deadpool movies so it might be worth catching up or rewatching some if you haven't already bit wont diminish your enjoyment when if you aren't up to date. Nonetheless this movie was fun through and through. Thank you Ryan and once again/most of all thank you to Hugh Jackmen for a fitting (final?) Tribute to THE X-man. You're legacy is safe.

I just hope this serve as a guide for the fans out there. Everybody of a full theater stayed seated until the very last second waiting for the post credit scene (and it is worth it). There are a lot of fun cameos from decades past and maybe to come, great fight scenes and tons of jokes for the comics and Marvel fans. I don't believe anyone is expecting a masterpiece plot or academy awards scripts and acting, but it a fan movie made from and for fans, with respect for the audience and the source material and that's all that really matters when you go watch a movie like this one. And if you are not a fan of Marvel or superhero's movies, well, why will you bother to go see it anyway?

Marvel needed this win and they got it big time here. The movie will have you laughing from start to finish with fantastic performances from both Ryan Reynolds and a returning Hugh Jackman, there has never been two actors made for their respective roles than these two.The action is basically non stop and the soundtrack will have you bopping your head as Deadpool and wolverine have their funThe cameos are fantastic. We all expect cameos from Marvel at this point and this definitely didn't disappoint. With a cameo that I did not see coming at all and when you watch the movie you probably will know what one it is.To sum up. This is a fantastic return to form for Marvel and yet another great outing from Reynolds favourite character.

This is a tough one. On the one hand, I think the movie is exactly what most people want from it - Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman hanging out, making jokes, and having a good time in the MCU. If that's all you're looking for, this movie absolutely delivers and it's well worth the price of admission. On the other hand... it's easily the worst of the three Deadpool movies.Deadpool is ostensibly doing everything he's doing in this movie in order to save his loved ones - all of the aforementioned supporting players from earlier Deadpool movies - characters like Yukio, Negasonic Teenage Warhead, Colossus, Vanessa, Blind Al, Dopinder, etc etc. However, only one of these supporting characters from the previous two Deadpool movies gets more than 2 minutes screen time, many of the rest don't even get lines. Instead, this movie replaces those supporting players for cameos from various failed Marvel projects - often for nothing more than a single joke or lazy nostalgic references. The idea is that these characters will finally be given the opportunity to have the send off / swan song they were previously denied in their own movies - but... none of them really get to enjoy that. They're just used in a fight montage that basically doesn't matter at all in the grand scheme of things.I can't help but feel like this would have been a much better movie had it traded the mostly ridiculous cameos in favor of involving the supporting Deadpool characters we've all come to love over the past two movies.I enjoyed the jokes for the most part, and it's good to see Disney embrace the rated R label for something like this - but the movie ultimately kind of fell flat as a whole.

Before watching the movie, I wasn't sure what to expect of a Deadpool & Wolverine movie. I have watched Deadpool 1 and 2 and really liked it (the first one more than the sequel) but this one is really massive! A lot of action and a lot of good jokes, there was many moments where the audience were just bursting out laughing. I mean, don't look at me I was next to my younger brother and I was honestly a little embarrassed of how some of the jokes were a bit too spicy but legendary in laughter! I think I really want to watch another movie with these two, they make an incredible team. I like how Deadpool is the funny always talking kinda guy and Wolverine is just there dropping f bombs and acting like he is sick of everything. Would recommend everyone watches this movie on a big screen it really makes a difference! I watched it on iMax and it was lit!

This isn't a WIDE APPEAL movie, it has those elements, but this clearly was made for the nerds and marvel loyalists. Which isn't a bad thing, just means if you're like me and don't get all 1000 references, it's going to be a bumpy ride for you. I got a lot of them. It suffers the Rick and Morty, Smiling Friends, current era humor problem of needing 100 jokes per minute and as such there's really a weak semblance of a plot and story. It was weirdly "CUTE" which given the amount of swearing and violence, is weird to say. I wouldn't say I regretted seeing it opening day, but would say, this is a STREAMING movie. That way you can rewind parts to see the jokes and easter eggs you've missed.The pros: -Obviously the CHEMISTRY between two of the nicest people in Hollywood from what I've heard. It's great. Though they did have a few character breaks where it clearly was like take 100 and they didn't have the budget to retake something anymore so you'll catch a Hugh Jackman smirk here or there when he's supposed to be pissed off. Pretty sure Happy Hogan has a MAJOR character break in his scene.-Decent effects -Good jokes -Some obscure out of left field references, like the "Leifeld Foot Store". Rob Leifeld co-created Deadpool.Cons: -Over stays its welcome -Blind old lady that's hood is kind of a tired old trope, I mean Airplane did that joke and it was getting old by that point. It's like getting a child to say bad things.-Story is so who cares and you can tell, since it relies way more on plot conveniences than logic.-Music was trying way too hard to be LOL RANDOM. "Isn't it funny we're playing a pop song from the 90s and early 2000s while slaughtering a hoard of people?"Overall If you're a comic fan, and a fan of the first two, you'll like it. It's made for you guys. Those looking for an Action Comedy flick might want to look elsewhere.

It's embarrassing to see this rated at eight stars. The first was a genius masterpiece. Witty, funny, likable characters, and you could see the effort all over the film for the full running time.The second film breaks the fourth wall yet more. Ryan Reynolds keeps talking about being the underdog, playing the likable guy who has an ongoing beef with Wolverine and Hugh Jackman occasionally, okay, that's funny. But there was too much effort into trying to make Deadpool into a billion dollar franchise with numerous spin-offs, etc etc. As a result, while the film had its moments, it definitely suffered with its focus on how to maximize the money and the depth the storyline.Come the third film and there is no fourth wall anymore. It's not an occasional fun moment. Wolverine isn't even Wolverine. It's just Jackman in a wolverine suit pretending to be angry with Reynolds because this was never, ever, ever, ever, ever going to happen. But now it happens, what a surprise. These guys apparently know that there are millions of desperate people around the world waiting to put the two of them together in a film and laugh about these oh so clever in jokes and be able to say how funny they are.Well the in jokes aren't that funny at all. They are told over and over and over. Wolverine had absolutely nothing interesting to say and just dropped the f-bomb, bub, and short short angry blurbs in order to provoke numerous cgi fights repeat themselves. The joke is on the audience. The story was dumb. The cameos were pretty dumb. Lots of cursing for the sake of cursing and then laughing like 5-year-olds that they were able to do it in a Disney film. Oh wow.The wit and smart jokes are gone. It's now full-fledged franchise with multiple other actors being Ryan reynolds's best friend because he's gifted them with their own spin-off superhero movie that will get greenlighted as a result of this film. It's totally mindless. It may take another film for people to realize, but this is really an unbelievably poor film that sets a low barrier for effort. And massive product placement.

Deadpool & Wolverine is probably one of the best movies Marvel has produced lately! This is what you call a comic book movie. The actors did an amazing job at bringing these beloved characters alive and portrayed them as expected, Hugh Jackman is the only Wolverine and Ryan Reynolds is Deadpool.The storyline of this movie was clear and well thought out, and unexpected moments were met with applause from the audience. Also, the comedy was actually funny this time around, lately, Marvel comedy has felt very forced, but this felt like a breath of fresh air. And another thing that I want to point out, is the soundtrack and sound design... PHENOMENAL!!!!! I found myself singing along to the songs and they added just that final touch to the scene, and the sound design was CRISP.Overall, please go and see this movie, it won't disappoint you. If you can't make it to any showings, please watch it when it becomes available on streaming services. 1000/10!

There's a lot of people talking about how the multiverse has "ruined" the MCU, and that this film was a multiverse cash grab and an attempt at falling in line with everything else. But, they're wrong. Deadpool is, and always has been, an irreverent character that takes personal shots at the writers, producers, and even the artists that have created him. This film is no different.Is it a classic Marvel movie? No. Is it a regular down to earth Deadpool movie? No. Is it an X-Men movie? No. It's more than that. Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman bring this buddy-cop film across the multiverse to life and bring in some surprising cameos and make fun of and potentially set up the next great Avengers film with Secret Wars. Even if this is the end (which would be ending on a high note) they nailed it. Fan fare is what the people want, and then they complain when they get it.People like to complain that movies are just fanfare and cameos, and then complain when there isn't enough fanfare and cameos. Watch it for yourself. And love every minute of it.Ryan and Hugh are the best at what they do, and what Deadpool and Wolverine do isn't very nice.

The opening title sequence, I liked. It was a bit different, props for that. In general the movie was ok. It was a Deadpool movie. If you like DP movies you will enjoy this one too.However, DPs many many monologues could be shorter. At the end there had been quite many and it got a bit boring. Otherwise they were well written.The story seemed a bit weak. In my opinion there wasn't a clear goal where the story was going. At least I feel the previous too were much more engaging and there was a clear direction and you as the viewer got engaged. I think they got too cought in the idiosyncrasies of DP and should dial it back a little for the next one.Still you should go watch it, it's a good movie. Could be better though.

Well, well, well, if it isn't the two most obnoxious (yet lovable) mutants in the Marvel universe, finally gracing us with their long-awaited cinematic reunion. Deadpool & Wolverine: The Snarkiest Show on Earth is exactly what you'd expect - a delightfully chaotic, fourth-wall-breaking, profanity-laced romp that somehow manages to be both mindless fun and surprisingly heartwarming.Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman clearly had a blast reprising their iconic roles, and their on-screen chemistry is so palpable you can practically smell the testosterone and sarcasm wafting through the theater. The plot is basically just an excuse for these two egomaniacs to one-up each other in increasingly ridiculous ways, but who cares when the results are this entertaining?Sure, the action sequences are a bit over-the-top (even for a superhero movie), the jokes sometimes land with all the subtlety of a Juggernaut to the face, and the whole thing is about as subtle as a Deadpool to the, well, you get the idea. But if you're looking for a cinematic experience that will make your inner 12-year-old giggle uncontrollably while your outer 30-something cringes, this is the film for you.Just don't bring the kids - unless you want them asking some very uncomfortable questions afterwards. Overall, a delightfully unhinged addition to the Marvel canon. Now, if you'll excuse me, I need to go wash the snarky off.

This is a difficult movie to assess. My initial thinking was that one of these after six years is fine and I think this is in some ways a welcome return to form. On the other hand, the idea of the multiverse, which has already been overplayed, is in force here. Not on the same level as, for example, the second Dr. Strange movie, but still it is here. They are smart enough to make fun of it, but even if you are satirizing and commenting on something by doing that very thing, you are still doing that very thing.Same with fan service. The movie is both doing it and making fun of it. They brought back so many characters from the past. This kind of meta-irony doesn't really work for me as it has become a cliche on to itself. At the same time, it is Deadpool, so I kind of signed up for this specifically. I do admit that there was one little-more-than-a-cameo that was actually done in a very cool way (and as far as I knew, they managed to keep it a secret this time).Sure, there is stuff in this movie that gets me, but I'm easy that way. I'll cry for anything with weepy enough soundtrack. But again, there's one of these things that really works for me within all the noise.Deadpool movies haven't really needed a good villain, but Cassandra Nova works pretty well and they do some cool things with her powers here. Also, I always enjoy it when the actor seems to relish the role and that's definitely the case here.In the end, there's a lot of things to like. Pretty every scene is good on it's own, but the whole feels messy and unfocused... or more like focused on the wrong things. I liked it, but I don't see this as being the course correction MCU so dearly needs.

I want to start by saying this movie opens with a bang. There's no slow crawl start. It just opens in your face! White the first minute or two of it. I was already laughing hysterically.If you're a fan of the Deadpool franchise, marvel universe, or X-Men at all, this movie is absolutely for you!I've read some reviews where people were talking about. It was pandering too much to the fans, but that's what Deadpool's always been. I feel by far this is the best entry in the Deadpool genre and not just because Hugh Jackman's in it.The movie is a roller coaster that doesn't stop at all, but the storyline is very good, there's a lot of emotion in certain scenes. So besides the fact that it's funny, it does take moments to be serious that pull at your heartstrings.The acting and the graphics were great! This is one of my favorite movies I've seen in a long time for so many reasons. It's just a good time! And there's so many Easter eggs you need to rewatch it just to catch them all.I've seen some people give it a night, I'm going to give it a 10 because it does exactly what it's supposed to do and it does it very well. If you didn't like the other deadpools, this is not going to be your cup of tea so just skip it. , then buckle up cuz this is one crazy ride!I'm still singing bye-bye bye by NSync in my head. IYKYKMy husband and I absolutely loved this!

I might be a victim of my own hype train. I've been hanging for this movie since the announcement. It doesn't help that Ryan Reynolds is a master of advertising. The marketing was so fun.So I was a bit sad that I left the cinema feeling a bit ... nothing.Now, that's not to say this is a bad movie. It is still entertaining. But it felt off and I'm not 100% sure why. I laughed, many times. Some jokes were really top tier too. But many jokes went longer than they should (Deadpool being suited up at the TVA comes to mind). The cameos were pretty cool (looking at you Vampire man) but were ultimately nostalgic cut ins with no emotion value at all. There was no time to gain a sense of comradery from any of them. They were either there for a cheap joke, or push the plot forward enough before being left behind. I know it's Deadpool "and" Wolverine. But could've had solid ground with other characters. DP2 managed it.The only thing I hated was the Venessa side story. Not only was it basically a couple of lines that followed the movie tendency to pump and dump. But the whole thing didn't feel like anything either character would do. It just didn't feel right. And Venessa deserves better (And more screen time).I enjoyed seeing Logan again. The movie intro dance was great. The fight scenes were great, though the music choices felt strange, like someone said: "hey, I like this song, and it's a whacky choice coupled with fight scenes, lets add it". I enjoyed the villain (even if she seemed to overdo it a bit) ... Vampire dude and purple bomber!Over all, watchable, but not something I'd go out of my way to watch again (I might grab a physical copy to complete my collection though - ooh, wait, I can't cause Disney stopped making physical media for Australia)

This is another movie (after previous Thor) that is a total disappointment for me, boring and silly.Honestly I was falling asleep in the cinema even though I watched previous Deadpool few times.If it wasn't for Ryan Reynolds who is really funny I would give one star.I feel like Disney keeps running both Star Wars and Marvel universe. I wander is it is the AI writes scripts recently. It is more about the special effects than about the story. The movie is completely empty for me, there is no plot not any purpose, in fact I can't even say what the movie was about.Massive disappointment as both characters are very good.

Deadpool wolverine is the first Marvel movie since the last Guardian that I actually enjoyed. The many digs at Fox, Sony and Marvel were perfect and captured everyone's feeling about the journey that the MCU has been on. I haven't seen my husband enjoy a movie so much in years.The cameos were perfect, the timing spot on, the Easter eggs were so many I had to go watch a YouTuber show my the dozens I missed. The chemistry was great between Hugh and Ryan and you could tell they were having the time of their lives.Thank you Ryan and Hugh for a tremendously wonderful night of entertainment! You made movie watching great again.

Wow! Just wow! Might be one of my favorite Marvel films next to Logan. A self aware romp through a forgetten Marvel catalog of characters complete with some pretty explosive and unexpected cameos.The way the film pokes fun of the entire Superhero genre was quickfire and only got better as the film went on. The creators knew how to hold their card til just the right moment and the payoff was major. Big laughs from everyone in the audience and for once they felt natural to the characters.Speaking of which, a surprising amount of chemistry from Reynolds and Jackman. They really know how to riff off eachothers characters and it just felt right. At first, I was afraid the mash up was going to become more of a gimmick but I'm glad they made it flow into the plotline the way they did.Overall, without giving away too much, this is a Marvel masterpiece. Highly recommended to fans of the Marvel filmography, or Deadpool in general. And as always with the character, not for the kiddos in the slightest.5 vibranium katanas out of 5.

Wolverine's claws really undercut Wade's wit. Just not funny nor original. Anymore. And the contrast between Logan's resigned silence and Deadpool's overdosed mouth is honestly tiring.This is a wanna-be Marvel movie without admitting it. The Avengers are laughing hard in their universe. The haters become the hated.There was so much auto-humour, it is just missing the mark. All the talk about Disney, Fox, the dog, Blake Lively. What is this, a semi-nepotic graveyard for attention hungry influencers? Give us a break.And what is it with cinema ticket prices Jesus. It cost me a fortune and now I want the katana for myself.

Tone and Style: The film would be a wild mix of action, comedy, and heartfelt moments. Deadpool's meta-humor and fourth-wall breaks would provide a unique narrative style, often poking fun at superhero tropes and the X-Men universe. The blend of Wolverine's gritty realism with Deadpool's cartoonish violence would create a distinct and entertaining dynamic.Character Development: Despite the humor, the film could delve into the emotional depths of both characters. Exploring Wolverine's struggle with his past and Deadpool's search for purpose could add layers of complexity to the story. Their evolving friendship would be a central theme, highlighting their mutual respect and understanding.In summary, a film combining Deadpool and Wolverine would be a chaotic, hilarious, and action-packed ride. The dynamic between the two characters, along with their contrasting personalities and fighting styles, would make for an unforgettable and entertaining superhero adventure.

Here's the thing the film was fun I love our two main leads but my biggest issue with the film is the jumbled story which is no surprise considering the MCU's fall from grace it has a huge multiverse issue, it points out the problems with that gimmick while also participating in it, the TVA just doesn't work from a narrative perspective they ruined my enjoyment of Loki, the nostalgia bait cameos also ruined Doctor Strange: MVOM, the villain was awful and like I said the multiverse aspect is just bad had this film been under just Fox it could have been much better but I'm sorry.This is another MCU fall from grace, don't get me wrong I enjoyed it but I much preferred, Deadpool and Wolverines journey in this and could of done without that horrible multiverse gimmick marvel won't stop shoving in peoples faces, I give this film a 6/10 critics will hate this thing audiences will love the cameos and nostalgia bait as they often always do.

If you still care about the MCU, is this movie necessary? Not at all.Is it a fun entry that gives the fans a bit more of what they like? Yes.I'm tempted to say this is a worthy cinematic experience.. ONLY because part of me understands this follows in-line with what Far From Home did and what it offered it's audience (enjoying it before somebody ruins it for you). Not because the plot was particularly memorable or well made! But because it rocks an excellent cast of surprises and has Cameos that are exactly what the latest Dr Strange's attempt wanted to be (giving a chance to something meaningful)! Not to mention excellent action choreographies, and how it works as a lovely farewell to a part of the Fox's Marvel entries.Personally, I felt the pacing was too slow in parts, and the movie a tad long. Some of the dialogue becomes tiring after a point, and the well-casted villain becomes an unnecessary clich after a point.. just for the movie to have an ending. I was also sadly-reminded of the pointless Loki and all it entails. Also, it becomes a bit overindulging at the end, and the CGI gets progressively worse. I think that if the story is good, the CGI's quality shouldn't matter as much, as it serves a purpose to raise one's imagination and help the narrative visually. For this movie, I probably started to notice or care about it, because after a certain point the story is just whatever.But still! If the entirety of the MCU ended with this, I'd be fine with it.

Reading reviews I was extremely excited to see this movie. I think I cought the very last week it was shown in cinema in my city, so was definitely late to the party.I thought the jokes were repetitive and unimaginative.The action was too CGI looking, as most hero movies nowadays.The plot was flat with not much , rather then the constant referrals to other superheros.The love story was so weak , I could barely feel anything. The connection between Wolverine and Deadpool seemed forced.For me the only enjoyable thing in this movie was the songs and the end credits where they showed old behind the scenes from X-Men.

Finally. So many things we have all wanted are now in movie form. Thankyou Marvel. This isn't the first time you made my jaw drop or smile for a entire movie. I sure hope it's not the last. I needed this. Child hood is good once again. Hugh brought his A game. So much fun. Deadpool is a character that never stops to make us smile. This was a bloody goodtime. Didn't think I liked the story for a split second then was quickly adverted to the awesomeness that played out. Perfection or dang near perfect. The character they showed and all the cameo's were awesome. Hearing people gasp in happiness in theater was cool .

This is near perfection, all the 4th wall breaks, all the one liners, it's just amazing. Lots of Cameos, some great surprises.Hugh Jackman adds so much to Deadpool, he's so so good. Ryan Reynolds is once again nothing short of sensational, proving once again that there is nobody on the planet but him that can play Deadpool.The story in this movie crosses the boundaries of cinema and really finds comedy genius in every moment. It's a joy to watch. The cross over from Fox to Disney has had no adverse effect on the franchise, if anything it has enhanced it. I can only hope there will be another in the series, with as many twists and Cameos.

This film is an exceptional cinematic experience that offers a wealth of intriguing details for avid comic book enthusiasts. The meticulous attention to the source material is evident in every scene, creating a rich tapestry that honors the legacy of the characters while introducing fresh elements that keep the narrative exciting and unpredictable.Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman deliver outstanding performances in their respective roles as Deadpool and Wolverine. Reynolds brings his signature irreverence and wit to Deadpool, perfectly capturing the character's sardonic humor and unpredictable nature. Jackman, as ever, embodies Wolverine with a raw intensity and depth that highlights the character's inner struggles and resilience. Their on-screen chemistry is electric, and their dynamic interactions provide both heartfelt moments and laugh-out-loud humor, making the film a thrilling ride from start to finish.The film's refreshing and engaging storytelling is a masterclass in balancing action, drama, and comedy. The plot weaves together intricate character arcs with high-stakes conflicts, resulting in a narrative that is both emotionally resonant and endlessly entertaining. The director's vision is brought to life through stunning visual effects and meticulously choreographed action sequences that are as visually spectacular as they are narratively compelling.Moreover, the film does not shy away from exploring deeper themes such as identity, redemption, and the cost of heroism, adding layers of complexity that elevate it beyond a typical superhero flick. The supporting cast also deserves praise for their strong performances, which add further depth and nuance to the story.Overall, this Deadpool and Wolverine film is a must-watch for fans of the genre. It not only pays homage to the beloved characters and their rich histories but also pushes the boundaries of superhero storytelling, delivering a cinematic experience that is as thought-provoking as it is entertaining.

Deadpool & Wolverine' is undoubtedly the most anticipated film of the year for many. A year that is now starting to pick up in terms of high-quality movies, and a Phase that has seen Marvel Studios struggle needed this film to succeed, and not just in terms of box office numbers. The Deadpool films have always been known for cheeky humor and legendary fourth wall breaks, but also for well-crafted action comedies that gave audiences what they wanted. Since 20th Century Fox, the studio behind those first two movies and that of X-Men, got bought out by Disney in 2019, many and I wondered how the merc's new home would go about maintaining the spirit of the character. Worries also revolve around how they could bring back Wolverine without tainting his legendary ending in 'Logan.' Was this third installment able to live up to expectations, and possibly exceed them? Yes.Except for one scene with shaky cam, the action was great, especially the expected fight between Deadpool and Wolverine. Shawn Levy knows how to direct entertaining and bloody action scenes. It showed in 'Free Guy,' and it shows here!Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman are fantastic as their respective characters. After fifteen years of having to deal with their appearance in 'X-Men Origins: Wolverine,' this is the team-up we've all been waiting for. Ryan Reynolds has proven himself reliably great as Deadpool, while Hugh Jackman channels in his prior work as Wolverine while also portraying a complex, different version of the character.The cameos range from expected to mind-blowing. I'm glad I binged all of the X-Men movies prior and most of the other Fox/Marvel movies except for 'Elektra' and the 2015 'Fantastic Four.' I won't say anything else for the risk of spoiling it, but believe me, it's a multiverse movie that understands when to implement cameos and pays tribute to the legacy of the Fox/Marvel films.Other than that, the fourth-wall breaks are iconic, Cassandra Nova is a good villain, the CGI is great, and the movie ends satisfyingly and excitingly.Overall, 'Deadpool & Wolverine' delivers what I expected and more! Now and then, I don't expect this film to "save the MCU," but it manages to be a phenomenal farewell to the characters of Deadpool and Wolverine (for a second time).For the technical score, my only issue is that one action scene with shaky cam, which leads to it being a 9/10. Technically not the best film of the year, as films like 'Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga,' 'Late Night with the Devil,' and 'Longlegs' have more merit. For the enjoyment score, Deadpool & Wolverine is the most reliably entertaining film of the year that I'll buy once it's on Digital. 10/10. You were probably going to see it anyway, and for good reason! It's damn fun!

In moviemaking, sadly, there can be a problem with going to the well too many times, and this latest installment in one of filmdom's better cinematic franchises verges on proving just that. This offering's predecessors (2016, 2018) significantly distinguished themselves from the kind of fare typically found in the superhero genre with their outrageously bawdy humor, hilarious sight gags and relentlessly maverick attitude. This time out, however, director Shawn Levy's latest effort is a decidedly hit or miss affair, with an often-incoherent script that feels like it was cobbled together from a collection of leftover parts, some of which work and some of which don't. I suppose that's not entirely surprising from a screenplay that was penned by four different writers, making me wonder how much consensus was in place in compiling the finished product. Moreover, this film appears to be intended to fold the Deadpool franchise into the X-Men franchise, an intriguing idea that, regrettably, is handled rather clumsily (as has often been the case with many other recent fusion offerings in the Marvel Universe). And, if all that weren't bad enough, this release gives short shrift to the colorful cast of supporting players that made the Deadpool films so funny, original and enjoyable, relegating them to little more than cameos in favor of walk-ons by a host of other MCU characters (some of them remarkably obscure, I might add) in an attempt to help cement the franchise cross-pollination going on here. It makes for awkward storytelling at times, especially for viewers who might not be familiar with these lesser-known figures, some of which are drawn from Marvel source material unrelated to its big screen offerings. To the picture's credit, it features yet another stellar turn by Ryan Reynolds as the off-color protagonist, as well as its share of hilarious bits (without a doubt the franchise's historically strongest suit), including a number of unabashed, razor-sharp asides referencing off-screen developments related to the studios that produced these films and the actors who have appeared in them. These strengths notwithstanding, however, this is a production that has sadly watered down the elements that best made this franchise work in favor of an overarching programming agenda that simply doesn't serve this film or the series particularly well. The creators would have served themselves and viewers better by sticking with what works and the basics of good storytelling than trying to force an issue for the sake of future productions that may or may not work over the long term. This has been a noticeable downfall in the quality of many of the most recent Marvel Universe releases, and I'd truly hate to see this franchise befall a similar fate.

This is a movie where the story aren't the strongest carrying the movie being the primary motor carrying the movie forward, but it's one of those movies where it's not the point of it. This is a movie for the fans, fans of Deadpool, fans of Marvel, and fans of the unmature humor we can enjoy without shame while watching the movie8/10 stars, it would have been a 10 if the story had been developed more seriously, but I didn't had any longing for it while watching it.It's funny, and more funny, silly and stupid the right way, and of course Deadpool's meta level makes it worth every dime.As someone said; it's easter egg galore, and couldn't be said more fitting :D.

Despite some strong actors and a little more than a half dozen genuinely funny jokes, 'Dead Pool & Wolverine' doesn't hold up to expectations.First, there is far too much emphasis on Ryan Reynolds. It seems like to makers of this film forgot that Dead Pool is the main character. Breaking of the fourth wall is used far too often, and more often than not it feels like Ryan Reynolds is speaking to the audience rather than Dead Pool.Second, there is far too much exposition. It rivals anime in the unnecessary or repetitive dialogue explaining things.Third, there is the inconsistent quality of CGI across the filmFinally, the jokes about Marvel and Disney not only undermine the suspension of disbelief the same way as Ryan Reynold references do, but they also go on too long. Well into the second act. This may have been meant to be satirical or "meta" but it ultimately makes for long boring stretches of the film.All in all, it's not as bad as Dead Pool 2 in some ways, but it is far worse in others. Hopefully this will be the last we see of Dead Pool in the MCU.

This film had to go through many problems to be made. Film studios, characters, actors, directors, scripts, but I'm very glad that it worked out in the end. Technically speaking, this is Deadpool 3. The film had strong marketing, a high budget, but it will also make money.The film gave me everything I expected, wanted and hoped for. I smiled on several occasions, laughed out loud, enjoyed the action. This is pure 100 percent fan film, fan service, there is no doubt about it. But we needed one successful superhero movie after several years of (mostly) big flops.Far from this being the best movie ever or anything like that, it won't even be the best movie of the year. We can talk about the action and the story, but that is unnecessary, that is not the point of the film. This is an action-packed summer blockbuster for fun and relaxation. Clearly, the film has several action scenes and very bloody ones (it justifies its R rating), but they are brilliantly filmed. Also, for me, the best part of the film is certainly the numerous cameo roles, references (Easter eggs) and mockery of anything and everything that is current now or has been in the last 20 years. That was exactly the point of the film.Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman are great in their roles and have great chemistry in their scenes together, which is almost the entire movie. We even got a little touch of movie nostalgia because the subgenre of duos who can't work together because they're different but have to, which was very popular 30-40 years ago, is practically extinct today (eg Lethal Weapon).The only thing I don't know is whether you will catch all the jokes, taunts and references because I have the feeling that there were about a hundred of them, without exaggeration.

Disney marvel movies always seem to struggle at finding the right balance between being entertaining and having a good story.It is clear from the opening act that D&W was made with the intent of entertaining the wider audience and providing great fan service to the more hardcore fans.However, this is no Deadpool 3... The events of first and second movie are largely ignored, due to a time skip. When we do hear about the aftermath of the second movie, it serves very little purpose. It feels as if there should have been a movie inbetween Deadpool 2 and D&W leading to the present events.The motivations also feel all over the place. Both Deadpool and Wolverine do not really go through much character development other than feeling a certain way to then feeling the opposite (very basic and there was never any depth to it). Any serious conversations that characters had lost a lot of emotion due to the fact you know it's building up to some sort of punchline.The movie is, extremely entertaining though. If you are prepared to leave your brain outside the theatre, unwind, and enjoy 2 hours of laughs and blood then you will have a really enjoyable time. The jokes hit, 80% of the time (which is a great ratio for MCU movies nowadays). The cameos are great, and the visuals and fight scenes are great too.Overall, this movie is a wholesome end to the Fox marvel universe.

The much-anticipated team-up of Deadpool and Wolverine unfortunately falls flat in this latest installment. The plot is a mess, feeling more like a lazy patchwork of ideas rather than a cohesive story. It lacked the sharpness and wit we've come to expect from both characters.One of the biggest issues was the overuse of jokes. While humor is a staple of Deadpool's character, this movie bombards the audience with too many gags, many of which simply don't land. The humor often feels forced, detracting from the overall experience.That said, there were still some funny moments that I enjoyed, showcasing the chemistry between Deadpool and Wolverine. However, these moments are few and far between, buried under an otherwise forgettable plot.In comparison to the previous movies, this is definitely the weakest. The film struggles to find its footing and fails to deliver the engaging narrative that fans hoped for. Overall, while it had some enjoyable parts, this movie is a disappointing addition to the franchise.

One of the most entertaining movies ive seen in a while. Deadpools vulgar and out of pocket humor Paris perfectly with a fed up grumpy deadpool. The comedy definitely stands a fair bit stronger than the action, which the movie is not hiding at all. Constant jokes, over the top violence and Breaking of the 4th wall really makes this movie worth watching.Its worth noting that this movie gravity relies on the viewer being caught up within the MCU. You really wont get the full experience without having watched, or at least have knowlage of the previous X-men movies (specifilly Logan), as well as the Marvel movies and series (mainly Loki).All in all Deadpool&Wolverine is a funny, actionpacked and awesome piece of fan service which surpasses any previous Marvel media all the way back to endgame.

It an epic masterpiece, all the movie is like a jaw drop.The story itself could be better that's why is not a 10.Seen Hugh Jackman again playing Wolverine is magnificent, no one can play Logan like he does.Ryan? I mean Ryan is so Deadpool coded (talking about humor), he's alway great.The jokes were actually pretty funny. I'm glad we have a Logan again.Paradox is also a good character, Matthew Mcfadyen has already prove he is a very good actor.An amazing casting with some of the most talented.The post credit was worth the wait.I'm glad they didn't use that much the multiverse, they just used when they needed it.It has Fan service which as a fan I liked cause it's not to excessive.I would have liked a better introduction for the Wolverine suit. But it was epic when he puts on the mask.Love it, worth the wait.

If there's a combo that could entertain us with a clich story and do justice to bringing back a legendary character, it has to be Shawn Levy and Ryan Reynolds.This has to be one of the most entertaining Marvel movies since EndgameRyan is one of the best actors of our generation with a great comic sense.Hugh Jackman exhibits sheer class that too while sharing screen space with an entertainer like Ryan, he shines and makes his mark.The writing has to be appreciated especially the dialogues are a major positive of the film. I just can't wait to watch it again.Marvel is so back. Hope they continue the streak

Was amazing with lots of humour. Deadpool and Wolverine, two of Marvel's most iconic characters, have captivated audiences for decades with their unique personalities and compelling stories. Their journey through comic books, movies, and other media has left an indelible mark on popular culture, and their impact is nothing short of amazing.Deadpool, also known as Wade Wilson, stands out as one of the most unconventional heroes in the Marvel Universe. Known for his sharp wit, irreverent humor, and breaking the fourth wall, Deadpool has redefined what it means to be a superhero. His self-aware commentary and unpredictable nature make him both endearing and entertaining. Deadpool's origin story, filled with dark humor and a mix of tragedy and comedy, highlights his resilience and unconventional heroism. His ability to heal rapidly and his penchant for chaotic antics set him apart from traditional heroes, making him a beloved character for those who enjoy a blend of action and comedy.On the other hand, Wolverine, or Logan, is a character who embodies raw strength, complexity, and grit. With his adamantium claws and healing factor, Wolverine is a formidable warrior, yet it is his internal struggles and moral ambiguity that make him truly compelling. His backstory, laden with loss, conflict, and an ever-present search for identity, adds depth to his character. Wolverine's journey from a weapon of destruction to a hero with a code of honor resonates with audiences on a profound level. His relentless pursuit of justice, coupled with his inner turmoil, creates a multi-dimensional character who is both powerful and vulnerable.Both characters have been brought to life on the big screen with remarkable success. Ryan Reynolds' portrayal of Deadpool is a testament to his ability to perfectly capture the character's eccentricity and humor. Reynolds' commitment to staying true to Deadpool's irreverent nature has earned widespread acclaim, making the character a standout in the realm of superhero films. The "Deadpool" movies broke the mold of traditional superhero films, incorporating a unique blend of comedy and action that appealed to a diverse audience.Hugh Jackman's portrayal of Wolverine is equally remarkable. Jackman's performance, spanning multiple films over nearly two decades, has set a high standard for portraying complex, layered characters. His portrayal of Wolverine's physicality, emotional depth, and conflicted nature has been widely praised, making him one of the most memorable characters in modern cinema. The "Logan" film, in particular, showcased a more vulnerable side of Wolverine, providing a poignant and fitting end to Jackman's portrayal of the character.The chemistry between Deadpool and Wolverine has also been a highlight for fans. Their interactions, characterized by a mix of tension, camaraderie, and humor, underscore the contrasts between their personalities while celebrating their shared heroism. Their dynamic adds an extra layer of enjoyment for fans who appreciate both characters' distinct approaches to heroism.In summary, Deadpool and Wolverine are remarkable not only for their superhuman abilities but also for their richly developed personalities and the unique ways they challenge conventional superhero tropes. Their portrayals in both comic books and films have captivated audiences, making them enduring symbols of complexity and entertainment in the superhero genre.
