The characters who actually working towards personal goals. Yes, it was personal for Deadpool up until the end. Then Marvel had to push their infamous "big cgi fight button" and everything suddenly was about cringy overused "the end of the world" stuff, thus, the film got worsened.Dear, god, Marvel really still baiting on fan-favourite cameos. Those are good to see in the articles/posts in FANDOM WEBSITES/BLOGS. Not in multimillion-dollar projects. Wake the f up.I haven't watched any Marvel thing after Guardians 3 but I think this is THE last Marvel product that I consumed. Perhaps I will catch on the certain films(I highly doubt) once they hit online but I don't think I wanna pay to get disappointed anymore.

This is by far the worst deapool movie, first one was excellent the balance between story, humour and sillyness was just right.2nd one wasnt so good but still enjoyable.But this one ,sigh, its just a series of jokes, like a stand up comedian, and most just don't land, way too many 4th wall breaks - that arent even funny. Story is pretty non existent, too many cameo's to list or even catch.To me it just seems like 2 hours of making jokes about disney and marvel, which the first couple were ok, shocking even, by the end it was just boring,no doubt there will be another given its current box office numbers, I hope it actually has a story!

Seriously, the sound mixing is terrible- the dialogue is about 1/8 the volume of the special effects cues- that I could feel in my balls. Save your money and watch it at home on video with the subtitles on, because I just paid $50 hard-earned green American dollars to have Charlie Brown's teacher withhold the plot from me until I was red-faced, vein-in-the-neck pissed off with the whole experience. I think I'm done with Marvel, and definitely done with the whole theatre-going experience. I was very much looking forward to this movie, but now that I've sat through it, I guess I'll have to deduce the plot via Youtube comment videos. I should have saved my money. This was the first Marvel movie I'd seen in the theatres since Iron Man 1, and I will NEVER pay for Marvel in the theatre again.

Now where to begin the film was funny that's what you'd expect from a deadpool film but she comedy was over done sometimes when I heard about deadpool and wolverine I was looking forward to it but now no way I think wolverine ruined this film this was probably the worse mulitverse film going they need to stop there was not much of a story either and BTW was that Wesley snipes as blade it sure sounded like him the fight scene's was really good and the bloody effects still don't know why they just didn't call the film deadpool 3 well don't no what else to say just got to keep typing until I've used the characters up lol.

To be fair, this movie was probably never going to completely work for me, as I am not a big fan of the other two Deadpool movies. But I went in open-minded, and the trailers they released were good trailers.Unfortunately, Deadpool & Wolverine doubles down on all things that makes me dislike both the MCU and other Deadpool movies. From the MCU, it has throw away, cardboard cutout villains, an awful and jumbled plot, and an absurd and borderline offensive amount of fan service. From the Deadpool films, it has very one-note "Can he say that???" type of humor.This movie pretends to be bold by having Deadpool bravely poke fun at Disney. But the jokes are ultimately very inoffensive to Disney, and obviously corporate approved. It has a scene where they make fun of the multiverse, and yet the whole plot revolves the multiverse, which is a total cop out.The villain is about as simple and boring as they get in the MCU. She's also weirdly overpowered, making me wonder why she didn't just snap her fingers, killing everyone. The plot mechanics are incredibly dull, and it relies way too heavily on fan service. Almost no jokes are told, just references that are lightly humorous. And the references and endless cameos really get old quick. They are there to manipulate viewers into focusing on nostalgia, so we forget that the script is absolutely awful and generic.Deadpool & Wolverine makes me extremely sad that we will no longer get any more films in the original X-Men canon. I now appreciate Logan and even The New Mutants all that much more. Because this really ain't it. RIP X-Men.

The anticipation of having Wolberine and Deadpool in one movie kick started the excitement when the movie started. But it turned out to a big disappointed.This movie is easily the worst I've seen this year, and I watch at least five movies a week. If you enjoy Ryan Reynolds delivering sarcastic, lame attempts at humor in response to every line from Wolverine and the other characters, alongside a weak script and boring action scenes, then this might be your kind of film. Personally, I couldn't stand the blasphemous remark of him calling himself Marvel Jesus. If a movie has to stoop that low to get a reaction, it's a sign that something is seriously wrong.Not worth the HYPE AT ALL. And am a big fan of their previous films.

This high rating shows that taste and appreciation for movie has dropped to a near idiotic level. This movie was hot garbage lol. Hugh Jackman was GREAT - hasn't lost a step but everything else SUCKED except for one GREAT, jaw dropping and totally unexpected cameo that made the movie for me. Ryan was annoying, and not funny at all. The formula was tired, the script was BARE bones thin... I really found this a waste of time. Just a bunch of LOUD, mindless violence. Not one single joke was funny - every joke was a homo-erotic joke and really immature at that. There's more bad than good here. I honestly feel jackman was wasted as was Monica. LAMO why was she even IN this movie - Wade's whole REASON for going on this adventure was ridiculous and that ending is probably the sloppiest writing I've seen in ages. It took 4 GUYS to write this mess?The ONLY thing enjoyable about this movie was the nods to fox's films and other older Marvel properties. I have no use for the MCU even though I've enjoyed some of the films - but I will always have time to rewatch the x-men series and this movie proved WHICH was the 'better' universe, sorry MCU.

Not very often a movie comes across that is so selfabsord that it actually tells you that it is too. Ryan Reynolds succeeds most behind a mask, whether that be the thin veneer of his personality or the depth of the characters he performs.Success has followed him and Hugh Jackmans return for Logan a clever pairing of essentially two immortals, becomes as repetitive as a Ryan Reynolds monologue.After 20min the movie is a long repeat of the same action, the same one liners and the same dead pool of writing.It's no wonder they are promoting this movie everywhere, because any pause to reflect and Marvel at what they've made and they might just realise it's crap.

You take an entire Series of excellent Marvel Universe Films (a Single Iron Man film earns the studio $1B), plus all the decades of "comic books", mash them all together, hose them down, then pass them through a leaf shredder; then write a script from that mess that only "Gen Z" (and maybe a very few 5th-graders) can make sense of; then pass this through movie theaters and call it entertainment? Really? ... NOT!!!!Marvel itself spent the last few years killing off nearly all of the Original Avengers and X-Men because they wanted to be 'stylish' -- and we end up with this tripe!They killed Iron Man. His movies merely earned the Studio billions.They kind-of turned Thor into a fatso with a beer belly, then into a girl.Then they took the Hulk from a raging unstoppable wrecking crew, and turned him into an effeminate combination of The Hulk & Dr. Banner.They killed off Captain America by turning him into an old man. Then all of a sudden Cap passes his Shield to another guy -- as if that's where his power came from!Then they killed off Scarlett Johansen completely to the consternation of every girlwatcher out there. Those guys need to await Gal Godot's next Wonder Woman film!So, the Studios, collectively, take all of their really big-buck earners, and just kill them all off -- really smart idea, there, Studio-Guys! Did you all flunk grade school too?Although, it's a different story if the actors no longer wanted to play those parts. I heard Ms. Johanson say: (after some on-set horseply) "See, this is what it's like working with these guys for 12 years!".But then we're left with films like this? Really? This is all you've got? Studio guys need to all be fired, then have them try to sell peanuts or pencils on the street.I gave the film five stars mostly for Hugh Jackman's performance.

Really? I think fox, marvel, dc, Disney etc. All are old hat. To make this kind of movies should STOP in this point. I think the best Wolverine was Logan. Deadpool 1 and 2 was also good but this...come on. All movie was a big green screen just like the other DC, marvel movies. Also these actors/actresses did much better in other movies. I think it is just a simple B-C category movie, overrated and over hyped. I did not like, never happened with me before but I thought I will leave the cinema in the middle of this movie. I hope nobody will continue this multiverse timeline never again in any movie.

The first Deadpool was... interesting....but I just couldn't get past the comic bloodshed and violence. It's so unnecessary....it tries to desensitize people and you have the same blood and gore in today's video games....it totally turned me off, because the entire movie is filled with it. I gave it a chance.... Hugh Jackman was the best redeeming character in the whole movie. Because he wasn't a smarta** and was a grounded character. Ryan Reynolds..eh...some of the jokes were ok.... I know that's his character but really...he doesn't do anything different in this movie that he hasn't done in the last 2. Sorry,

Pretty boring story really didn't enjoy it I do not know what the hype is about bad story bad visual effects unnecessarily long and boring fights and not nearly as funny as part one or two were do not get ur hopes up thinking this is gonna be good that's what I did and I ended up very disappointed do not recommend. I think the end was interesting and there were some parts where I wasn't being bored to a crazy level this does not change the fact that I do not understand how it is possible for this to have that good reviews go watch any other marvel movie and u will more satisfied than this is will make u.

Obviously the grudge that has been made clear throughout the Deadpool series is he doesn't like Wolverine. Well Obviously!? This film is basically a way for Marvel and Reynolds to make more money out of a pretty dry pool, Hence all the cameos from actors needing a buck. Film is flimsey, violence at beginning not really needed and too long, actually way to long like the fight scenes with the Wolverine. I can see why they made the film it's in the title! But if you haven't watched Loki, Marvel why did those time travellers turn up. If u don't watch the M. Universe this film won't work. Hopefully no more now?

How this movie was made: @Disney HQ: what cow are we milking today? Deadpool? Ok, ask our Guy in the home for delinquent youth to have them write the screenplay. And they would, and cheaper!Normally there are filler episodes in a series when the money ran out. But why o why make a filler movie? And then spend an insane amount of money to have all actors fight each other. Because it would look silly to have them sit around?Why would an immortal go fight other immortals? Because Pain is Fun? Says who?In Loki there were some good episodes, a few... This movie however recycled some of the most boring parts near the end where they got stuck in the mess they created. In fact Loki was often so bad I left my house in the absence of a movie theatre to walk out of. (I'm back.) Another thingy; it's possible to have the actors protest against the Multiverse madness, but not in a movie that is so uninspired that they need several universe to gather crumbs in, to put a trail to the end credits. Moldy crumbs like an ugly dog, or the stupidest mask in the history of super Heroes? Oh its on purpose?Hugh Jackman should play Dirty Harry, not ruin a Deadpool film. Wolverine please leave the scene.... The whole movie is a mix of watching a VHS of an old birthday party, and a bunch of ten years old kids who just saw king Kong, running around and following suit in behaving like monkeys. And some deranged adults who just saw a slasher movie slashing each other with real knives. Such Fun... No, ultra violence is not funny! No, foul language isn't either. Unless it serves a purpose. When did Disney hire these bloodthirsty scumbags? Why? There are plenty of boring movies everywhere. STOP WRITING BAD SCENARIOS, use books! They are already written, they are great and many and gathering dust.

I am writing to express my dissatisfaction with the recent Marvel movie, which I believe falls far short of the high standards we have come to expect from Marvel Studios. As a long-time fan of the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU), I feel compelled to share my thoughts on the direction in which the franchise appears to be heading. First and foremost, I must address the issue of the overwhelmingly positive ratings this movie has received. It seems to me that many of these ratings are likely paid promotions rather than genuine audience feedback. In my honest opinion, this movie does not deserve the praise it is getting. A more accurate rating would be one star, reflecting the lackluster quality of the film. The plot was uninspired, the character development was shallow, and the overall experience was disappointing. It is disheartening to see a beloved franchise like Marvel producing content that feels more like a cash grab than a labor of love. Marvel, once known for its captivating storytelling and complex characters, seems to be losing its touch. The latest movie is a far cry from the earlier MCU films that captured the imagination of audiences worldwide. It appears that Marvel is now churning out movies with back-to-back subpar stories, relying heavily on the brand's name rather than delivering quality content. The unique charm and creativity that used to define Marvel movies are becoming increasingly rare, replaced by formulaic plots and predictable narratives. In this particular film, I found the storyline to be weak and unengaging. The characters, once richly developed and multi-dimensional, felt flat and one-dimensional. There was a noticeable lack of effort in the writing, with dialogue that was often clichd and uninspired. The visual effects, while technically impressive, could not compensate for the lack of a compelling story. As a fan, it is disappointing to see Marvel, a studio that has set such high standards in the past, produce a movie that feels so devoid of creativity and innovation. Furthermore, it seems that Marvel is prioritizing quantity over quality. The rapid release of movies with little regard for storytelling and character development is concerning. This approach not only dilutes the brand but also risks alienating long-time fans who have supported the MCU from the beginning. Marvel's strength has always been its ability to balance epic action with deep, emotional storytelling. Unfortunately, this balance seems to be slipping away in favor of flashy visuals and superficial plots. For those considering watching this movie, I would advise caution. If you have a lot of money and time to spare, you might still find some entertainment value in it. However, for those who appreciate thoughtful storytelling and well-developed characters, this movie may be a disappointment. It is a shame to see Marvel, once a powerhouse of creativity and innovation, resort to such uninspired content. In conclusion, I believe that Marvel needs to take a step back and reevaluate its approach. The studio must return to its roots and focus on delivering compelling stories with well-developed characters. It is not enough to rely on brand recognition and special effects; the heart of Marvel's success has always been its storytelling. As a fan, I hope to see Marvel regain its former glory and continue to produce movies that captivate and inspire audiences around the world. Thank you for taking the time to read my thoughts. I hope that my feedback can contribute to a constructive conversation about the future of the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

The movie was disappointing and of low quality. It's difficult for me to understand how the demands of the younger generation have shifted so drastically. The film lacked a coherent story, meaningful message, or purpose. It seems to cater to a generation raised on unrealistic expectations, driven by video games, superpowers, and violence.I'm not suggesting that the past was inherently better-every era has its own strengths and weaknesses. However, it's concerning to see how this generation seems disconnected from reality, growing up with diminished values, less education, and a greater tolerance for violence. Perhaps we, as a society, are partly to blame for this shift.I can't help but worry about the future. Will the next generation be even more immersed in violence and fantasy, abandoning education altogether? In a world where books have been replaced by movies, it's crucial that films guide the younger generation toward a better future, rather than simply offering mindless entertainment filled with violence.

I rarely write a review but after I saw this movie I felt I have to do that.I love the Marvel Universe and movies like X-Men, Logan and also Deadpool but this hybrid version is very bad. I am ashamed if this is the niveau of our age. Also the music just makes the film ridiculous. The movie has so much potential but godless jokes ruins it. Did this movie have a deep plot, no. Did it have lots of funny jokes, action and a seemingly fun adventure, yes. This movie was funny. It was fun to see Deadpool on screen with Wolverine. Hugh Jackman is an amazing actor and has done a ton of movies. He is allowed to play a character without much substance, even if it is Wolverine.The only thing I will say critical is that Disney should look at movies like "Men in Black". It's a movie that gets away with being adult toned but also teen friendly. It tells a clear and concise story without all the glitz and glam. I think movies today rely too much on visuals, familiar faces, and how much they cram into a movie in the time allotted (thus neglecting a clear plot). Other than that Deadpool and Wolverine was a good movie. I will watch it again.

Marvel needs scripts to support their superheroes appeal. Scenarios and clever ones actually are difficult to get nowadays, so in this film you get an unlimited flow of bad mouth, endless ranting and bubbling, boring fight scenes "spiced" by dirty stupid humor.I really feel bad for those talented actors and actresses involved. They show as they are having fun but actually they opress their art. This is not acting. This is something really offensive to anyone who wants to call themselves an actors.Finally this film really offends the sense of humor and the basic sensibilites of all people.. This is BEYOND pathetic and insulting to all viewers.

Now that I have come to terms with and am less annoyed by Ryan Reynolds' whole Ace-Ventura-Lite-with-abs persona, I was able to enjoy some pretty hilarious dance routines and nicely timed line deliveries, and quite frankly some pretty great visual presentations, my favourite being the villain's robot skull lair.Emma Corrin gives an impressively cold turn as the quite well conceived evil foe.The problem with this film is that you think you're getting a separate entity from the usual MCU, with its endless boring, excessively complicated expositional lore jargon and drawn out dramatic monologues, and tendency to switch between outright slapstick to stark stare into the distance teary misery... So, parts of this film are like a nuclear hit of caffeine, then others are like a tranquilizer dart that could take down an angry lion.

I went to this movie on the basis of some good reviews and the enthusiasm of my Son who I went with. It was mostly a young audience and it seemed to be well received or at least got a number of laughs or chuckles. I didn't want to give it a 'god-awful' 1 or 2 rating as the film had some good actors and was a piece of work to make no doubt.BUT, endless killing, even though 'artistically' staged and part of movie phantasy, was too much for me. I think it desensitizes people to violence. Moreover, the story line was implausible, not that Marvel cares much about that. Also, tiresome, the constant use of the "F" word was tiresome.Lastly, the director and writers didn't seem to know how to end this sorry spectacle. I kept thinking the movie was over and was ready to bolt out of there, but then another scene would get tacked on and then another. My take on this film may reflect my age and the fact that I've seen many great movies in the 70's and beyond. A Samurai film has some intense fights but they are more often integral to a good story and, done well, are amazing to watch.

After seeing the high rating I was very disappointed by this. I love the first 2 as they are top notch so I was expecting far better story line but it was like they spent all the budget on the cameos. Massive shame really. I chuckled 2 during the film. Gutted I paid to go the the cinema to watch it.my wife also felt the same about the movie.personally.On the bright side the effects were very good and it was nice to see a tribute to fox and they journey with marvel during the credits but that was the best bit of the film.One thing I know for sure is that I won't bother watching it again. X.

If this was a glorified 60' TV special, it might 've been something, but as a 200 mill. Movie it's a mediocre (at best) film with no story and one or two good moments, but nowhere near as charming as the previous two entries. At least the previous two had some style, heart and especially the second had some good cinematography, but this is just bad. Honestly, I didn't expect more from director of Free Guy. Only Hugh Jackman brings his A-game and it's just sad to see him dragged into this only to see him in the yellow suit. I guess, if you are a moron who likes to clap in a movie theater this movie is for you. You'll get to clap and say "I know this" a lot.I like fun and chill movies and I don't expect every comic book movie to The Dark Knight or Logan, but I expect it to be at least decent and enjoyable. The opening credits are my favorite part but after that I was mostly bored with a few chuckles here and there. This not a theater experience, this is an "I'll watch it on my phone" experience. If you saw the leaks on the internet then congratulations, that's the "best" the movie has to offer. But, hey, if you love this movie, congratulations! It has already made tons of money and I'm sure the studio won't understand the wrong message and make more of this cheap crap... And people get angry at Scorsese for spitting facts. This truly is Disneyland, in the sense that you'll see many people cosplaying as characters you like but without substance.

Out of 2 hours 10 mins , 1 hour 20 mins is stand up comedy form Ryan aka dead pool . Keeps on speaking throughout the movie . Worst part of deadpool series .Very less action sequences, no story , nothing . Wolverine's part is superb . To many heroes shown in the movie without any specific reason . Past heroes from old movies . Don't know what marvel is trying to do form adding all the old past movie heroes . Really boring and too long movie , very talkative . Don't waste money in theatres , instead watch it when it comes on Netflix or some application . Save your money from This talk comedy show .

If you're wondering what this movie is like, then just imagine it in your head. Think of Deadpool 1 and 2, then close your eyes, imagine a scene that has violence, gore, and taboo humour that would make any 13-year-old boy laugh... then do that for 2 hours straight, and you've got yourself Deadpool & Wolverine. Oh, and cameos... you need cameos. Thank God that Ryan and Hugh have saved a dying Marvel franchise and Disney's integrity through unoriginal scripting, predictable scenes, and more villain foes who seem to experience a drop of roughly 60 IQ in the last fight scene. Well, at least the franchise died on its sword. There's integrity in that.

I went in with a lot of expectations from. The movie. Apart from few moments here and there the movie is just a soul less script riding on nostalgia. Deadpool breaking the 4th wall feels forced here and most of all Hugh Jackman looks stiff as hell. I thought the chemistry would work but sadly it doesn't. When you go in for a deadpool movie you expect a laugh riot but here the scenes were appearing forced. The villains had weak motives and the cameos felt out of place. Compare it to the first movie and it doesn't hold a candle. Ryan needs to step up his game with the franchise. Still the movie is much better to the last few MCU movies.

I must confess a fondness for the first two Deadpool instalments. They were, undeniably, a breath of fresh air in the superhero genre. However, this latest offering is a perplexing departure from the formula.The crux of the issue lies in Deadpool himself. The character, once a complex anti-hero grappling with mortality and loss, has been reduced to a grating caricature. His incessant chatter, while previously endearing, now feels like a relentless assault on the senses. The Wolverine character, too, is a shadow of his former self. His transformation from brooding anti-hero to reluctant sidekick is jarring and unexplained.The plot is a haphazard concoction of tired tropes and forced humour. The villain, Cassandra, is a one-dimensional antagonist whose motivations are as clear as mud. The constant barrage of self-referential jokes and product placements feels more like a desperate attempt to fill screen time than genuine wit. The multiverse concept, once a promising avenue for exploration, is squandered on predictable twists and turns.The film's saving graces are few and far between. The cameos are enjoyable, and the canine companion offers a welcome moment of respite. Yet, these are mere distractions from the film's fundamental flaws. The action sequences, typically a Marvel strong point, are lacklustre and repetitive. The overall tone is jarringly inconsistent, veering wildly between juvenile humour and attempted seriousness.In conclusion, "Deadpool & Wolverine" is a disappointing misfire. It squanders the potential of its beloved characters, offering little in the way of compelling narrative or character development. The film's reliance on cheap laughs and forced cameos is a disservice to the franchise. It's a film that promises much but delivers little, leaving one to wonder what might have been.

"Deadpool and Wolverine" is an absolute disaster from start to finish. This film had no potential from the get-go, and it shows in every painful minute. It's a meaningless, hollow attempt at entertainment that completely misses the mark. The plot is non-existent, the characters are lifeless, and the humor is painfully unfunny. There's no redeeming quality to be found here-it's a waste of time, money, and even the talent involved. This movie offers nothing of value and isn't worth a second of your attention. Heed this warning. Please, please heed this warning. It is AWFUL. You should be paid to watch this film. It should be a form of punishment in fact.

This film is nothing more than a pitiful attempt at a super hero film designed to inflate Ryan Reynolds ego even more.I am not a prude but the excessive profanity level and the graphic violence are a little over the top for a so called Marvel film.There is no real plot, the storyline is weak and predictable and the repeated Deadpool, sorry Ryan Reynolds, monologues to camera are boring and tedious.I'm really surprised Hugh Jacman went for this one - anything you can do, I can swear more.Cassandra was actually a breath of fresh air, but of course you can't have anyone outshining Ryan, shame.Abysmal.

I have watched all 3 Deadpool movies and i think this is a very bad movie, worst of all. The hype before i watch the movie is all lost. Maybe i have too much expectations.There is no buildup story of the villain, no background story of those heroes appear to help deadpool. The ending is lazy. D&W manage to beat the strongest villain they have faced on second meetings. The writer can at least make it more believable. The villain is boring and loses to D&W so easily. The jokes are try hard. This movie is created for the sake of reunion (or for the bosses to milk more money out of this series).It is not a movie that can stand on its own, possibly can be skipped.

This movie needs alot work on it. This deadpool sucked only thing I seen theat I like in this movie is the comedy parts other then that the movie pits people asleep because how boring the movie is. Because the other deadpools were more action and less boring and even had a better story line to go by besides this movie does. So I believe they need to take this movie off and reduce the movie so it would be a better fit deadpool movie besides of a rainbow Brite movie. This movies is to lame and don't keep people on there edge of there seats like the other action pack deadpool movies did in the past now deadpool ia more rate PG wanting to be movie.

Don't waste two hours of your life with this movie.There are no deadpool jokes for much of the movie and all is left is gratuitious violence, forced dialogs that don't flow, a soup of heroes, too many cross references that are superhero specific and required to understand the movie instead of general culture to make the movie light and fun.This movie left me with a complete sense of regret and disapointment. I guess that all the media is bought because the people are going en masse, unalerted of how bad this movie is.So I'm doing this for you now: Don't go and watch this, it does not live up to previous Deadpool movies.

This review comes from someone who is admittedly not a religious follower of the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Still, I decided to watch this film because I knew Deadpool was the quirky anti-hero, and that Hugh Jackman did a good Wolverine. I wasn't expecting much going into this movie, but even so I was disapointed.First of all I just did not not connect with any of the characters. All of Deadpool's friends seem to harken back to previous installments that I did not watch.It felt like the two protagonists nothing at steak either. Sure the their home universe was being unraveled or whatever, but because there was a multiverse, they could just go to a new one.Deadpool is invincible and Wolverine is regenerative. They had some clashes with eachother, but it was always obvious that they would come out OK.The story was a mess. It just felt all over the place. I think the multiverse setting is really getting tired in these Marvel movies (and Deadpool even jokes about it in this movie too). After Deadpool found a cooperative version of Wolverine, I didn't really understand why he had to go to the void and team of with some of the superhero has-beens.And even the actions scenes, which one would expect to be bombastic in a superhero movie, felt a bit uninspired. There were a few too many instances of impaling or otherwise injuring somebody's genitals for it to remain funny for me. On the topic of the movie's humour, I thought it was cringey. I get that the writers are trying to portray Deadpool as an edgy character with his explicit humour, but it wore thin on me. With every new quip about cocaine or homosexual acts, they became less shocking.Overall I didn't think this movie had any redeeming qualities. Even adamantium Wolverine seemed weak and cripled by alcohol addiction. The overreliance on cameos in this movie had me feeling completely lost at times. I would not recommend this movie to anyone.

This movie was so bad I went out of my way to write a 600 word essay why it sucks soooo much. This movie is Marvel trying to be original and "creative" and falling so badly on their face it's just embarrassing. I think this is the first time I've actually fallen asleep in a movie theater, napping for around 20 minutes. I was so disappointed I couldn't sleep for longer. Plot is flat and "sucked from the fingers" as we say in my country. There's just nothing of substance there. One of my smaller gripes is that the movie went out of its way to destroy one of my favorite movie characters - Blade. Don't waste 3 hours of your time and your money - just skip this movie.

For those who consider themselves responsible adults and decent parents:I made a mistake of taking two teenager Marvel fans to see this movie. I heard it was very successful at the box office. I am not an MCU expert by any means. With my level of Marvel expertise, I can say that the first Iron Man with Robert Downey Jr. And Gwyneth Paltrow was a nice movie.This movie, on the other hand, was not just bad. It was shockingly bad. No character development. No plot development. What you get is the endless and pointless in-jokes for the sake of filling up time, lots of F-Bombs and blood and gore that doesn't serve any purpose.An hour into the movie, I realized that nothing was happening in terms of the plot. I would have left the movie theater if it weren't for the boys watching.Then I saw these fighting scenes between the Wolverine and Deadpool and the one with many Deadpools and I thought that this movie is celebrating blood and gore for no reason. There is violence for the sake of violence that doesn't serve any particular purpose of the genre.As I watched these drawn-out scenes, I paid attention to the public reaction in the movie theater. While some claim that this was humor, you wouldn't hear anybody laughing during those scenes.This movie is an example of what's wrong with our culture in the recent years. We give movies R rating for the curse words and glorify violence. There are movies that tell a compelling story where violence is part of it. This one - it's a celebration of violence for no good reason. If you took the blood and gore away and cut the movie down in length by 50-75%, you would still walk away with the same essential understanding of a dumbed-down overly simplistic plot.I asked the boys what they liked about the movie when the ordeal was over. They knew about Marvel movies a lot more than I did. They referred to the in-jokes. So, really, are you prepared to sit for 2 hours watching a movie where nothing is happening in terms of plot twists and just listen to the in-jokes?Please give me back the 2 hours of my life.I am deeply disappointed that this tasteless parody of a film could be so successful at the box office. If this is the epitome of all the comic-book character movie-making, if this is where the evolution has taken us, then it's a really sad world we live in.Remember the movie called Idiocracy? Well, in some ways, we are past that level of hopelessness.

Hugh Jackman just ruined his Wolverine legacy all because Reynold's ego needed to ride on an actual actor's laurels.A bunch of characters who just regenerate when they get hurt equals no suspense or concern for anyone -- you might as well just play a video game.I would give Reynolds kudos for recycling if it pertained to refuse and not the jokes in this film -- but it does champion the phrase 'there is nothing new under the sun'.In summation, this film was Reynolds just mugging for the camera and silently but very obviously shouting, look at me! Look at me! As for Jackman, I'm guessing the size of the money truck they drove up to his house paid for a renovation and then some.Horrible.

After watching this, I don't think this movie has what it takes to save the MCU. It was actually surprisingly disappointing, and this is coming from someone who actually liked Deadpool 1 and 2, with 1 being the best to me.The movie lacks good pacing. I constantly got bored because the movie was all over the place. I kept wanting to look at my phone. This movie seems to care more about fanservice and cameos rather than telling an actual good cohesive narrative. As a result, this movie lacks the heart of Deadpool 1 and 2, especially 1. Deadpool 1 narrative was actually surprisingly good and well paced, and it actually knew how to be serious and emotional when it needed to be serious and emotional. I lowkey got a little choked up from the rain scene where Deadpool was hesitant to show his new face to his girlfriend for the first time but couldn't do it. But as for Deadpool and Wolverine? Just too much cringe jokes and bad chaotic pacing for me to take any the small "serious" scenes serious. This barely feels like an actual movie to me, feels like a bunch of skits loosely put together for a movie. Maybe I'm old-school, but extreme fanservice, constant nods, and cameos were not enough to please me. I need an actual well-structured story with good pacing.So does the comedy itself enough to make up for the lack of story and pacing? Not really! The comedy fell flat for me for the most part. Deadpool 1 and 2 were much funnier. Sorry, but I found most the jokes just cringe or corny. My theatre was mostly silent. There was a few actual funny moments, but it wasn't nearly enough overall.The action was just okay! There was no real stand-out fight scenes. The action was EXTREMELY CGI heavy and just didn't look that great. Deadpool 1 looked SO MUCH BETTER! Deadpool 1 had shocking low CGI for a modern superhero movie now that I think about it, and it looked amazing.I really wanted to like this movie but sorry I gotta be honest. I highly doubt this is quality enough to save the MCU, it's one of those movies everyone will forget in a month or so. This movie NEEDED A LOT of work! I should've known, since third movies are very rarely good. I really think it's time to drop this tired multi-verse nonsense.Deadpool OG was like a surprisingly good romantic comedy disguised as a superhero action movie. Deadpool 2 was just classic action Deadpool. Deadpool 3 was just fanservice above everything.My ratings for all Deadpool moviesDeadpool- 9/10 Deadpool 2- 8/10 Deadpool 3- 4/10.

I'm still wondering what I've watched? I certainly lost 2 hours of my life watching the weakest plot I've seen in my entire life. There's no substance, no stakes, no drama, just jokes (repetitive and boring at some point), fan services, and useless cameos. They erased everything good in the first 2 Deadpool movies bring in Wolverine and throw up a clueless plot with a massive PR, ads to please some fans, nothing else.This is a pure MCU/Multiverse era, the worst one, they managed to do worst than Eternals and Ant-man Quantumania. I'm certainly a minority here, but I refuse to be treated as stupid fan ready to accept and watch any garbage as long as it's " fan services ".RIP MCU.

This movie is so full of filth and foul language that it cannot be enjoyed. The plot is typical of Dead Pool. His movies were some of the worst every put out, I could not watch them either! When Marvel came out with Wolverine it was actually child friendly, Family Friendly and could be one of the movies that are enjoyed by all age groups. I find myself watching them over and over again. Deadpool is a very bad movies. I you are a movie lover, you Will fall in sleep with this movie. All these comments on these reviews are not correct. The graphics and action scnes is excellent. But that is only the positive you can say about thuis movie. People wake up and be realistic about thuis movie. There are movies that be better and relaesed this summer. The actors having trying to do a good job, but the moviewriters wrote bad humor and a stupid story.I hope that Marvel learn about this bad movie, and try to do better next time, and also with a better story and also for not marvelfans.

I loved all the actors, and their performances were excellent as expected. Plus the show had some really great one liners! Like one in the beginning when Deadpool said there are 206 bones in the human body, 207 when watching Polly Ann." It was funny but the audience expects more. As for profanity some was o.k. And appropriate for the situation, but most seemed gratuitous and almost like filler. However, all this aside the whole move seemed like an " exercise in ADHD cinema". Nope, I'm done with anything Marvel. The franchise has evolved into an effort to rehash old characters with unnecessary dialogue, swearing, ridiculous storylines to grab a few dollars from the ADHD crowd.

I love the Deadpool and X Men movies and was really looking forward to this, but I was disappointed. Just far too many gags. Sometimes less is more. The Merc with the mouth's gags in the Deadpool movies hit the spot, but Logan is a serious, dark, angry and moody character and comedy and gags don't suit a movie with Wolverine. There are a stack or cameos with a few that really surprised me. Cassandra Nova is a great protaganist, but it was all a bit too much Mad Maxy for me. I am sure many purists will like the homages paid and I am sure it will sail past a billion dollars, but I can't help thinking it was a missed opportunity. Both the stars play with gusto and it's great to see Jackman back doing what he does best, but it doesn't save the movie for me and I'm gutted about it.

What's with all these multiverse stories? As soon as they resort to multiple universes it no longer feels like anything matters. Nothing is final.When two immortal characters fight over nothing when they can't be hurt. It means nothing. And repeating it certainly doesn't help.The acting was good, and I really enjoyed seeing Wolverine again, but the story was lame.I'm not sure if it was just in my theatre, but the volume range was way too high. The dialog was typical movie volume, but as soon as a song played it literally was twice as loud. Ear splitting. I could see about a third of the audience cover their ears.

Deadpool and wolverine together looked like a forced mashup, the story line was weak and the movie had too many characters to do justice to them. This movie needed a good trimming, but i guess there wont be enough left to sell it in theatres then.Deadpools' lines were great as always, they were really well thought out and funny.Wolverine wasn't given enough space to do anything, it projects a forced undertone.MCU really need a visionary leader to trim it's work, it has the good stuff but the mixed stuff leaves a bad taste in mouth.This was the first MCU movie in which i didn't stayed for the post credit scene.Stan Lee's work is being missed.

I LOVED the first Deadpool movie and although the second movie wasn't quite as good as the first it was a definitely decent sequel, so I was really excited to watch this one. Sadly it was a massive let down. The movie without giving away any storyline (well to be fair, there isn't much of a storyline anyway), is really just a couple of hours of cheap cameos and jokes about movies. There are a few funny moments but it overall just didn't have the same originality as the first two. I was bored and yawning before the halfway mark which says a lot. It is such a shame as it had potential but I wouldn't recommend.

I love most of the Marvel characters. I didn't know about Deadpool so I had no clue. So when it named it Deadpool Wolverine I thought it was some kind of episode of wolverine. I'm a Spider-Man fan the Fantastic Four all those guys. I was really disappointed when I went to go see this the language the seem to be getting in all the liberal catches putting Fox down it's not my cup of tea. So as needless to say I will not be seeing another Deadpool I couldn't stand the afford every other word and he had his own family in there and I'm sure they got to watch it. I just didn't bring up my family and I was in brought up with all that. Again I'm more of the Spider-Man had a story there's a point to the movie is a good guy and a bad guy and there is some rhyme and reason I almost fell asleep and I never fall asleep at Movies my friend who is a little more open-minded she almost fell asleep twice during this movie so they really like it or you really don't. From those of you that are old school I don't recommend it.

Why all the gay sex humor? Especially since that population is so very small in the real world. (Unless there's an agenda to spread chaos and confusion to a population of unborn living, living dead?) I wasn't laughing and neither was my 14 year old son. Both of us found it to be repulsive. I understand my triggers very well and the propagandized programming directed towards the unwitting m-asses in this movie was pretty cringe. I'm a single mother raising an emotionally and spiritually STRONG man that knows thy self and SELF. Anyways, I'm not a fan of the Marvel movies. True art has higher dimensions of meaning like HBO's West World Series, Free Guy, the Matrix, the Leftovers... There was zero dimension of higher meaning in Deadpool & Wolverine.

In Marvel's world without consequences and a plethora of superheroes who die or live by the directors whim it was not surprising that wolverine will be back in some form despite his convincing death in Logan. This is exactly the reason why the audience gets superhero fatigue because this is world where your actions have no consequence and people can be brought back to life because the prepubescent western audience shed a tear for their much beloved hero. Ryan as deadpool is sublime as always and sometime you wonder if it is Ryan or deadpool behind the mask and Logan looks and acts the part but the problem lies in the story which is just another pathetic cash grab on a largely prepubescent minded audience. The jokes work but the story plods along and there is little to look forward to except when these two cool actors say their lines. Not recommended and the tedious story will make you want to leave but hey you paid for the ticket so you would rather suffer through the mind numbing storyline. No no and no. Marvel should stop bringing superheroes back to life just for a cash grab!

I love Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman, and I love the other two Deadpool movies a lot. I was so looking forward to this movie. For me it was impossible to be interested in the plot of the movie because there were too many 4th wall breaks, and it was too foolish (like floating skull Deadpool.)They lost what made the other Deadpool movies so great. Almost everything Deadpool said was a 4th wall break. It's like he isn't even in the movie, so you aren't invested in anything he does. The plot that is there is so weak that it seems like an afterthought. Worth a watch for the few good scenes in it, but don't go expecting a real movie/plot.

I feel like I'm in the minority here, but I have to admit that I didn't like the film.If "Logan" was a gala farewell, "Deadpool and Wolverine" would be the post-credits party that no one asked for. You know that moment when you're already in your pajamas, ready to go to bed, but everyone decides that the night isn't over yet? Well, that's what happened to our favorite wolverine. "Logan" gave us an epic conclusion, where we saw our hero take his last breath and the surviving mutants finally escape to freedom. A dignified, emotional and final farewell.Then, out of nowhere, they decided to bring back Wolverine, like that friend who comes back from an exchange trip with a suitcase full of useless trinkets. No need, guys, really. And to make matters worse, these Time Guardians - who are actually more annoying than that bald villan - stayed there, interfering in everything, trying to keep the timeline in place, trying to resurrect what was already dead and done. Their attempt to keep the universe alive felt like trying to inflate a balloon that's already popped-unnecessary and doomed to fail. It's kind of ridiculous, honestly. Result? The film experience went down the drain. Who wants to see Wolverine deal with temporal bureaucracy? Tell me! It's almost as if they took the perfect ending of "Logan" and decided to edit it, like that uncle who always thinks he can improve his grandmother's recipe and only manages to ruin the dish.The film's story was weak overall. Weak villan as well.Anyways, i am just going to delete this from my mind.

The movie seems like a movie that just needed to be made in order to bring Marvel back on track after Endgame. But the result is disappointing. Deadpool was finer on his own and perhaps better off with another movie including him properly in the MCU. This movie takes excuse on the multiverse and creates a mixup of whatever, whenever, wherever. As long as we team up Deadpool with Wolverine to make some money. Lacks a meaningful plot (Deadpool-wise). Constantly shoring pun's about MCU Disney Fox etc. Bringing forgotten characters back to life for no reason at all. What's the point? The movie shows the desperation that Marvel has fallen into after climaxing with Endgame. Better leave Deadpool alone.

The storyline was so uninspired that my boyfriend, a die-hard Deadpool fan, fell asleep through 80% of the film. Despite the attempt at humor, the jokes were predictable and failed to deliver any real laughs. This movie stands out as one of the worst superhero films I've ever encountered, making it a regrettable use of 2 hours and 27 minutes, not to mention the $30 ticket price. The high IMDb ratings are baffling and make me question whether they reflect genuine quality or are skewed by fan enthusiasm. As a dedicated X-Men fan, it's deeply disappointing to see such a beloved franchise return to the big screen in such a lackluster and underwhelming fashion. If you're expecting a film that honors the legacy of the X-Men or delivers a compelling superhero experience, I'd strongly advise tempering your expectations.

Good old Walt Disney would not survive if he were around today. He built Disney and the Disney name to have value when it comes to the family. In 1984 when Disney launched Touchstone Pictures to release the Tom Hanks film Splash, they didn't want to release it under the Disney heading because it had nudity and some foul language. After that there were a string of R rated films. Sure Deadpool is an R rated character that did well under Fox, but would Walt approve of this film, who knows. Now don't get me wrong, I already knew what this was all about as I had seen the first two films as well. I honestly thought they were okay, and I knew what this was going to be too. But when I see children in the audience, because it's Marvel, and I don't see any care for what we used to call morales, it makes me sad. And yes that is where I put poor Walt, because the Morales of his studio has went down too. If you enjoy the film that's fine, everyone has an opinion, this just happened to be mine.

Dear reader,This movie is another cash cow for Disney. If you would like to waste time, please watch this movie. The jokes have been all the same throughout the franchise, it is boring.Also, who is this Blake? I do not know this Blake in the Deadpool franchise, am I missing something? I get that she is his wife, but I do not understand what she has to do with the movie? All the references to Disney, Fox, whatever & all the unnecessary cameos make no sense and only pollute the storyline.Further, I liked the X-men from Sony. At least, they could finish a trilogy without any mentioning of the real world and stick to the story. I really do not understand why there has to be a rivalry & all the random disses.Disney, can we focus on making great movies again and not this abomination of distaste?Finally, I would like to add, there were some funny moments and the costumes looked great.Sincerely,Someone who appreciates an unique storyline.Ps. Ryan Reynolds, would you please stop being Ryan Reynolds in your movies?

If anybody has fully watched this movie and says "yes you should watch it" that person hates you, this is complete rubbish... the only humor is thinking about the huge amount of stuff that can be less painful to do, other than watching this pile of rubbish unfold.It is actually hard to pick the worst part of this film, is it the horrible acting? Is it the horrible selection of the worst soundtrack? Is it the fact that some people actually find this funny inside the theater? Or perhaps the horrible visual effects? I think it might be a mixture of no plot and huge amount of unfunny jokes about drugs and gay sexIf you think you'd like this kind of thing go watch is always sunny in Philadelphia or little Britain... this movie should have never been released.

I mean, why mince words. This movie is just unwatchable. 2 hours of solid garbage and an insult to the audience.Every piece of comedy, sarcasm and one liner feels forced. So many scenes and sequences between Deadpool and Wolverine were over done and felt they were there just to allow Reynolds more lines and also because the movie had no substance to last full 2 hours.MCU hasn't really produced a good movie since the endgame. Either they have really run out of ideas or they just realized they got a base to get to a billion anyways so why spend time and energy into making good movie.All I know is this isn't good cinema and if this is the best MCU can do, it's time to move on from this circus.

The plot is thin, extremely constructed, artificial and unnecessarily confusing and pointless.Multiverse here, timelines there, a universe is slowly dying because Logan died (?), so a crazy guy wants to destroy this universe quickly and painlessly with a machine like Thanos, so they bring Wolverine from another Earth to prevent that, then a crazy chick comes along who also wants to destroy the universe. The writers were crazy there.Extremely much blabla, 99% of the jokes refer to other films in the Marvel/Avengers/X-Men universe or take aim at Fox/Disney.The gags are exclusively for insiders, and at the same time at a fifth-grader level. I couldn't laugh at them.After a short time it becomes brutally exhausting.There isn't even that much action.The action that is there is a bit bloody, a bit of splatter, but overall completely unspectacular and boring.By far the worst Deadpool part, and Wolverine anyway. Deadpool has now arrived where the others have already arrived: in the Marvel uniform.A shame.

You can usually tell when a superhero movie is going to be garbage by the creative team, the studio, the trailer, etc. I was primed and ready for this one a month ago. But after seeing it, I wish Jackman would've stayed retired.There is nothing in this movie other than the cameos and a yellow Wolverine costume. I went in expecting a real movie, so maybe that's on me. The first two Deadpool movies were irreverent and silly, but they weren't soulless. This movie is soulless. There is no story, there is no heart. The trailers played literally 99% of the 'character-introspection' that exists in the movie.If you're curious going in as to what's eating at Wolverine from the trailers, rest assured you will be disappointed. It's nothing other than run-of-the-mill lip service used to distract a bad guy. What's the Vanessa-hook for Wade this time around? There's about 10 seconds of screentime devoted to that, and, yes, it is that poorly thought-out and pointless.I've avoided most of the worst superhero movies in theaters. I did see Batman Forever in the movies as a kid, I saw X-Men Origins: Wolverine, and I saw Green Lantern. This movie is on that level. It's funnier, but it's that caliber of filmmaking. The action scenes aren't even that good, which is weird.Let me reiterate something...this is a 2-hr Easter Egg, it is not a movie. If you want to watch a movie, watch something else. If you like watching Mystery Science Theater 3000-level spoofs/meta-commentary, you'd honestly be better off watching that. If the thought of "Comic Book Shop Fanboy Talk: The Movie" gets your pants tight, you're in luck. That is all this movie is.

Deadpool and Wolverine, an anticipated mash-up of two beloved Marvel characters, has proven to be a colossal disappointment. From start to finish, this movie is a painfully drawn-out exercise in futility that leaves audiences yearning for their lost time.Firstly, let's address the plot - or the glaring lack thereof. The narrative is a chaotic jumble, an incoherent mess that fails to provide any semblance of direction or purpose. It felt as if the writers simply threw together random scenes, hoping the sheer presence of the titular characters would suffice. Spoiler alert: it doesn't.The humor, which should have been a saving grace given Deadpool's reputation, falls disastrously flat. The jokes are stale and forced, lacking the sharp wit and cleverness that made Deadpool's previous outings enjoyable. Instead of laughing, I found myself cringing at the awkward attempts at humor that consistently missed their mark.The film's pacing is another major flaw. It drags endlessly, turning what should have been an action-packed, engaging experience into a tedious slog. Scenes linger unnecessarily, stretching out moments that add nothing to the story - if you can even call it that.To say I want my time back is an understatement. Deadpool and Wolverine is a prime example of wasted potential. With two iconic characters at their disposal, the filmmakers somehow managed to deliver a forgettable, lackluster experience that fails on almost every level. Save yourself the agony and skip this train wreck. Your time is far too precious to waste on such a disastrous attempt at filmmaking.

Deadpool & Wolverine is so bad that makes the last Ant-Man movie and art movie made by Nolan Antonioni and Bergmann combined. The only group it might appeal is that of 14 year old boys and not the clever ones. The humor which supposed to be a Deadpool's strong point is non existent. The only sector that justifies my 3/10 star review is probably Hugh Jackman's performance as Wolverine who is constantly angy, which I believe is true because of his anger and his disgust of how he let himself participate in this - kind of - movie. The good part is the cameo of past heroes and that the cinema was actually fully booked by people that all regretted their money. It's certainly an elevation of taste, as someone understands the garbage we are served today.

The other Deadpool movies were great. They were much funnier than this movie. Not that this movie is bad-it's not. It's just that it's not as good. The other Deadpool movies are filled with jokes and those jokes hit the bullseye. This movie is also filled with jokes but most of them hit the edge of their target. Tons of jokes and most of them are "meh".Also this movie has a lot going on in it. I think the writers were trying to keep the interest of the audience by making a lot happen, but really they filled the movie with a lot of stuff that needs explaining, and the fact is that you would need to make this movie like 6 hours long to explain everything, so since it's not a 6 hour movie and a lot goes unexplained, this movie is somewhat confusing.I was really looking forward to this movie. I loved the other Deadpool movies. I love Wolverine. I love both actors who play the characters. But this movie disappointed me. Not a great movie but not a bad movie.

Went to see this movie because my brother heard it was really good but judging by the reviews I don't get this film at all. It's a common theme in marvel films where they add too much comedy which then ruins the seriousness of the threat/villain. I'm not going to lie that it was funny for some parts but the overuse and repetitiveness of constantly trying to make something funny just cuz just gets boring and annoying over time. At the end of the movie I just wanted it to be over already and ready forgot what is it the heroes are trying to accomplish here. Do not see this movie if you are expecting a film worth remembering.

Deadpool & Wolverine. Saw it in premiere Xd for my birthday. I love watching movies on the big screen. Deadpool and Wolverine was okay. I've watched all the Wolverine movies and I think I've seen the previous Deadpools as well. I think Morena B is beautiful. Always good to see her one the big screen. However this crossover was rough. The whole concept lacks a real storyline and almost feels like scraps of ideas that didn't make it as full movies. We miss Stan Lee. The marvel universe was better when Stan Lee was still alive. Even the cinematography could have been better. Though the movie is rated R, I believe it is really for a much younger crowd. The reason being that a younger crowd may be more easily entertained. I would recommend waiting to see it when it is released on streaming services.

That about sums up the sheer manic trip of this movie. While Deadpool 1 is the story of, "am I good enough to be a husband" and 2, "am I good enough to be a dad", 3 asks "am I good enough to be an Avenger."Judging by the quality drop, yes. I write quality drop because the sets are generic, the fights are obviously prerecorded without a script and boring to watch, and the plot is...people journeying out of a computer generated zone...This seems to be the trend of Marvel Disney: green screens, exposition dumps, disconnected fight scene, then rinse and repeat until enough frames are shot to equal a movie. The jokes are "meh" and it could be because we've seen this two times before but it was mostly because there wasn't much going on to make into something funny.These recent Marvel films suffer from the inability to keep a story flowing. They lack rhythm. Sure, someone plugs plot details into a plot generator and out pops this mess.With that said, Hugh and Ryan do a fantastic job acting. The best parts of this film are the love letter to Fox, and what they contributed to the franchise. Sure it wasn't always the greatest, but a lot of people did put hard work into them.We had to learn what NOT to do somewhere, and it appears Disney has yet to learn NOT to substitute the flow of a plot and story, for the convenience of Corporate Systems of governance.It kind of sucks, but at least Deadpool 2 had the best character to ever grace Mutant Comic movies; that is Domino.

This movie was like a rollercoaster, but without the tracks. It just kind of...went. You know? Deadpool and Wolverine together, that should be gold, right? But this thing felt like they tossed 'em in a blender with a bunch of random stuff and hit puree. There's no real story, just a bunch of scenes stapled together with hope. I mean, Deadpool's funny and Wolverine is cool, but they just felt like two dudes hanging out, cracking jokes with no real reason to be there. It's like they replaced a script with a wish list of cameos. Don't get me wrong, seeing (insert random cameo) was a kick, but it didn't make up for the fact that I had no idea what was going on. Basically, it was like watching a really expensive, overproduced home video. Lots of flashy stuff, but no real heart or soul.

The movie lacks good pacing. Most of the comedy doesn't land unfortunately - Jackman looks old and bored. And are we still doing the stereotypical offensive Indian characters in 2024? C'mon marvel, we all know you wouldn't show any black character in an offensive light. Mocking different races was never funny.There is barely any narrative thread connecting this to the first two films but hey! It does exceed in being a ginormous try-hard onanistic advertisement for old Marvel franchises. If you're an easter bunny looking to collect them all, this might be for you, otherwise may I please recommend something along the lines of Dredd, PG Psycho Goreman, The Loved Ones, Dead Heat, Toxic Avenger, Der Samurai, Severance, or the wholesome series Ash vs Evil Dead? Bwahahahaha JUST KIDDING here's another intertextual Disney ad disguised as an actual movie!

The movie was mediocre and unremarkable, with a lackluster plot and overall weakness. While the first installment was also just average, it was more forgivable as an initial attempt. By the second movie, however, there was an expectation for improvement.I found myself forcing laughs, and it wasn't even cheesy enough to be endearing. Charging $20 for this is unbelievable. The only positive aspect was the abundance of easter eggs, which might go unnoticed by the average viewer. It seems the movie was intended for fans, but it fails to satisfy even those who consider themselves dedicated followers.Never again.

Was never a fan of Deadpool, but I heard about the cameos and thought I give this a shot. First of all, the CGI is horrendous, look worse than video games with those fake blood and over-exaggerated gore p0rn.Then the jokes and conversation, low class toiIet humor, and again and again and again. Yeah we get it, the bromance, the "Haha" metro jokes, the dog... my goodness, how many times? 3? 4?What is the point of a movie when your protagonist(s) are invincible? Since they are never in any real danger, what would be the thrill? It is like watching Mandalorian after he got the armor. Then it just turn into an invincible super hero. That's like... playing video game with invincibility cheat on. What is the thrill? What is the excitement?This film is made by children for children with low expectations.5/10.

"Deadpool & Wolverine" is a highly anticipated crossover that ultimately fails to deliver on its promise. The film attempts to combine the irreverent humor of Deadpool with the gritty intensity of Wolverine, but the result is a disjointed mess that falls short of both characters' previous outings.The plot of "Deadpool & Wolverine" is one of its biggest weaknesses. It feels hastily thrown together, lacking the coherence and engaging storyline that fans have come to expect from both franchises. The narrative jumps from one contrived scenario to another, with little regard for character development or logical progression. This lack of a solid plot foundation makes it difficult for viewers to become invested in the story or care about the characters' fates.The humor, a defining feature of Deadpool's character, is another area where the film falters. While the previous Deadpool movies were celebrated for their sharp wit and clever meta-commentary, "Deadpool & Wolverine" relies heavily on silly, lowbrow jokes that often fall flat. The humor feels forced and out of place, detracting from the overall tone of the movie. Instead of the clever, self-aware comedy that fans love, we get an overabundance of juvenile gags that wear thin quickly.In comparison to the previous films, "Deadpool & Wolverine" lacks the polish and attention to detail that made its predecessors stand out. The character interactions, which should have been a highlight given the strong personalities of both Deadpool and Wolverine, are awkward and uninspired. The film fails to capitalize on the potential for witty banter and meaningful exchanges between the two iconic characters, leaving viewers disappointed.The action sequences, while visually impressive at times, do little to salvage the film. They often feel like a series of disconnected set pieces rather than an integral part of the story. The lack of a compelling plot and meaningful character arcs makes it hard to care about the outcome of these battles, reducing their impact.Overall, "Deadpool & Wolverine" is a missed opportunity. It struggles with a weak plot, relies on humor that doesn't hit the mark, and falls short of the standards set by the previous films. Fans of Deadpool and Wolverine may find moments of enjoyment, but as a whole, the film fails to live up to its potential.

Marvel is good before parallel universe .. Now all is suck !Nonsense all. The story is not good .. the story plot make confuse and dont have the main story .Marvel end with avengers end game.I know the deadpool character is to much talk , But this is to much .. And first is funny , but if you repeat and repeat i will be bored .Hope next marvel with RDJ come it will be better .Save one earth dont save all the earth ..With all the character make it ruin the character it self .Thor end marvel ..Very waste my time with this film,last is antman . I think i stop with marvel .. no more.

Although it's not the only problem with this movie, the double combo punch of time travel and multiverse nonsense destroyed my interest in this movie and Marvel in general. Time travel has been overused for years. Yes, some stories were interesting but it is a fantasy which has become more of a crutch. And we now have the multiverse thing added in. It was fun for a while with sliders but, like time travel, it's become a cheap trick. The MCU now uses both time travel and multiverse elements is a very messy way.So I haven't been that interested in DP2 due to the time travel aspect. And DP&W, along with Marvel in general, with the combination of time travel and multiverses has become nonsensical. There wasn't much else of interest in DP&W either. I am OK with gore when it fits in the plot. But there is so much in this movie which was clearly there just for spectacle. And most of the dialog and jokes were not interesting nor funny.In the end, this movie was actually depressing. I could have done or watched something which was actually interesting or fun. Instead, I forced myself to finish this piece of crap. I haven't found the MCU interesting since Infinity War. I am done with the MCU.

After each Deapool movie, I wind up thinking "Where can they go from here?" There's something about the formula with this character (aka Ryan Reynolds breaking the fourth wall while making vulgar jokes and grotesquely killing people) that guarantees diminishing returns. Every time Wade Wilson shows up, the stakes feel lower and I care a little less. The story almost seems beside the point now; everybody is too busy making jokes and explaining plotlines to tell a real story. That said, I did laugh a bunch. If you tell enough jokes, some of them are bound to land. It is basically Spider-man: No Way Home but with dick jokes and exploding heads. But for all our wondering about what would happen when the MCU and Fox merged, the answer seems to be that you get the best and worst of both. And that means we're still stuck with multiverse movies that spend all their time explaining things and then undoing the things they just explained. Plus, look at this cameo from someone who used to be in our stories! Hugh Jackman takes it seriously and the suit looks great, but that alone doesn't justify a two hour runtime even if you make sarcastic quips about the runtime throughout the movie.

Deadpool & Wolverine (2024) promised to be an explosive addition to the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU), uniting two of Marvel's most beloved and notorious anti-heroes. However, despite the high expectations and tantalizing elements, the movie fell short in several critical areas, leaving fans with mixed feelings.Plot OverviewThe central plot revolves around Deadpool (Ryan Reynolds) and Wolverine (Hugh Jackman) teaming up to save Deadpool's universe from being obliterated by a formidable new villain, Mr. Paradox, and his devastating weapon, the Time Ripper. Mr. Paradox is on a mission to "snip off" dying universes, and Deadpool's universe is next on his list. The story had the potential to be a gripping tale of heroism and sacrifice, but ultimately, the execution lacked the necessary impact.Main Characters and PerformancesVillains and AntagonistsSupporting Characters and CameosThe movie features a slew of cameos from notable Marvel characters, including Elektra, Gambit, Blade, X-23, and Johnny Storm. While these appearances were meant to excite fans, they felt more like superficial additions rather than integral parts of the story. Each cameo was brief and lacked meaningful interaction with the main plot, which could have added layers to the narrative.Action and HumorThe movie excels in delivering high-octane action sequences and humor. The banter between Deadpool and Wolverine provides many laughs, staying true to Deadpool's unique style. The fight scenes are well-choreographed, showcasing the characters' abilities and teamwork. However, these elements alone were not enough to carry the movie.Plot Execution and StorytellingThe film's main storyline - the mission to save Deadpool's universe - promised a significant impact on the MCU. Yet, the resolution of the plot felt anticlimactic. Despite their efforts, Deadpool and Wolverine's actions resulted in minimal change, with only one universe being saved and no substantial alterations to the overarching MCU narrative. This lack of significant consequence undermines the movie's stakes, leaving viewers with a sense of missed opportunity.Deadpool & Wolverine (2024) is a film that delivers on humor and action but falls short in storytelling and character development. The inclusion of numerous cameos and nostalgic elements like Wolverine's yellow suit provides momentary excitement but fails to contribute meaningfully to the plot. The film's central mission to save Deadpool's universe lacks the depth and impact needed to feel consequential within the larger MCU. As a result, fans are left with a movie that, while entertaining in parts, ultimately does not fulfill its potential to "save the MCU."While Deadpool's humor and Wolverine's nostalgia hit the right notes, the movie needed more substantial plot developments and deeper character explorations to truly resonate with audiences.

The first two deadpool movies were stand-alone fun and hijinx. This was sold as being the same but in fact was an MCU movie with all the requirement you be a Lore expert in thirty odd movies and months worth of average to mid TV series.It's so concerned with being a metatextual goodbye to films we've forgotten about that it forgot to be a film. To be clear, I'm the kind of Nerd who laughed at Liefield's Shoes. I'm that dork they make the references for. But the entire film is references, baskets of Easter Eggs being poured over you until you're numb.I didn't want another MCU movie.MCU movies are work these days. Exhausting work that even nerds like me feelime a chore.I stopped reading the comics owing to the need to know decades of convoluted backstory.I lost interest in the MCU after Endgame Part 1 because I realised there were never going to be stakes again. And now it also need a decade of convoluted backstory to understand.I went into Deadpool 3 hoping for a refreshing stand-alone super hero story that capped the trilogy. Instead I got another exhausting franchise meta narrative that killed its own characters to shove itself into the MCU mold.Rant over, go see the next episode in Marvel, Tony Stark is Doctor Doom in a bad suit now and we're all supposed to care.

With the incredible potential of combining two iconic MARVEL characters, played by the great Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman, one would expect an exceptional movie.Unfortunately, despite the star power, the film falls short. The storytelling was lackluster, and the writing failed to deliver the punch that i hoped for (infinity war style) . The overuse of the multiverse concept struck again, which,made the plot feel convoluted and overdone. To top it off, the ending was so uninspired that it felt like a twist you'd expect from a budget-bin DVD. It's a real disappointment considering the talent involved.A missed opportunity, to proporly introducing the X-men to the MCU to say the least.....
