"Deadpool and Wolverine" had the potential to be a blockbuster, bringing together two of the most beloved and iconic characters from the Marvel Universe. However, the film feels like a missed opportunity, coming across as disconnected and poorly written. While there are moments that may appeal to hardcore fans, the movie, on the whole, struggles to find its footing, leaving casual viewers feeling unsatisfied.Wolverine, on the other hand, is portrayed in a way that feels disconnected from the character's previous iterations. The brooding, conflicted hero is replaced by a version of Wolverine that feels more like a supporting character than a co-lead. The dynamic between Deadpool and Wolverine, which could have been a highlight of the film, lacks the chemistry and depth needed to make their interactions meaningful. Instead, their relationship feels superficial, with the film relying on cheap thrills and action sequences rather than meaningful character development.Dialogue and HumorOne of the most disappointing aspects of "Deadpool and Wolverine" is the dialogue. The film is riddled with cheap, one-liner jokes that lack the cleverness and wit that fans have come to expect from Deadpool. The humor often feels forced, as if the writers were trying too hard to replicate the success of the previous Deadpool films without truly understanding what made those films work.Wolverine's dialogue, too, suffers from a lack of substance. His character is known for his terse, no-nonsense approach, but in this film, his lines are often reduced to generic tough-guy clichs. The dialogue fails to capture the essence of who these characters are, making their interactions feel hollow and unengaging.Direction and PacingThe direction of "Deadpool and Wolverine" contributes to the overall sense of disconnection in the film. The pacing is uneven, with scenes that drag on too long interspersed with abrupt action sequences that feel out of place. The film struggles to find a rhythm, leaving viewers unsure of what tone it is trying to achieve. Is it a dark, gritty superhero drama or a lighthearted, comedic romp? The film never seems to make up its mind, resulting in a jarring viewing experience.Catering to Hardcore FansWhile "Deadpool and Wolverine" may not work for the average moviegoer, it does have moments that will likely appeal to hardcore fans. The film is peppered with Easter eggs, references, and callbacks to the comics that only the most dedicated fans will appreciate. However, even these moments feel like a crutch, as if the film is leaning on fan service to compensate for its lack of substance. For those who are deeply invested in the Marvel Universe, these nods to the source material may provide some enjoyment, but for others, they do little to enhance the overall experience.ConclusionIn conclusion, "Deadpool and Wolverine" is a film that falls short of its potential. The disjointed plot, lackluster character development, and cheap dialogue make it a disappointing addition to the Marvel franchise. While hardcore fans may find some enjoyment in the film's references and Easter eggs, casual viewers are likely to walk away feeling underwhelmed. This movie is a testament to the fact that even with beloved characters, a film needs a strong story, well-crafted dialogue, and thoughtful direction to truly succeed.

"Deadpool and Wolverine" attempts to blend the irreverent charm of Deadpool with the brooding intensity of Wolverine, but ultimately falls flat with its reliance on cheap action and humor. While the idea of pairing these iconic characters promises an exciting ride, the execution leaves much to be desired.One of the most glaring issues is the film's CGI. Despite the high stakes and explosive action scenes, the special effects feel disappointingly low-budget. From poorly rendered explosions to unconvincing character animations, the visual spectacle is marred by a sense of cheapness that detracts from the immersion. The scenes that should have been awe-inspiring instead come off as lackluster, failing to live up to the standards set by previous superhero films.The gore, a staple in both characters' narratives, is equally uninspired and tasteless. Rather than adding to the intensity or emotional weight of the story, it feels gratuitous and poorly executed.The humor, which is supposed to be one of Deadpool's strong suits, falls into a similar trap. The film is saturated with cheap jokes, with about 90% relying on sexual innuendos and crass humor. While Deadpool is known for his irreverence, the over-reliance on this type of comedy quickly grows tiresome. Instead of clever wit or genuinely funny moments, viewers are bombarded with lowbrow humor that fails to elicit more than a few chuckles.In summary, "Deadpool and Wolverine" is a disappointing entry in the superhero genre. With its cheap CGI, uninspired gore, and overwhelmingly sexual humor, the film struggles to find a balance between action and comedy, leaving fans longing for the days when these characters were handled with more care and creativity.

So disappointed after reading a lot of positive reviews. Especially after bringing on Jackman, who has done a lot of great work.There is no storyline worth explained whatsoever, it is all made up to get a far out excuse to bring on cameos. Sure, we get a few laughs on the way, but the pace is destroyed by an excessive amount of too long, boring fights in slowmotion. Yes, we know you can't die, so stabbing each other is about as interesting as seeing two brothers hit each other on the shoulder.Sorry, I normally like Renolds and Wolverine is a favoruite character of mine, but Marvel should have stopped after Endgame..

Man... their conversations used to be highlight of the movie. FYI, I feel he was the only one in the entire franchise to ever match up to comic standard of Ryan Reynolds.Third, well if I add third it would be tantamount to nitpicking what with the jumpy storyline anti climactic ending and real underused of TVA, I mean we all saw how Loki misuses the device, Reynolds could have taken it a bit far most versions of Wolverine were expected, he has sinned to a Wolverine on a cross, he is tall so somewhere he's short, messiah in one pariah in other these were kind of expected...

I see lots of people giving this a 10.They have to be industry people trying to prop up the score.This was not a 10.It's probably more a 1 but I've given it a generous 2 because there were a few laughs .Other than the few laughs there was little else .When I heard they were bringing Wolverine into the franchise I really hoped for something special .What we got was a mess .No story to speak of .Far too many characters and cameos .The script could have been written by schoolchildren.Actually schoolchildren probably would have done a better job.The fact that this movie will do well at the box office Means they'll do another one using the same formula.And on and on it will go until people actually call this stuff out for what it is . Crap!I really enjoyed the first Deadpool movie .The second one was ok, not as good as the first but they tried .This one just beggars belief .What were they thinking ?Just Bad Bad Bad !

I enjoyed Deadpool 1 and 2, but like with many Hollywood sequels, the appeal seems to diminish over time. Deadpool 3 feels more like an MCU movie with Deadpool as the main narrator. I found the random introduction of what I think are MCU characters both confusing and pointless. In my opinion, the franchise should have ended after Deadpool 2. As a person that is not educated on the comic book culture, I was lost. I just hope they won't produce more content that could dilute the quality of the first two movies. If you're a fan of modern comics, you'll probably enjoy the movie, but if not, it might not be worth the money.

Let me preface this my saying I have never seen a Disney Marvel movie that I enjoyed.I didn't mind the first 2 Deadpool movies, and I had low expectations for this one knowing that this one, unlike the other two, would be made by Disney.I did find the jokes funny, but the lack of plot and character development had be bored. Meanwhile the people sitting next to me seemed to be having the time of their life, so maybe this movie just wasn't for me.I found the aesthetics ugly. None of the characters were attractive, despite the actors not being bad looking in real life. The backgrounds were ugly too. Too mechanical looking and too orange.The villain, as in all Disney movies, was an emotionaless Brit who spoke with a complete lack of intonation. (Is it even politically correct to continuously portray Brits as boring prudes? It's 2024. We're supposed to be passed stereotyping like this).Anyway, that aside. If someone asked me to summarize the plot of this movie, I couldn't do it. Some sort of fixing a world, time device thing? I had no conclusion to anticipate. It was just like every other Marvel movie, no real beginning, a bunch of CGI violence, and an end but this time with the witty jokes of Ryan Reynolds.A lot of gay insuations from Deadpool towards Wolverine that never went anywhere. If you're going to go that route in the dialogue, I expect some action. A make out scene between Deapool and Wolverine definitely would've made this movie more original and more entertaining.All in all, if you like movies that are just mindless fighting with no plot and witty jokes, you'll probably like this.If you like movies that have substance in the way of a plot and with characters whose emotions you can feel/connect with, this movie is not for you.All in all, this movie was mid.

Ryan and Hugh funny odd couple-esc movie but with incredible images and action. Jumping on some if the more uncreative Disney Marvel plot narratives to creat a story around. Hitting some required Disney Checkbox Casting queues on the way to watching the Ryan aand Hugh show. Fun, but slightly numbing at the start.There are more fun scenes in the movie than shown in the trailer and marketing, so but it's not to the level we have had in prior characters past movies. Structured buddies comedy, only with beloved comic book character.If you absolutely love, and I mean LOVE, both Deadpool and Wolverine, you have to go, so enjoy the good parts.

Out of my appreciation for Hugh Jackman and Ryan Reynolds I gave this 5 stars. Both have created iconic characters of Deadpool and Wolverine. I can't imagine any other actors playing these roles. Deadpool is one of the funniest, original superhero movies I've seen. Wolverine is iconic. So I have enjoyed these two incredible entertainers for 25 years. But this movie is a like a knock off toy of your favorite character you buy at the dollar store. What a total freaking mess. The jokes are non-stop and non-funny. I didn't actually laugh genuinely once. I wanted to laugh so bad I found myself laughing at jokes that, after thinking about, weren't actually funny. The story is manic and aimless. The scenery is boring. The dialogue is pointless. The villain is a Gen Z kid. The fight scenes are non-sensical as neither character can actually die. This movie is low to no stakes. The only ending I was actually waiting for was the actual ending, as in I couldn't wait for it to be over. It's hard to believe this but on a Friday night in a packed movie theater on opening weekend the energy was very low. People kept waiting and waiting for something more substantive but it never came. So I left 30 minutes before it was over. Out of respect for these two incredible actors who have given us so much fun over the years. But this is a joke of a movie, and unfortunately, the joke is on us.

Wow, I don't know where to begin. I guess first off, I am not a huge fan of these multi-verse movies. Seems like everyone is doing them nowadays and it's getting really old really fast.Next, this is by far the worst one of the three movies. I rated both movies before this a 10 out of 10. They were hilarious, raunchy, crude, it was a really fun good time. This one does have a lot of that, but some of the jokes fell flat to me.Then weird things such as the line "boys are so silly" by the overpowered girl boss just didn't sit well with me. Those are the types of things that have been failing for Disney, I would've thought Ryan Reynolds would've asked that line to be cut.Anyway, I am so glad I did not pay a dime to watch this.4/10 by far the worst one of the three.

Yes, this movie is for only fans of the franchise and are able to understand everything, from the plot to the Easter eggs.The movie is aimed to their fandom and doesn't care for the rest of the audience.I'm just a person who likes movies, and I like them...but this is a convoluted mess that goes from boring and complicated to action packed scenes so convoluted that my eyes were tired... I don't think it's for kids because of all the gore, although the humor is as silly and infantile as it can be.If you are a Marvel fan you are going to love it.If you are watching it because...kids...I'm sorry for you.

This movie is the antithesis of the 2 other, much, much better movies, the jokes at the statue quo, the don't give whatever everybody things, the don't do a movie just for the money. Horrible, terrible, I just think that the people that like the movie lost their neurons as it was played. So it need to be more that 600 hundred words what can I say, money grabber?, badly written, no funny jokes whatsoever, too. Much inmecesary references, the plot didn't have any sense whatsoever, just. Kill, kill, kill, blood, blood, blood and other thing. That could. Attract. Any money. Hope. This movie kills. The franchise, I really really do,. They does. Not. Deserve any money. Dollar.

Ryan Reynolds has been trying to ruin Marvel for quite some time. I'm glad Stan Lee is not around to see this. At this point Ryan is just beating the heck out of an already dying horse. It's just weird.The Marvel universe is based on the great comic book heroes that Stan Lee created. For the most part, morally sound individuals who try to do the right things and help others. Reynolds has been intentionally endeavoring to belittle and demean the whole universe and all its characters. He seems oblivious to the fact that Stan Lee's morally sound heroes have consistently been tremendous role models, especially for young people. He seems fixated on perverting the whole thing. Or he just doesn't care. Either way, it's weird.

The movie Deadpool and Wolverine is a very boring movie. The plot in general can get confusing if you don't understand one part or pay attention completely. The plot is self is not an interesting plot and is kind of dull. It has a good amount of action throughout the move and a lot of comedy, but the action is mainly between wolverine and deadpool which becomes repetitive and gets boring quickly. The comedy is there like any other deadpool movie. Near the end of the movie it becomes better with the action scenes becoming more interesting. But overall m, In my opinion there are better deadpool movies that have better action scenes and a better plot than this movie.

If you love Ryan Reynolds you'll love this as it's purely and simply the Ryan Reynolds show. It becomes so irritating after the first 30 minutes.It's just him, throughout, being sarcastic to everything that moves and the constant references to movie Companies gets sooooooo boring, we don't care about Fox and Disney and whatever has gone on there.The storyline is random and apart from the main theme I didn't have a clue what was going on.Hugh Jackoff just looked old and bored, it was another Dallas moment bringing him back to life.The only redeeming feature for me was the music, and without that it would have been even more meh.The Madonna bit at the end was worth waiting for.The special effects are good but it's just Reynolds, he grinded on me so much as just never shuts up.If it's raining and you've got nothing better to do then watch this.

Legitimate question here, did artificial intelligence actually write this movie? Its a legitimate question because the shallowness, idiocy and perplexingly nonsensical jokes could not possibly have been written by people who just got done with a rather lengthy strike in Hollywood. In fact they sound like jokes from a script that someone has been sitting on for quite a while considering the gap between Deadpool 2, and this third installment. No offense, but if this is modern comedy in an action fantasy film, please place it back in the oven or grab as its not done yet. Only the most dedicated mouth breathing casual audience could possibly find anything entertaining in a film where half the jokes are bad computer animated fight sequences with lame 80's (and unfortunately newer) pop songs playing in the background. How groundbreaking, since apparently if you did this in a little movie called "Suicide Squad" (both if we're honest) people think its kind of garbage. Not unlike Paul Rudd's career, Ryan Reynolds has seen his heyday pass him by as well, since his claim to fame is "those deadpool movies and insurance commercials," what a legacy Ryan. Yet, here he is the one cracking a joke at Paul Rudd's equally dead franchise i.e. Antman. How brave. Worse than the overwritten dialogue is probably the odd dichotomy of having to both pretend Wade's deadpool actually cares about anything between all the offensively unintelligent jokes at I suppose whatever the AI algorithm came up- like this gem:"You know what? You're a ******* joke. No wonder the Avengers didn't take you or the X-Men, and they'll take ******* anyone. I mean, you are a ridiculous, immature, half-wit moron. I have never met a sadder, more attention-starved jabbering little ***** in my entire life, and that says a lot because I've been alive for more than two hundred ******* years! And I'll tell you, that bald chick was right about one thing: you will never save the world. You couldn't even save a relationship with a ******* stripper! Mother******, I wish I could say you'll die alone, but it's one of God's best jokes that you can't die! Except that's on all of us! You got nothing to say, mouth?"This enormously out-of-touch speech is the most overwritten, pretentious, fourth wall breaking trash I've ever heard or read in my life. These characters have so little actual growth, that they have to invent some lame speech for Logan to present to Deadpool, even when he has little reason to know any details of Wade's life, or his accomplishments prior to this film (almost like they forgot to mention those two other movies or something). Here-in lies the problem with a movie where two of the main characters have to be blank slates in order for the script-writers to do anything. Cameos galore cannot save a movie where the two main characters learn nothing about each other, babble insane lines that don't even rationalize their own behavior since we are only aware of them from previous franchises, which the writers are relying on so they don't have to do any actual heavy-lifting. All the 70 year old Wesley Snipers in the world can't save your dumb buddy cop film with cheesy one-liners, cartoon violence computer animation, and disgusting tonal dissonance whenever some lame song that plays at Walmart all day comes on as if it means anything at all.You can say I "don't like fun," but I've seen these movies, they've been coming out for years and they have no other direction to take except for maybe self-parody. There were so many lame jokes about Disney and Fox that only some corporate suit knowledgeable about rights issues, licenses, marketing and IP's could have suggested them to the AI. Cowboy films also became their own walking parody, so much so that an Italian director ended up making some of the best Cowboy films ever made (and the cheesiest too). The fact that people are still slow to understand the idea of "Sphaghetti super hero film" as long as it has someone recognizable in it, tells you a lot about our current generation of movie-goers and their expectations. The bar is pretty low, but luckily the collective memory of goldfish isn't dictated by how many of them are in one fish-tank. Over 20 years ago, X-men was popular because it was doing something different, that was when comic book sales weren't completely on life-support like they are now. Yes, its sad, but they had it coming, and like-wise so do movies starring 70 year old "Blades" spouting the same terrible lines he made infamous so long ago that I forgot they were even remaking Blade. If you do not take time to humanize these characters, develop good stories for them (like Logan) and rely on parody, you will end up stepping into the same quicksand Marvel slipped into. The adoration and money comes from bamboozled fans from somewhere, but I doubt even they are capable of currently connecting the dots when it comes to the generally insufferable tone these movies are going for now.

If I have to be honest, it started great, it kept pace for a while, then cliches start raining along with cut body parts and sex jokes. For two hours we had fun, a lot of laugh, dirty jokes and ugly dogs. Then I was satisfied it ended and it was no more of that film. Fun moments, sad moments, new faces, something was missing. I can't complain it was boring, it was just one idea less than I expected it would be. I don't know why some moments were missing, the ones shown in the trailer, but anyway it's worth it watching for the Deadpool fans. Just please avoid the seats near people with popcorn at the cinema.

I think one of the things that made the previous two Deadpool movies a success was that they had to be inventive because of the restrictions on licencing and to some degree budget.However now Deadpool is fully in the Marvel stables, and they have unlimited access to characters and budget, inventiveness has gone out the window. All you're left with a poorly written film which is bloated with pointless cameos, Easter eggs and substandard special effects. If seeing other MCU characters turn up for 30 seconds makes a good movie in your opinion then you'll probably love it. But it felt like fanfiction written by a 13 year old for the majority of the duration.The part where the film shines is the interactions between Deadpool and Wolverine, but the actual plot is ridiculous, there is no real sense of peril and the resolution is neither interesting or satisfying. The movie also felt about 40 minutes too long. Have never been bored in a Deadpool film before, but I was last night.It's a real shame as the Deadpool films have always been so left field and entertaining but this just felt packed with typical Marvel bloat, pomp and a lack of any real jeopardy.Sincerely hope that there is no Deadpool 4 and am shocked to find myself writing that.

Don't get me wrong, Wolverine I love, Ryan Reynolds I'll watch every day if the week. But this is nothing more than pantomime. I cannot understand the 10 ratings - someone said industry ratings prolong the film up. It's weak, and didn't need to be made. I can't say the plot was weak, it wasn't meant to be strong. The 4th wall is there for a reason - we get drawn in to watching something, a story being told. We watch to be immersed in the story. The gore is beyond cringe and given recent events touched a nerve - give it context and it's fine but mindless and over the top. Not needed. I left wishing it had been as good as I'd been told.

So let's see: what constitutes a good movie?Good action scenes? Check.Good editing & directing? Yeah sure why not, check.Enough superhero copyrights to shove cameos of half the superheroes ever made just coz we can? Check.More copyright for popular songs to shove more nostalgia to the "colorful" mix? Check.Good story? Nah! It's 2024, who needs that any more?!!Important disclaimer here: I never was a fan of Deadpool, I came here for Wolverine. If u saw the movie I think you'll understand my disappointmentWolverine here is no more than a side kick at best. I wouldn't be surprised if I knew that his whole script reached Hugh Jackman on a bunch of sticky notes or something. There's no character depth, no relatable motives, rare scenes of good acting, just a couple max . I really hope the money was good Mr Hugh coz I'm relentlessly failing to understand the reasons why you might have thought this is a story worth telling! I mean you ended Wolverine on a legendary high note with "Logan", this one is so sadly underwhelming! Even that simple title is so hilariously misleading it should've been something like "Deadpool(s) & Co" or maybe "Deadpoolers' wet dream" or something. Even the SciFi aspect of it is as expected from Marvel so outlandishly un-relatable entirely based on that multiverse hoax they're fond of, might as well do a story on flat earth!The overarching message of the production team all around the movie was "We're the company that created so many other stuff you loved earlier, that has to be enough for you guys to like whatever BS we throw at you, right?" You can see that message in the amount of out of context cameos, the Easter eggs, the soundtracks of other movies jammed in out of mood scenes, even in the closing credits, they just shove other movies' bloopers and BTSs that till now I fail to fathom their relevance. My god, if it wasn't for the spoilers I would have mentioned some character cameos that I wouldn't even care to mention in a joke! You'll know her when you see her.Call me old school but I believe a good story is a 1, add some good acting to it then it becomes a 10, good directing gets you to 100, throw some good production money that's a 1000, but if you have no story you end up with just zeros. After all, the movie business, at its core definition is just a glorified art of storytelling, right?

Please end these movies. Just stop making them. If you cant get the length right, stop making them. They are TOO F@&$%NG LONG. STOP MAKING THESE MOVIES. STOP. NO ONE CARES anymore. They arent good, ryan reynolds is grasping to relevancy like a drunk grasps the toilet as he hurls gutfulls of bile into it. These movies could be fun, if you would let them be fun, but you have to drag them on and on like its warren beatty in REDS or something. Dont you understand no one wants these movies to be this length, do you think all the people im sitting in the lobby with while the movie is finishing had to take shs??? No, they couldnt take it anymore. No one can take it anymore. The next marvel movie better be no longer than an hour and a half or im going on hunger strike in front of marvel headquarters.

I am struggling to understand how this movie is rated so highly. It just...should not have been made. There is so much nonsensical crap going on that you just tune out. I know you have to give the Deadpool character some grace however, the movie falls short in a bad way.What is up with all the random character appearances? That makes zero sense. I cannot believe I sat through this debacle. It is by far one of the Wolverine movies to date. He should have stayed dead. His character was not honored in this sham.Do yourself a favor and steer clear of this sh@# show. They did fans a grave disservice.

This was the worst wolverine or Deadpool I have ever seen. A little too much butt comedy for adults. Didn't like it that Deadpool seemed to be working out his gay tendencies in this movie. Walked out of this before it was even over. Was this just to introduce all of the actors to some future movie? The blood soaked fighting just reminded me of a comedic cartoon. I kept watching to see if there would be some kind of a serious plot and a suspenseful rest of the movie, but it just never happened. The Spider-Man movie seem to be the only worthwhile marvel to show whatsoever. Not so many butt jokes or weird discussions that aren't appropriate.

With the overall positive reviews and promise of being Marvel's only superhero movie of 2024, I hoped I'd enjoy it. I also like the wolverine character and found some enjoyment from Deadpool in the past. Particularly in the first Deadpool movie. However in spite of some of the jokes being funny, I overall was not very entertained. I'd say a big reason for this is that there felt like there were even fewer real stakes for the superhero characters than normal. Both could regenerate. And everything else was so hammed up as part of comedy, that there didn't seem to be a lot of care for me in any of the character. Not only did they not seem to be real or in serious danger, but they didn't seem to analogous to something or someone that mattered to me either.The easter eggs were relentless in a bad way. They did the multiverse thing again. And it really seems to make it so anyone who dies feels like they were just a video game character losing one life rather than losing the entire game. The only one that I thought did the multiverse idea particularly well was Sony with the Spider-man and the Everything Everywhere all at once movie. I think this is because the stories were a bit more ambitious, original and cartoonish in style, and they made each interaction of each universe unique enough to each matter to the viewer and feel indispensable from one universe to another.This movie will not age like fine wine even if you enjoy it now. You probably won't enjoy it much in 10+ years. The 4th wall breaks are part of the style and identity of Deadpool. But perhaps they should have been relegated to one movie or at least had a few more of Deadpool's established original friends be part of his journey in this movie. That way there could be some more stakes for them rather than for others.

Complete and utter waste of money. Would much rather have watched this movie at home if I wasn't misled by the hype. Plot felt really boring and there's far more dialog than action and the dialog was hardly entertaining, although I do agree that the funny parts were pretty funny. Feel like this movie is far too overhyped, with marketing pushing it very hard. The only thing I enjoyed is that they bought some of the old superhero's back from pre-iron-man/'08 saga. It's a nice homage.Jackman did a great job and I feel like he worked out even harder than for his previous xmen movies looking at his abs being even more prominent, especially against the age he is now. It was nice to see Laura or X23/ his side-kick from the Logan movie.

I fell asleep twice during the Deadpool & Wolverine movie. It's not funny, quite boring, and ultimately feels useless. The plot drags on without any real direction, and the humor falls flat, failing to capture the essence that made Deadpool's earlier films enjoyable. Wolverine's character feels underutilized and out of place, adding nothing substantial to the story. You can exhange Wolverine with any other hero and the story will be exactly same. The action sequences are uninspired, and the dialogue lacks the sharp wit expected from a Deadpool film. I'm truly surprised by the positive comments I've read about this movie. It's disappointing, especially given the potential of these iconic characters. Definitely not worth the hype or the time.

Let me start with saying im probably the only one who didn't like this movie I really had a hard time not walking out of the movie theater. I stayed and watched something I would rather classify in the tv comercial (comedy/sketch) department. Then in the major movie theaters. Deadpool 1 and 2 at least we're easy to watch hillarious full of good action /fight scenes . The CGI was good and not overdone . And the acting was good.But this final version of Deadpool and wolverine, is just a chaotic bunch of mixed together edited together comedy sketches, that belong in tv commercials or one the comedy central .But not on the big screen. There is like no storyline whatsoever in it yeah sure the description says otherwise .But what's supposed to be the story all I seen in the movie, was him looking for a wolverine, and killing everyone on his path . And 90%of that was cgi animated bull..t. The only posetive was the little snippets with blade in it, but those also looked more like something that was part of a comedy skit, rather then part of a movie .So overall review .Acting was bad because the movie was mostly cgi. So little to no acting neededDialogs were cringe aside from the jokes Storyline : what storyline ??When I left the movie theatre I thought by myself wtf did I just watch, I Rather could have stayed at home, and just rewatched the previous Deadpool movie's that would have been more entertaining.

Deadpool. It's like watching the Naked Gun movies killing Leslie Nielson's career all over again, except this time with Hugh Jackman in DeadPool. The thing with Hugh Jackman, though, is that he is the white Denzel Washington, and no matter what he does or how it's done, he will create movie magic. He's just that great an actor. Not even Ryan Reynolds's curious foray into the dark side of movie magic can diminish him, but boy, did he try. In this movie, Ryan brought back some great cameos onto the screen (no spoilers here) that seemed to expose a not-so-cynical side to him. He seems to have a positive leadership vein and a seemingly cumbersome drive to advocate for others. This may be how he became so successful with Boost Mobile, his leadership, his compassion, and his promotion of others. However, Ryan has a dark side to his comedy that he apparently thinks about a lot and he has developed this entire Deadpool franchise around it. But I do not believe that is who he is, and I am pretty sure Blake tells him that regularly. He's not that dark, angry, cynical guy from which this Deadpool character was carved. The movie's whole premise is that he wants to be beloved and accepted into the Marvel Universe.Ryan Reynolds is a natural comedian with a God-given talent for comedic timing on the level of Carol Burnett, Harvey Korman, Lyle Waggoner, and Tim Conway, all wrapped in one. Maybe that's a little generous, but I do like Ryan. But unlike in his business ventures, in the movie realm, he doesn't seem to listen to the other voices in the room or to focus groups. Someone undoubtedly said to him, enough with the stabbing and the blood. It's boring. It's not even juvenile. It's something from a deep, dark place in him that he wants to put in our faces, along with imagery of sexual trains and bulging pockets, if you know what I mean. It's pointless. It's not funny to youngsters either. The only funny part for youngsters is that I, as a parent, would take them, my kids, to a movie displaying such images. For such a talented comedian, it's baffling that he is stuck on these galling images.If Ryan Reynolds chooses to use his talents to create Deadpool sequels in the likes of the Naked Gun series, it would be welcome in my home. Even the Naked Gun sequels had sexual innuendos and comedic physical comedy bits parodying this sexual act and that sexual act. One that comes to mind is when Detective Drebber was on top of the wheelchair scientist ala 69, and they went careening down the stairs. But it's all about how it's done. It was a funny scene that went from bit to bit and just got more outrageous as it went on. In this movie, Ryan has his hand stabbing one guy in his buttock from behind and the other hand stabbing another guy into his genitals, and then he rocks back and forth. It was all overdone, with nearly a minute of watching that. And that's 5 minutes (or more) into this scene, with all the stabbing and blood flying around. It's just ridiculous. Don't waste your time. It seems as though Ryan Reynolds has surrounded himself with yes men when he was making this movie to the point that no one could even tell him that enough is enough with the stabbing and the blood. Maybe the yes-men thing works in building a business, but maybe not so much in movie making-just a thought.

"Deadpool & Wolverine" had the potential to be a thrilling blend of action and humor, but unfortunately, the creators opted to rely heavily on excessive swear words and blasphemy, which detracts from the overall experience. The overuse of this crude language doesn't add depth or wit to the dialogue; instead, it feels like a cheap attempt to shock or entertain. This choice reflects more on the creators and those who enjoy such content than on the actual quality of the film. The movie falls into the same category as many Hollywood productions that prioritize profit over substance, catering to fans without moral values and good taste. It's disheartening to see talented actors and iconic characters reduced to this level, where the focus is more on pandering to a particular audience than delivering a film with genuine creativity or depth. This film could have easily delivered the same action-packed excitement and humor without resorting to such dribble, making the reliance on shock value all the more disappointing.

Deadpool and Wolverine was funny however; it wasn't necessary to mock Christianity. Wolverine was "crucified" and Deadpool refers to him self as "the Messiah" or "Marvel Jesus". It's fine that the writers are not Christian or religious; but what's the point of degrading the beliefs Christian audience's?Do the writers Rhett Reese, Paul Wernick, Shawn Levy, Ryan Reynolds, and Zeb Wells have something against Christianity specifically? Or Is it that they just don't know any better ?I admire all the writers and the their work, I just hope they would be more considerate next time.P. S. Jesus said, keep his name out your mouth.

Ok, held off watching this movie at its opening because i never believe all the hype, i finally was "in the mood" and went to see the thing. Now the only thing going for this movie is the impressive effects you can see alot of money has gone into making this movie . This movie felt like a rip off of DC animated Crisis on Infinite Earths. You have evil son of a gun that wants to destroy a universe. Check. Will he be satisfied destroying just one like a Lay's potato chip?Of course not. The different time lines ? The different versions of the Wolverine character . How many outlets have used the parallel doppelganger play? Lots .To me it just got stupid. As for this latest Deadpool saga Ryan Reynolds quick comedic quips get to be tiresome after a while. At least i did'nt pay to see the thing my wife did.

A movie made just to show Wolverine and Deadpool together. Did we need the stretched fight in the car, Deadpool too long monologue that killed the guy from Fantastic 4, other characters that showed up, just to be killed, plus some blood, was the Ant-Man skeleton really needed, some weird cloud made monster, they were feeding? Wolverine as a sort of VIP, without who the Universe will collapse? Whiskey supplies? Or they were alloud to take it with them.Professor's sister. Claims that she has a great time where she is, with the key in her pocket to a normal world. For sure. What's with all the Deadpools , really?Wasted opportunity.

As a big fan of Deadpool, and Reynold's interpretation of the character, it pains me to say that all Disney pulled off was a generic corporate-safe version of Deadpool. Really disappointed. By all means, the movie isn't terrible: great acting, great fight scenes, good gore, good production values... However, the writing feel flat due to what I assume was Corporate influence. After all, this IS a Deadpool movie without funny jokes nor any edginess. This is the safest R-Rated movie Disney could've done. The blandest thing made just for Reddit audiences... I don't believe I am actually saying this, but can we have 20th Century FOX back?Looking here on IMDB, I've seen people complain about IGN's 7 out of 10 review. Well, IGN was too generous.

I have no idea why people love watching this trash. No depth, just crude and vulgar humour with lots of unnecessary violence and blood. The bits that are supposedly funny are not. The best part of the movie was the last 10mins. If you are looking for fan service, Deadpool and Wolverine delivers. Please do not think this is Endgame level Marvel because unfortunately, it is not. Marvel put violent characters in a movie and said go for it. Great action (minus one scene near the end where Hugh Jackman or his stunt double must have just had enough and was clearly just going through the motions).The plot is just really, really, really bad. I can't type anymore as I'm thinking about lowering my score. This will definitely break records because fans want this but Russo brothers still are the kings of Marvel. Go and see it for the fan service but do not go in looking for some kind of direction for the Marvel universe, just have fun with it. If I could describe it, it is like driving through a brand new car wash, with the windows down.

I don't write many user reviews, as so many others do this just fine.But I cant seem to figure out, why this has so many 9 and 10 star scores ?There is even a mention about the "bald female actor" which describe her acting in this movie as bad ?I mean, she is litterally the best actor in this crew..And the story felt lazy written.Normally, I'm easy to entertain, and not very critical in my viewing. But I was kinda bored through this.I guess I should've seen it coming, from the last years promotion and endless spoilers.And the trailer on YouTube apparently made it to guinness book of records.I wouldn't be surprised if they also payed for the 10 star reviews in here ..In comparison , I was entertained much better in Thor: Love and Thunder , and even the Captain Marvel movies, was not this bad either.If you asked me, this should've been skipped, for a total reboot of the cinematic universe.I guess, maybe, if you are a die hard deadpool fan, this movie is kinda.. mediocre.. = 5 stars.

I was anxious to continue watching movies, to see if this would calm him down.Yisus Marvel is similar to the real Yisus in that it always promises to come back but never arrives.You can continue to make jokes about penises and anus, break the 4th wall and point out what you are doing, which is just what you have done before and yes dear nerds, let's do that ooagain but raised to the cube and then 3 lines of Inca dandruffThe film is based on that, and on the 20 years of history of the MCU, which as in the comics to understand most things you need footnotes about which comic or character they are referencing, that of course is a delight for fans who can take the meme of Captain America or Dicaprio and say "I understood that reference".At what point did the history of the MCU become more important than the history of the movies themselves? The point they've reached is that the story really is the least of it and as Ryan Reynolds would say, each one is a long trailer for the next and so on.The best, the end credits with behind the scenes of the death Fox's films and the cameos of course.

Reynolds is good with his quick wit. The film is too long but hollywood just wont stop doing that.Unfortunately wesley snipes and jennifer gardner are in it too.Disney adds the usual political messaging but in a more subtle way usually except a few scene where its blatantly obvious feminist agenda which distracts from the story of course but the executives think we need to hear it again and again.Overall I enjoyed it and I dont like this genre or disney at all.The fight scenes are over choreographed and too long but I guess some people like that?I suspect they let Ryan ad-lib a lot which was a good idea to let someone who is naturally funny come up with dialog rather than the union wirters.

I liked this movie. I liked this movie a lot. The cameos, the Wolverine, jokes, action, villain was ok. But many aspects were very great. But just not for a supposedly epic marvel comic book movie.Deadpool and Deadpool 2, in my very novice IMDb amateur opinion, were phenomenal comic book or superhero movies! Case in point cable and juggernaut! I still can't speak enough of how epic those two films were. But this Wolverine and Deadpool movie, even with all the pizazz, could not quite measure up to those movies. I think the reason it couldn't was due to the far fetched script. It was just too out there.But seeing Wolverine and Deadpool together on the screen was great. However, I need more than a team up to make a movie a success.Lastly, why does Ryan have to make so many jokes about men? Are the comics like that? Anyways, great comedic movie. Enjoy!

TL;DR: turn off your brain for 2 hours & pretend to be entertained.I actually believed they would've pulled off somewhat of a masterpiece. But this was 2 hours of shameless, pitiful fan pandering with little to no focus to everything else that should matter to a so-called super-action flick. Story and combat.It falls short on both. Plot is lame as hell, with the uber-predictable "save your universe from extinction at the hands of Skeletal Bald 5-foot Chick villain of the week at the 11th hour".And when the narrative isn't blatantly sucking off Wolverine, it just serves a never-ending Exposition train & lame telegraphed one-liners about how bad Marvel has been doing, taken directly from Instagram comments of random people with 0 posts and private profiles.The fight scenes are below par with far too much focus on close-quarters combat, which is probably due to their ages - Ryan is almost 50 and Hugh is nearing 60.And the cameos. Well, I don't know Ryan's history with everyone else but the return of Wesley Snipes as Blade, considering the bad history between the 2, seems like a Pity Job designed to humiliate the man now that Wesley is in the movie that Ryan is in charge of, instead of the other way around. Making him smile like an idiot donkey at the end was far too obvious.After all we all know how fake-nice guy Ryan treats those he doesn't like, made apparent by showing the famous Avengers 2012 action shot that gets cut off abruptly just before it shows Black Widow - Ryan's real-life ex who he heavily resented because she's a successful independent woman and he's an extremely insecure little man. Hence why he married a nobody after her, so he can be the star of the family.Quite ironic seeing how it's fairly obvious Ryan's star is fading fast. Nothing he's done outside Deadpool in the last 10 years is ever mentioned. Which is perfectly reflected in DP3. A stale, unfunny nostalgia act. And if this is what it takes to gross over 1 billion at the box office in 2024...cinema is well and truly doomed.Ryan's fragile ego might as well have left in the Captain Marvel & She-Hulk cameos because it's not like they would've made the movie any worse than it actually is. He managed that all on his own. I'm glad Marvel/Disney put their foot down and stonewalled him on releasing the bonus footage he wanted to show off to please his ego. Know your place, little man.

Subjectively, I understand the title as "Fun enough, but too meta". However, that's for everybody to decide for themselves.I accidentally paid for this movie twice. I selected a wrong day the first time around and before I noticed my mistake, the movie was already over. So, it doesn't really matter what I think, I've already voted for this thing with my wallet.First of all, kudos to everyone involved, especially Bob Chapek (this wouldn't be greenlit without him). I know it wasn't easy to get all these people and IPs together.Humor: Three times the same gets old. It's like Jack Sparrow - he's fun but his jokes get stale after a few movies. I loved H. J. and R. R. play against each other though.Immersion / 4th wall: There's no 4th wall, no immersion. Hence, there's ironically no breaking of the 4th wall.Characters: There are no characters, only actors. Hence, you are never really concerned for their safety. Nobody died during the production to my knowledge so there was no need to be concerned.Plot: The same thing as above. This isn't the usual story movie, this is a commentary about the current state of things in Disney and Hollywood. You could watch a Doomcock video just as well. On that note, the whole project was a nod to the HiSHE video for Logan.Soundtrack: None, if I remember correctly. Just a random collection of pop songs, as usual.In the end, it's all about what you want from this. Does it deserve 8+? For me, absolutely not.

Try to ignore much of the bad reviews, it is readily apparent many of them have never read a Deadpool comic, and are strictly comparing Deadpool 3 to Deadpool 1 and 2. Yes there is a lot of 4th wall breaking, and there may or may not be a plot, depending upon how you see it, and there is an abundance of cameos. But, news flash, that is how Deadpool is. To those who take the time to look outside of the films, and to comic book fans, pick up a Deadpool comic. He is in every universe. Personally I enjoy when he teamed up with Tom Sawyer, the times when he changes history, or when he killed every MARVEL character, (at least a few dozen times).The point is, don't look for plot in Deadpool. He was driven insane, and I am saddened and amazed that Reynolds hasn't been able to show the multiple voices in his head yet, (there are at least two aside from his usual personality portrayed in the films), and having multiple 'pools is par for the course of accurate portrayal of the character. This is a film written by Deadpool fans, for Deadpool fans, and for people to learn more about the character. The film was fantastic.

The first 2 movies in this trilogy had a great collection of misfits including ones without super powers such as Dopinder, Peter, the blind lady and the bar man, plus some comical super powers such as "luck" which set these movies apart from the typical Marvel movies.Sadly what we have here is very close to a typical Marvel movie. They should have just called it "The Wolverine (and Deadpool)". Sure we have Ryan Reynolds addressing the audience directly, taking jabs at Fox and Disney etc, but with so little of the team from the first 2 movies we just have Ryan Reynolds gushing over Hugh Jackman for nearly 2 hours with your typical X-men style plot. Ryan is supposed to annoy only the characters in the movie, not the viewers too.There are enjoyable moments in the movie, but I was hoping for Deadpool 3, not Wolverine 10 and the whole experience seems a sellout.

Deadpool (Ryan Reynolds) is living an empty life after breaking up with Vanessa. The Time Variance Authority captures him and Paradox (Matthew Macfadyen) intends to destroy his universe. He escapes and recruits the worst Wolverine (Hugh Jackman).The Multiverse strikes again. My first impression is that none of this matters. There is an infinite number of everything and there is no stakes in any of this. As the movie goes on, I find some fun in Deadpool pulling references and not treating the multiverse so seriously. Then comes all the old movie versions and it's fun nostalgia. I started hoping that Deadpool would end the multiverse. If I have a vote, that's the next movie. Feige could be the big bad and Deadpool could burn down Marvel headquarters. After that, they would have to restart the MCU.
